text: looks inviting .  somewhat thin but more close to medium .

s - prominent citrus hops , mostly orange , with some floral , and a nice , strong , sweet caramel malt undertone . t - hop flavors again with grapefruit and pine .  it is slightly watery on the palate .
had a pretty nice look to it . pours dark , dark brown with a dark colored frothy head that lingers .  m - some carbonation , not much to speak of .
appearance : golden with a nice amount of head that stays with it until the last drink .  lowish carbonation and a light , smooth mouthfeel .

a - a very light straw color with great clarity and a large , thick white head . perfect . this looks tame like a corona but has loads of complexity .  i had this beer at the great waters facility as we stop in often . i try to take notes on the beers i try but sometimes forget . the attack was very smooth and there was a sweet and smooth flavor with faint hops character at the finish . i do n't think i have had any cask beers at great waters that i did n't like .

330ml bottle served into an snifter glass.enjoyed on sep11.pours intense orangish copper in color , chill haze appearance.crowned by a creamy light yellowish off-white thick layer froth.brief retention leaving some spotty lacing.yeast & intense caramel malt aromas . buttery bread , toffee hints & slightly fruity -apricot & peach- notes to the nose.spicy , orange zest & subtle coriander flavors.gentle warming alcohol.sweet bitterness in the middle.medium but intense body.soft carbonation.dry bitter finish.smooth fruity aftertaste.a beer for a long & paused drink.a nice warming beer .  m : gritty and more astringent than any brown ale i 've ever tasted , very porterish feel .

hard pour gets a beautiful head to rise up , just a little more than two fingers worth of off-white frothiness . smells phenomenal . a bouquet of citrus hops , with a little bit of floral and maybe piney for good measure . so nicely balanced , just a little bit of bitter and the rest is flavor . the alcohol would probably catch me a buzz after just a couple , but it certainly weighs in a little lower than some comparable ipas , which is nice .  too much carbonation for this style ( -1.0 ) .

they share the same appearance if poured into the same glass , and the head is excellent . the taste is almost identical , with the can version being perhaps a little more bitter . i think these nitro cans are a great invention .  this beer was purchased at cyclone liquors , in ames , iowa . the beer was very dark in color and tasted very well . i drank the beer warm and i think it was a good beer . i would try this beer again if it was presented to me . it had a very nice sweet taste for a german dunkel , which i am not a huge fan of .
) tasted 10/02 : bronze/bright amber color with good tan lasting head .  m-explosive carbonation . tough to gauge the feel over the bubbles . a bit too carbonated for me .

a harmonious aroma of raisins and rosemary , dominating . dates and caramel , intoxicating sugars . wow , taste is right there too . it 's just alluring .  light copper color with a large head s. malty with a slight resiny hop smell t. more bitter than sweet but well balanced with roasted malt m. a little to acidic and carbonated for my tastes d. a good lighter amber ale that i can heartily recommend

smell is quite tart smelling , bit of sweetness , can easily make out the raspberry aroma .  pretty weak mouthfeel , it 's a bit watery . i 'm enjoying the flavour and aroma quite a bit but the mouthfeel is a bit weak . but lacking in mouthfeel .

pours black and thick . substantial tan head that forms of a billion tiny bubbles then morphs into a very slow fading creamy foam .  the feel had decent carbonation , if only it had n't been followed by a lingering metallic feel on the tongue .
sweet tropical notes , mainly mango accompany a major amount of hops in the scent . there was a lot i liked but overall very good .  m. a bit acidic d. overall a nice iipa .

this beer opens with a strong cranberry wash and finishes with an odd mix of the tart cranberry and heavy saccharine of the molasses . it 's certainly enojyable enough , but has trouble deciding whether or not it wants to be a dessert beer .  m/d - a little sticky but the body is still thin and it feels appropriate for the style .

a beautiful brown with red highlights and a tan head that lasts and sticks .  m & d - the brew is a tiny bit watery , the doughy character is a tiny bit too small , and so the mouthfeel is n't as full as i 'd expect .
smells great . spicy , malty , slight peppermint .  mouthfeel is a little too carbonated and light but i still enjoyed the beer in-spite of those tow minor complaints .

s- smells like autumn . upfront you get a nice whiff of pumpkin and spices . the rum creates a perfect blend here . adds a great alcoholic sweetness to the aroma . t- after the aroma , i ca n't help think that this was a let down . the blandness actually intensified as the beer warmed .  and this is a surprisingly warming , earthy-tasting beverage for a `` summer ale '' -- i would n't mind opening up one of these in midwinter either , except in that it lacks body . it 's in the mouthfeel that the summeriness stands out .
does n't quite live up to the smell , but still very pleasant and highly sessionable .  medium bodied and a bit sticky in the mouth .

incredibly fresh hop aroma . absolutely unbelievable . must try these galaxy hops for my homebrew soon .  the first time i had this beer , i distinctly remember it being among the worst i had ever had . apparently my ba colleagues disagree , so i 'm giving it another try . there is some faint grassy hops , but this beer is mostly about the malt character . overall , this is way better than i remember . i might have to make this a regular part of my beer fridge ! or perhaps they had n't figured things out when the brewery was just getting started . glad that there 's another quality beer in e-town .

aroma is complex and deep- cherries , plums , cloves , cinnamon , orange peel and nutmeg all seem to float on a platform of caramel and molasses . but what starts out as intriguing eventually becomes overbearing by the end of a 750ml. , and those phenols become too prominent .  more carbonation would go a long way .

it smells great , a little like their nut brown ale , which along with the oatmeal stout are two of my favorite beers .  s - some grassy hops paired with caramel malt t - slight hop bitterness resolving into some serious roasty malt , but then it 's all gone fairly quickly with just a hint of woody bitterness m - quite light with just a hint of carbonation on the back of the tongue ; the slight bitterness endures for a whlie d - quick drinkable , though the excessive roasty malt will probably get in the way ; little to no alcohol warmth nice drink ; did n't expect it to be as dark as it is - listed as an american porter , but it 's almost a supercharged brown ale .
the hop aroma is like sticking your nose in a bag of cascade hops and taking a deep breath .  m : very smooth , but seems pretty thin in terms of the body of the beer .

the smell is very strong of nutmeg , cinnamon , pumpkin . this is an excellent pumpkin ale . the scent is so strong you will convince yourself that a pumpkin pie is baking nearby .  mouthfeel was average .
the spiciness attacks your olefactory senses with a vengence . aroma reminds me of some winter warmers i 've had .  mouthfeel : a bit thin and watery .

the best part of this beer was the nice grassy hop aroma ( dry hopped with fuggles ) .  i first had this beer a year ago and fell in love . so i was excited to see it appear once again this fall . i find it a very easy beer to drink even for the inexperienced beer drinker . flavorful and rich with malts , a slight hint of hops towards the end . the aroma is sweet but not overpowering , you can definitely smell the sweet malt that went into this brew . i highly recommend this beer . unfortunately its not around year round but it definitely will give you something to look forward to come fall .

the pour was impressive as a dark chocolate filled my beer mug , the smell was pretty good with those hints of chocolate coming to bear .  had to give it the maximum points for appearance , because even out of an imported bottle , it looks just right . comes in with an alcohol bite that 's almost like an imperial . pertty nice taste , though , and if you had some , i would n't refuse .

4 finger frothy white head with great retention and lacing .  this is pretty good , but not up to the level of most other weihenstephaner beers in my book . the aroma is raisiny and alcoholic with grapes , dry grain , hint of bread , honeym , pine , herbs , and hay . the taste is bread , herbs , pine , faint hints of honey , apple and lemon , with a tingly pine-herb flavour and bitterness , along with a faintly rough , thin mineral-water quality . it goes pretty well with food and is fairly easily drinkable , but not great .

a : what a great looking stout . deep brown color with an extremly silkey 1/2 '' head that slowly disipates into lacing s : roasted malt t : grain sweet ness and roasted malts m & d : mouth feel was medium and dry .  this is an excellent pilsner . number three on my list , only behind konig and pilsner urquell . just as crisp and refreshing as both of those , but a little lighter in taste and body . very clean , top quality .

pours copper in color , red hues and gets lighter the more you drink ... how surprising . a massive off-white head , tight bubbles of carbonation and superb staying power .  this is a great light summer ale from pike brewing . this could be a great crossover ale for the bmc drinkers . it is very light yellow and clear . head is white light and fluffy , overall a great light easy drinking als . this is a beer that everyone will like .

looks great ! great color , small head .  smell : uh oh , something is going wrong ... taste : blecchhh . my stomach is starting to turn . what happened to this beer ? simply put , the taste is sour and offensive . beef notes : horrible . what was the thought process when putting this beer out for sale ?

this is delicious beer . the aroma is just like liquor soaked fruit , with a hint of cinnamon . it 's got a nice clear amber color .  the mouthfeel was a bit watery which could be due to the fact it is only 4.8 % and thus not alot of malt was apparently used , but i think it held up well over time , although i have not tried this fresh so i can not compare .
the off-white two finger head is dense and creamy , holds up extremely well and leaves patches of sticky lace .  good carb , but feels a bit thin and watered down in general .

extremely fruit-fillled aromatics - pungent apple sauce notes lead the way into a more diverse array of stone-fruit esters . lush oaky notes with a touch of bergamot in the finish - complexity grows as the beer warms . i 'm still impressed that the base beer can be improved upon by soaking up the best characteristics of the barrels it is aged in , but these special editions of harvest ale have certainly `` matured '' more than simply `` aged .  the carbonation is surprisingly strong for the style .

smell is awesome -- the smoked pork hits you first , followed by hints of raw sugar , honey , apples or pears , and black licorice . first few sips have an element of 'burnt'-ness to them , but once you get used to it , it 's quite pleasant . there 's almost a saltiness to it , with some background flavours of coffee , chocolate , and strong malts .  m good medium body , with a lot of carbonation , either takes away from this beer .

smell is very appealing indeed : very fresh , clear orange , a bit banana , defenate floral hoppyness , and also some spicyness/clove .  i think that the long trip from greece to williamsburg , va did n't treat this beer too kindly . pours and looks like the standard heine-clone . taste was rather flat .
s-this beer has a nice sweet flower aroma with hints of roses and apricots .  the mouth was a bit oily but not unpleasantly so .

the aroma is a beautiful butterscotch malt and caramel experience , like candied hops . there is a hint of some apple but all in all i would say this smells more inviting than it tastes .  smooth , nice , a little thin maybe . not a ton of carbonation at the end which leaves it a little watery .

pours a beautiful bright burnt orange color with a hefty tan head that bubbles up at first and leaves lots of lacing .  mouf & gt ; average drinkability & gt ; great ! more beers to add to the breakfast menu at my house .

a heavenly delight of a smell taste : 2.5 this beer is incredibly sweet . loads of candy sugar in this , i am sure . this beer has crazy sweetness its very cloying .  good coffee and chocolate and malt ( ate a small piece of oreo birthday cake with this and it was damn near orgasmic ) mouthfeel is surprisingly thin .

into a large tulip glass , there 's an instant dispersion of foam billowing in the glass , even with the slightest trickle from the bottle . swirling the glass whips it into a pruneish tan meringue . like a cumulonimbus cloud , the foam defies gravity and pushes above the rim , forming irregular peaks and crags . it coats the glass like suds from a bubble bath , sticking in fluffy 3-dimensional shapes all around the edges .  smoky , malty and mildy coffee-like . deep black with a thumb thick mocha head . fore is hoppy bitter then roasted barley malt follows . very much in the fullers vein as opposed to the more roasty and coffee/chocolate flavored american porters . very nice brew .

insanely tart notes of lemon zest , white grape rinds , and dry oak barrels . so incredibly tart ; for me , the only comparable wild ale is batch 2 beatification ( in terms of sheer sourness ) . fantastic beer .  mouthfeel : thin yet flavorful .

quite nice . p : rather boxy and angular at first , with no discerning flavors other than a malty bitterness .  a bit watery at the start , but , it gradually gains weight as it rolls to the back of the palate .

drank it on draft at legacy and at reading country club i have also had three cases of it made for them by the lion in bottles it is smooth favorful light and not biteing , nice head great smell very refreshing to drink it is a amazing product that they have made it is very nice to just sit and drink again and again .  m - kind of watery , but good carbonation .

there is a magical cascading effect within the beer as it settles . a beautiful off white head remains perfect throughout the experience lacing is awesome .  poured chilled in large ale glass ; bottle courtesy buzzlitebeer a : dark chocolate colored ; good frothy head ; decent carb action s : chicory and ( what ? ) tobacco predominates ; musty coffee t : wow , unusual ; the brown ale is a base for experimentation into coffee and tobacco ; bitter cacao serve this to friends and you 'll definitely have a talking point ; it 's very distinctive

i prefered the tap version as the apricots were so intense in the aroma as the bottle had more funk and barnyard . apricot , lemon and peach flavors . moderate acidity for a cantillon . the palate could be drier and the carbonation more lively but this a stellar offering by cantillon once again .  m : a little thin on the body , and surprisingly light and spiky with the carbonation .

appearance : burnt amber with a big bubbly pure white head that has a steam of rising carbonation feeding it . tons of stickage as the head slowly drops . pretty stuff .  mouthfeel seemed a bit to lean to me .
almost no froth , no noticeable bubbles , very good looking beer .  the body is on the thin side , with below-average carbonation .

good lacing & head retention s : intense almost burnt caramel & malt & some alcohol t : smokey caramel & a little aclohol up front , then a hint of cherry & oak . finishes with dryness , a slight smokeyness & a praline sweetness mf : sticky rich body with excellent carbonation & balance drinks good , but 2 would be about my limit .  this beer has a flavor i really like m- pretty thin and bubbly , almost reminds me of a bmc feel o- one of my favorite tasting pale ales .

was picked up by my bro-in-law and quickly swept away to milly 's tavern to begin our pre-race inebriation . the pumpkin ale was a solid beer , and had a wonderful nose and flavor . the color was clear golden and the glass came lined with sugar and spice !  the body of the beer is actually approaching medium and the carbonation is not overly fizzy as many macros are .

s -- amazing smell of dark chocolate and roasted coffee , no sweetness to it , but very pleasant . t -- the coffee in the smell comes through the strongest , with a hint of the chocolate .  the only detraction i can fin is the below average body .

wish this tasted half as good as it smelled .  taste : sweet malt , raisins , a lot of sweet nutty flavors like pecans , sour/tart dark cherry flavor , ending with a nutty malt characters mouthfeel : really light body , low carbonation , pretty basic .

deep , shiny gold/light copper with good , medium creamy head , that lasts a few minutes , medium white sticky lacing , hugging the glass a good while .  as readily available as bud , and a whole lot better . a great fall-back session brew , which is good with a meal , or having several at a baseball game .

delicious citrus fruits with resin-y sweetness in the background -heavenly . d : a little too off-balance to be gulp-able , but certainly a yummy beer .  nice carbonation , but this comes off as a little thin . this should be more drinkable considering its thin body , but as this is a stout , the thin body is a bit of a turn off .

a - poured a nice rich brown / black into chalice s - sour fruit , tart , background malt t - sour , nasty , vinegary - tastes like a bad beer - bad oj , tomato and yeasts .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin and the carbonation is quite sharp ; a bit fizzier than i 'd like .

2010 vintage look : the beer pours a dark brown color with no head smell : chocolate , vanilla , caramel and bourbon taste : overly sweet ( dark fruits ) and alcoholic . bourbon is very much present , but the alcohol is sharp and disturbing mouthfeel : medium body with low carbonation overall : the beer could have been so nice , could , because the alcohol is so badly hidden that i can hardly distinguish this with a bottle of pure ethanol from my work .  tastes pretty amazing really . watery on the tongue but ends dryish .
smell- nice nose of hard alcohol , vanilla , deep caramel and barrel flavors .  it was also a little to carbonated for me in the mouth feel category .

it smells like when i picked hops and stuck my head into a box of them . it smells so fresh it 's wonderful . the taste was rather assertive in hoppiness .  a little lighter and less sweet than many `` real '' belgian beers , and a little thinner in the mouthfeel department .
appearance tan creamy four finger head on a straight pour . a good looking beer .  mouthfeel was a little thin , that 's my only complaint .

poured out of the bottle into my samuel smith 's pint glass a jet black in color with a nice 2 finger tannish-brown head that settled to about one finger after a few minutes .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin and harsh from the acidity and carbonation . also finishes quite dry with little to no bitter .

wonderful aroma ! it 's fantastic !  an e-mail from the brewery indicated that twins lager is not the same beer as hauenstein , just with a different label . schells tells me that the twins lager uses a different recipe and yeast than the hauenstein , but a side by side comparison leaves me wondering why they would go through the trouble . i have always liked `` cheap '' beers . the beer drinkers of olden days wanted it cold , crisp , and cheap . but for afternoon lazing back and swigging , there is certainly nothing wrong with a cold bottle of twins lager . twins lager might be `` twice as refreshing '' as the label purports , but , boy would it be a treat to drink an original recipe fitgers again !

a - pours a very clear rusty orange/chestnut brown with just a short layer of white foam that quickly disappeared s - really nice citrus aroma , mango , orange & grapefruit , really nice smelling beer t - mango , grapefruit and orange and lemon rind , there is a bit of bitterness that seems to taste like the rind not hops .  mouthfeel is somewhat disappointing . if we 're talking about banana bread here , then it should be thicker , like bread .

pour is a burnt gold or darkish amber with a foamy white head , but the aroma takes over immediately . smell reminds of an american barley wine . very rich and malty with tons of hops , it could pass for sn 's bigfoot .  it is a bit thin , bordering on watery with adequate to slightly low carbonation .

poured into a 16 oz becher , a near opaque dark brown with a huge rocky head and plenty of sticking foam , truly gorgeous , then it the wheels come loose from the cart .  the mouthfeel was thin with a slightly dry aftertaste .

s- wow , loads of scents starting with a spiced apple and spiced pear followed by great light sweet malt scents and of course the belgian bready yeast ... this reminded me of my trips i used to take to julian with my parents and brothers as a child , we would always go up there for some fresh apple pie and hot cider ... t- not as much as the smell , but still great . you pick up on the apple/pear , spices , light sweet malt and loads of bready yeast with a nice crisp finish .  bittersweet finish . kind of think and syrupy on the palate .

this beer looks wonderful . a beautiful mahogany red , cloudy and rich topped with two and a half fingers of rich foam . the beer leaves textbook rings down the glass as you drink it ( rather quickly ) .  a surprisingly great beer from a brewing giant . it could have been a little less punishing when guzzled , but hey it 's a dark beer and we are not dealing with coors light here . i think the beer is buitiful to look at , and is rather smooth . but the lable and beer fit perfectly ph
the smell- almost like pumpkin pie . could smell pumpkin and the right amount of spice aroma .  m - a little water , but it goes down smoothly d - this is a really good beer .

s - sweet malt , candy , prune , marmalade t - sweet malt that very quickly becomes medicinal ( cough syrup ) and spicy m - low carbonation and syrupy with a neutral finish d - enjoyable flavors , but the medicinal taste is overbearing  a little too thick on the tongue , but nice .
probably the most impressive head i have ever seen on a beer .  m : upper light body with high carbonation .

it pours a cloudy golden orange color and smells delicious . the nose had hints of orange peel , coriander , hops and light caramel . drinkability was a little low though due to the over carbonation and the sweetness of the beer overall , but very good . will buy again  in my opinion , flying dog brewery has created a great seasonal , smooth-tasting beer with very little bite or after taste . i would definitely recommend it to any self-respecting beer drinker who might be having an end-of-summer party this or any october .

appearance- poured a golden copper color with a decent carbonation and quickly dissipating white foam head smell- sweet malts and green apples were the first things to hit me off the nose , sugar sweet , lots of apples maybe caramel dipped ones even , appealing smell taste- a mix of sweet with slight twinge of bitter at the end .  mouthfeel is sticky-sweet and dense .
lots of apricot and sweet smells on this one .  m : mouthfeel is decent , goes down reasonable smooth even with the slight burning sensation .

a- pours a pitch black hue with brown and amber highlights , small tan/brown head that is mostly sustaining , fair amount of lacing throughout s- fruity scents dominated by raisins and dark fruit ( as advertised on the label ) , i am also getting tones of apple , peach , belgian candy , sweet caramel/toffee malts , and a modest alcohol presence t- initial taste is raisins , raisins , and more raisins ( almost cloyingly sweet ) , followed by a variety of fruits and spices , yeasty/bready/sweet malts , a little bit of chocolate and belgian candy , finishes with sweet malts , a touch of bittering hops and warming alcohol presence m- medium/full bodied with good carbonation , nice slick texture that coats the tongue in sweetness d- 9 % abv is well-masked , but this definitely a sipping beer to be enjoyed over time ( much like a port or desert wine ) .  the mouthfeel is very fizzy due to the ample carbonation .
nose was rich with fudgy chocolate , smoke and charcoal .  4.5 m - lacks body . a bit thin but spritzy carbonation .

the bashah has a body that is as black as midnight - very striking and its only with light held up behind the glass that you can catch a glimpse of deep ochre hue . produces a thick deep tan 2-3 fingers of head that contrasts beautifully against the dark body .  m : the body is not as thick as i was expecting . it on the thin side as far as stouts go , but drinks very smoothly . i would have liked a thicker body , but that 's just being picky .

awesome hop aroma of german noble hops . smells like tettnanger to me ... pleasant , dry and crisp character . decent hop bitterness and flavor .  smell is of old corn/rice and skunk . pew . taste was horrendous . a skunky malt liquor flavor mixed with sweet rice/corn adjunct . maybe it went bad on it 's journey from the carib-bean ? looks like i should have gone for the sam light that was also in the fridge ...
the aroma is sweet and rich , on the softer side as barleywines go , well balanced between caramel malts and woody hops .  the palate is average .

the smell is truly incredible , and the taste is malty and pleasant .  its perfectly balanced and not overly done . m very medium , which i find most all stone beers to be and i dont really complain about . the carbonation is present and isnt overly aggressive or submissive .
smell is fantastic ( i love hops ) .  m : starts off creamy , but i 'm pretty quickly struck by how watery this is . the carbonation is decent , but i find this surprisingly thin .

smells creamy/milky with rich , almost sweet coffee , chocolate , kaluha , cocoa , and a touch of green hops . absolutely divine . the flavor is roasty with burnt/charred malts , coffee , chocolate , and a medium bitterness .  m : a little bit thinner than expected , medium-light bodied with low carbonation , lightly creamy .
pours very golden , pretty clear looking . great head that sticks around and some nice lacing .  like cheap malt liquor infused with citrus and nail polish remover .

nice retention and very good lacing . clear amber color makes this an all around great looking brew .  very well carbonated , but not alot of head . i am thinking its a unique hop that i have not experienced alot of . thoughts - this beer is one of my favs from shiner .
appearance & gt ; yellow , lively . lovely .  ) my only qualm was the the body seemed a little thin .

a : pours amber color , small white head , slight lacing down the glass s : smell is very citrusy , slight malt background t : taste is also very citrusy .  this beer poured a dirty blonde color , with a haziness that made me suspect that i would n't enjoy this beer too much . aroma was malty , and flavor was a sweet maltiness with only a hint of hops . this was n't what i was expecting from an american pale ale , and i really did n't enjoy it . i may have gotten an old beer , but there is no date code on this beer , so i have no way of knowing its age and it gets what it gets ... most of this one is going down the drain .

smell & gt ; mmmm ! burnt toast and sweet malt . taste & gt ; not very complex but very good . nothing exciting . drinkability & gt ; i could drink this again for sure .  quenching , medium-light body , citrus-earthy character .

a : rather mild amber color , nice sudsy bleached-white head , globs of wonderful lace as thick as frosting on the glass paired with vibrant bubbles .  mouthfeel is probably the most disappointing aspect of this otherwise excellent beer ; the carbonation promised by the head largely disappeared , leaving a slick , full bodied beer with very light carbonation . a nice , sharp bite of carbonation would have been welcome in this case , drying out the finish nicely , but that does n't happen here .

really nice nose on this . a big whiff of belgian yeast , revealing dark fruits and a faint hint of very bitter cocoa . after a few nose dives in this one i 've become a bit used to the yeast smell and richer chocolate notes are revealed as well as a faint alcohol aroma .  the overall feel is dry , like it should be , but unfortunately , it 's also a touch chaulky , which is pretty unfortunate .

gives a snootful of dark chocolate and sweet dark molasses from 6 inches away , truly intense aroma . flavor is gently dominated by the chocolate , leans a little toward chocolate flavor extract , but nothing definitive .  my only complaint with this beer is that it is a little thin .

aroma is great . cherry , oak , cabernet , phenolic , yeast , sour , sweet tarts ... mouthfeel is a touch awkward with carbonation at first , but mellows during the drink as it warms . dry on the finish .  i 'd love to try this on cask , if only to taste it more directly without all the carbonation dancing across my tongue .
i hate it when that happens- it looks good , smells good , and then does n't taste nearly as good .  while the carbonation is nice , the overall feel is a bit thin .

aroma was an incredible with scents of spicy dark bread .  good carbonation and medium bodied . flavor is spicy , yeasty , hints of sweetness that gets buried by the yeast . lingering yeasty aftertaste .
great retention and generous lacing . lovely looking porter .  m - a little thinner than i thought and more carbonated than i would expect .

it is an aromatic potpourri of lighter hop notes . i like getting mint flavors and smells from a beer , it 's a sense that is under appreciated in craft brewing .  body is ok , nothing special but not bad . very boozy finish .
very nice aroma . hmm , not sure about the taste .  m- somewhat thin , actually . smooth , clean , but a little more watery than i expected .
pours a two finger cream head that fades slowly , leaving a good lace . nice deep amber color .  m : relatively light though not particularly carbonated .

the aroma is spicy with loads of malt and touch of hops . the nose is spot on with what i think a marzen should smell like . overall a decent marzen .  the mouthfeel was a bit unimpressive too light in my opinion .

paid $ 24.50 or so for the mixed case via lancaster county ... the beer pours a slightly hazy amber color with a large white head , exceptional retention and a dozen or so lacing effects , almost a perfect pour .  reminded me a bit of bmc with a bit of syrup added for sweetness . the taste is more of the same with a quick malty dryness at the end that seems to say , `` ha ! had you fooled..you thought there was about to be something pleasant here , did n't you ? in fact , this may get sacrificed to the kitchen sink . as i always say , in total fairness to the brewer and his ( or her ) intentions , this may have its fans , but it most assuredly is *not* for me ...

serving type : 16oz bottle appearance : pours a darker cloudy orange colour w/ a 1 finger head . plenty of lacing the whole time while drinking .  the mouthfeel is light bodied with a high level of biting carbonation ( the carbonation is the only part of this beer that i 'm not too fond of ) . quite dry due to the high level of carbonation .

it was quite amazing . nice bitter coffee notes , with more chocolate notes and sweet malts than with the aroma . this was smelling great , drinking good and going down easy .  a new contender for the worst beer i 've ever tasted . it tasted like a carbonated v8 with sweeteners added .
pours a rich brown color with a large froth of dense , creamy head . retention is good , but lacing is downright gorgeous .  m : medium to full body but needs more carbonation .

a : pours a beautiful bronze with ruby highlights . this beer looks fantastic . s : smell is of juicy citrusy hops , with an abundant dose of pale and caramel malt .  the mouth feel was hindered a bit , as the bottle had n't been sitting in my refrigerator long enough , the ale could have been a little more carbonated .

smells quite good . pours dark apple juice color , clear , mild head .  does smell a little like `` beer , '' as my wife would say . so sweet on the tongue . slight raspberry tartness but it is like drinking raspberry sorbet after it melts . it is still trying to recover from the sweetness . a good once in a while beer . sorbet beer , i tell ya .
put it under bright light and it looks magnificent in my flute !  mouthfeel is effervescent , lighter bodied ( almost thin ) , medium carbonation and slightly dry .

medium amount of carbonation s : i really enjoyed the burnt caramel smell that comes from the roasted malts . there is some maltiness , smokiness , and some slight sweetness in the aroma .  it is a little bit sweet on the tongue . i could stand it to be a little bit more dry .
smells wonderful , though a little bit of a mess , taste wise , still worth enjoying while available .  mouthfeel : surprisingly thin body , full carbonation , fairly thick coat after the swallow .

frothy near lace remains . the aroma is a vibrant combination of tangerine juice and zest hop nose along with mellow esters of a ripe pear nature . understated light caramel bolsters fruity sweetness . spot on and appetizing aromawise .  it was barely palatable : very little carbonation - full of sour , gone-bad notes .

aroma : it has that rare smell that is as full and alluring as you 'd hope it would taste : banana bread , roasted chestnuts , cloves , hints of chocolate , estery and phenolic notes . the finish is very clean , with lingering bits of pepper and chalky dark chocolate . mouthfeel : it has a very smooth feel even though the carbonation is quite prickly . the dark malts give it a fuller and more flavorful character than most saisons , although incorporating them also reduces the peppiness and refreshment of a traditional saison . would i get it again ? : yes . it 's a solid beer , and though not the pinacle of its style , a welcome alternative to traditional saisons . bottled : february 25 , 2011 served : may 6 , 2011 price = $ 8.99 at whole foods ( nyc ) additional notes : - international bitterness units : 30 - malt : pilsner , rye , crystal rye , black malt - hops : pilgrim , saaz  i got this beer in the beers of the world gift box for christmas . immediate taste is a lil sharp and bready with a hint of citrus in the smell . it was not an out of this world experience , but it is a very light and enjoyable beer for everyday or get togethers .

poured a 355 ml bottle , dated 15 nov 2007 , into a tulip . a : poured a massive 1.5 fingered creamy head , in a tulip this appears huge . the color is a glorious tawny . the carbonation is rising nicely in the glass and it seems as if the head is hardly going anywhere .  the mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with no carbonation .

the nose ? wow ! intense citrus and definite grape fruit aroma is almost overwhelming , but in a very , very good way . never had anything like it taste : as i go for the 1st sip , i 'm almost squinting my eyes , expecting to drink a form of carbonated grapefruit juice .  m- low carbonation , medium-body .

subtly fills your nostrils with sheer weight as well as clove , coriander spice , lemon peel , vanilla bean , has a lively yeastiness , some banana notes , while light of touch it 's never not there . the fruit mainly banana , pear , apricot , more skin and pit than flesh .  the mouthfeel i found oddly watery ... but still fairly full bodied at the same time . carbonation was fairly mild - maybe that lended to the `` watery '' sensation .

this beer pours with a thick and foamy head . wonderful active bubbles slowly float to the top to form a thick white head .  i 'm rather late with this review but i had this on tap at nicholson 's downtown and it reminded me of sierra nevada celebration . in fact at the time the original name was celebration ale . i 've since had a few growlers from jungle jim 's and though it 's a quailty brew i 've experienced some diacetyl like off-flavors when served from the growler . still it 's quite enjoyable and recommended . i wish the best to mike and his future brews !

achieved a very impressive tan head . the appearance was the best thing about this beer . wow , overhyped ?  carbonation a little higher than i expect in the style but still manages to be exceptionally drinkable .

ruby and brown shades with decent clarity , a beautiful 1/2 inch head of white foam sits atop with solid retention .  apricots . hops undetectable above the jaw-clenching , eye-squinching , head-shaking sourness . awful . ugh . otherwise , it defintely seems to be beer , ( if in no way resembling any version of a contemporary pa ) , but with a sour and bitter fruitiness that pervades , annoys , and overwhelms . the originally enticing head cashed in early and diminished to virtual non-existence before i gave up trying to like this one ; very little lacing to wash out of the glass . wo n't drink the other two in the sampler , did n't finish this one , and opened a sn celebration ale to get the taste out of my mouth .

aroma is sweet delicious malt bomb extravaganza . dark fruits , plenty of sweet caramel laced with burnt sugars , no heat at all , and a small amount of oaty malted milk ball aroma . a+ aroma for sure . this is one amazing beer , it woo'ed the hell out of me .  m - comes across a tad light on the carbonation , making it a bit watery for my liking .

poured almost pitch black , good size tan foamy head that diminished to a tan creamy collar that held the sides of the glass all the way down .  mouthfeel is light and carbonation fades to almost flat .
the nose is creme creme creme . the taste to too strong for the brule , which takes away from the nose of the beer .  the carbonation is ok ; small fresh bubbles at a decent strength .

nose is very full and really inviting . aromas jump out of the glass a buttery toffee . a big abv sipper with a great nose . sorry jay-bone , just did n't cut it for me .  m - body is a little thin , moderate carbonation .

huge off white head eventually settling to a half inch and tons of thick lacing . strong steady carbonation , perfection for this strong style considering lasting head on a barleywine is a rare happening .  mouthfeel was ok ; about the same as urquell .
pours near black with tan head .  mouthfeel is soft and a little heavy .
poured a medium copper hue with a huge chunky white head . there was very good retention and sticky lacing .  the mouthfeel was light but a bit chewy .
bottle to a tulip pours a clear red body , and by red i mean excellent vibrant red . has a fizzy white head that doesnt stay for the party .  light to medium in body .

smells amazing . chocolate and some buttery , boozy notes emerge with warming .  though this is a red ale of stormy garnet and the menu states it is `` brewed with 20 % honey malts for a touch of sourness '' ( honey = sourness ? it is not merely that this red ale tastes bad ; it is absolutely offensive . of the lowest evolutionary order . the entire beer is corrupted by spoilage and should n't be served publicly .

a-dark brown/black s-nice blend of cocoa and leafy hops..really impresses on the nose . t-hops are a little more forward on the taste ... .interesting hop dimensions ... some bright citrus ... .and some grungy pine and weed like notes ... roasted malts ... .also some darker cocoa ... m-rich ... fuller bodied ... .feels bigger than a regular black ipa ... body fits ... o-top notch effort .  m- a bit thin for my taste .

bottle acquired through recent secret santa swap w/ alohac pours absolutely beautiful brown tinged amber . fluffy , long lived , tan head with loads of lacing throughout .  m : medium mouthfeel with moderate carbonation .

smell- the smell is another one of my favorite parts about it . i can smell mangos i think . taste- ok at first it is a little bitter but once it settles it has a great full flavor tast to it .  mouthfeel : the carbonation is light , as is the body .

break out the smoked sausage , the perfect beer to accompany it is here . alaskan smoked porter is beautifully smokey . one whiff makes you think you 're in a great deli , loaded w/ good smoked sausage .  a - black on the pour with no head whatsoever s - big burnt malt and bittersweet chocolate aroma along with some bourbon , some oak and vanilla in there as well , slight alcohol , as the beer warms up , smells almost like straight bourbon , maybe more like a bourbon and cola t - big bourbon flavor right up front , lots of oak as well , some bittersweet chocolate in the body , finish is more bourbon and oak along with some vanilla , alcohol notes , long finish m - a bit too flat for my taste , full-bodied but totally devoid of any carbonation action in the mouth d - i 'm glad port put this in a 375ml bottle , because this is a sipper , treated this almost like fine bourbon sipping for quite awhile , but i could sip on this all night very interesting beer .

i just about busted a nut getting the # $ # cork off in one piece..ahh make that several pieces that did n't fall back into the bottle ... but after a long and arduos process the cork was successfully removed.. poured a dark brown ... relatively clear..absolutely no head ... mouthfeel is very uncarbonated..i love the nose ... molasses ... .brown sugar ... .dark fruits ( plums , dates , even burgandy cherries ) ..a bit of oak ... just an awesome smelling beer.. the flavors are similar to the nose but much more tame ... .dark fruits ... molasses ... oak ... good taste to this ... my biggest complaint is the loose mothfeel ... very uncabonated which gives it almost a watery texture ... seems almost thin ... overall , the nose is great and the taste is very good but the body leaves something to be desired..definitely worth trying ... i wo n't be buying any more though ... .  m - the feel is not terrible .
huge deep malty scents , with lots of caramel and toffee and a nixe bit of earthiness , as well .  the carbonation does not give this beer a pleasant mouthfeel that i would like .

the smell of tangerine jumps right out at you the moment you free this beer from the bottle . tangerine just fills the room . this is a unique ipa . fruit fresh from the tropics start this beer off . mango maybe ? the flavor actually kind of mutes itself in the middle and the hops kick in during the finish and stay . the hops are very citrus in nature and somewhat floral . i do n't detect the piney nature of a lot of ipa 's .  cons : the low carbonation level does hurt many factors of the beer , but it is such an exquisitely brewed offering , it 's only a minor issue .

2009 vintage poured into a pint glass a : aggressive pour yields 3/4 finger cream colored head with good retention . clear reddish copper liquid is beautiful s : herbal and earthy hop aroma .  this was my first encounter with pumpkin ale . i must confess that i could not finish the bottle . i had the distinct impression that the beer was trying to taste like something and not quite getting there . fearing the latter , i tossed the bottle after about five sips .

the aroma , however , is a-one , outstanding , and really well captured in the wineglass : nice , fresh pumpkin accompanied by strong notes of cinnamon , nutmeg , clove , maybe some ginger ... wow , this is the smell i look for in my pumpkin ales - imo they nailed it . that said , i feel the flavor takes a step back ; maybe the nose raised expectations too high ... still very nice , with the pumpkin and spices pulling through , but perhaps not as robustly as the nose had led me to believe ; there 's also a not entirely pleasant though subtle bitterness to it , as well as a bit a boozy bite to the finish .  i always look forward like most do the annual stone anniversary brews.poured a rich deep amber with a tight and sticky one finger off white head , big hops in the nose with a mix pine and herbal/leaf , there is a gummy , fruity-like sweet note as well.the mouthfeel is a bit sharp i will say it crashes down the gullett at first , it does begin to smooth out after a few sips but still seems a bit harsh.no holds barred hops hit the palate up front with big pine and big herbalness , a healthy does of sweeter alcohol gives a slight burn along with a bit of dark fruit.very good but seems like it something that should sit for awhile , still another fine one from stone .

awesome smell , couldnt wait to drink it !  drink this on tap at city beverage in durham . i like the color and mouthfeel , though a bit thin for a heavy beer aroma is slightly sweet and complex spices taste is toasted barley , spices , and slight caramel with little head . drinks easy for a heavy beer
the smell was delightful . with a hoppy nose and a touch of citris .  mouf & gt ; meh . okay . average .
excellent straw gold with a nice thick foamy white head and amazing lacing .  m : medium body with low carb . dry finish . nothing special here .

a- starts as a massive foamy cup of liquid , then turns into a very impressive carmel colored beer with excellent one inch head that hangs around for the whole pint . creamy look that is very appealing . heavy lacing on the glass ... great retention .  a completely black beer with a thin mocha head . boris is a thick , almost to the point of sludgy beer with a roasted malt taste with a noticeable but background hop presences . the oatmeal comes into play as a slight cookie taste . overall it 's a great beer that worthy of a try .
really nice aroma . smells of pecans , buttery crust , vanilla and dark fruit .  the only thing slightly disappointing about this beer for me was the mouthfeel seemed a bit watery .

smell : strong coffee notes over roasted malt . fairly straight forward but the limited dimensions it offers are good in their own right . taste : fairly waterly coffee rinds .  mf : the carbonation is n't quite as spritzy as i would hope to go along with the huge sourness , the body is light d : this is a great lambic .

the nose really is redolent of pepe du chat , gooseberry , bright herbal citrus with a nice minerality with a touch of dry malt - very sauvignon blancesque .  light , decently carbonated , and quenching for the desert dweller .

smell is intense . lemon sour acidity , pepper , lots of sweat & musk . sweet florals . earthy funk . it just seems more then a tad empty when compared to what i smelled up front .  a-garnet with small ring of foam s-raisin , pancake syrup , faint vinager t-assertive sour front , sour cherry , some malt sweetness , dates m-medium , with average carbonation d-very tasty !
this is quite possibly the sweetest smelling beer i 've ever sniffed .  flavor is absolutely nothing like an oud bruin .

s - a lot going on but still well balanced . smells of citrus ( maybe orange ) and pine , along with some winter `` spices .  the body is surprisingly light with moderate carbonation , helping to make this very drinkable .

poured into a goblet carefully to leave behind the yeast sediment . nice thin creamy head , that leaves great lacing all down the glass .  nice dark brown color with fantnaztic lacing ! smells choclotly with coffee . tastes even and thick with cocoa sweet caramel flavors continuing thru . good for its class this porter represents well , its much better than its younger brother . would drink again .
looks fantastic ! sort of a hazy golden apricot colour with a finger of foamy head that sticks around .  mouthfeel is a bit thinner than i would have expected .

poured from bomber into my stone irs snifter ( 2010 ) a - pitch black with a big persistent dark tan head . the head is beautiful on this beer . what an appearance !  mouthfeel is way more thin than the head and lacing made me think it would be . very quaffable .

the smell had a distinct piney hops character - lots of spruce needles . also present in abundance were the usual line-up of spices anchor employs ; clove , nutmeg , cinnamon , and molasses .  mouthfeel : this was my one issue with this beer . it loses carbonation quickly , and with not that much to start with , it is kind of a bummer . a little sticky as well but the taste makes up for a bit of this .

i 'm pouring this into my hotel low ball/water glass , for what it 's worth . looks like a fine scotch with a bit of bone white head at the top . quite a bit of visible bubbles indicates a good amount of carbonation .  tingly in the nose which is common with sour ales but this is n't sour at all t. sweet with dried fruit , malty m. has a biting quality , a bit to carbonated .

this brew pours a small head of dark brown colored bubbles and an opaque black brown colored body .  mouthfeel : a bit thin the only thing i can say i 'm disappointed about here just seems watery i even recall the original munich formula having more body but hey sturdy carbonation excellent o-fest .
pours a cloudy garnet hue with a thin but persistent head . leaves an incredible lacing on the glass .  thin mouthfeel , this is the achilles heel of the beer .

i am smelling a creme brulee desert right now ... i do n't think i could tell the difference from the real thing . exceptional . there is a touch of courseness in the back of the throat from the abv and bitterness .  m : it 's a little thin , but i kind of like it . d : improved because of the thin mouthfeel .
smells of raisins and roast malt and a little chocolate , very nice .  good carbonation , which i appreciate . minimal complexity to this beer .

appearance- one of the best looking belgian pale 's i have seen . a large 2 inch big bubbled head which 1/4 inch remains until the last drop is consumed . excellent lacing stuck to the entire rounded wall of my glass .  the mouthfeel is quite thin , verging on watery .

a - tons of carbonation streams up from the nucleation point to a puffy off-white head of almost three-fingers . good retention and clumpy lace above a totally clear golden yellow beer .  a soft , almost too light mouthfeel and a little weak carbonation , the only appearent downside of this brew in my opinion .

excellent nose showcasing the belgian yeast strains . even the hops come out kind of boring , with a mild bitterness that does n't satisfy . good body and carbonation , but drinkability suffers because it just does n't taste that great .  mouthfeel : it 's a bit heavy for the style .
color was a dark brown with amber highlights .  m - medium to light body , low carbonation , smooth mouthfeel going down , perhaps a bit watery .

a - a faint haze in an amber brew with a slight reddish tint . a frothy head that is long lived with thick clumps of lacing .  the feel is a little odd . it does n't seem to be too carbonated , but the bubbles sting like sprite against your lips .

the smell is extremely vibrant and spicy reminding me immediately of egg-nog . despite being very interesting and flavorful it becomes difficult to drink about halfway through .  m - extremely light and watery , typical carbonation from a cask .
the brothers consistently nail aroma . bubblegum and tart cherry with moderate roasted qualities and a faint hint of wheat twang .  mouthfeel : there is a lot of bitterness .

overall a fantastic beer .  is this someones idea of a joke ? rotten peaches with a kick of dirty feet is not something i prefer in my beer . sour an nasty , she be . i should have know by the pour , cider apple yellow fizzy white head . cripe , im glad i only got 2 bottles of this overpriced ( $ 2.50 a pop ) sour peach soda geez , only 4.5 % . i would have kicked myself in the sack for buying this , but im no longer that agile .

citrus notes are bright and festive in the nose , enticing . t : the nose is somewhat deceiving , this is a bitter bomb .  malts help to round it out a little , but that bitterness hangs around for quite a bit m : medium body with typical sa carbonation , slightly oily d/o : well , apparently zeus is known for that intense piney flavor , so it is highlighted well here .

smell is dominant dark fruit ( plum and fig ) with just hints of chocolate cake , cherries , and that leather smell . very complex . there is a dark smooth malt character and some caramel as well . i could smell this all day . taste is the nose , followed by a whiff of smoke and finishing like a rich deep red wine . my brother commented that he picked up on dr. pepper like qualities . caramel malt . mouthfeel was oily and clingy . drinkability : i know it 's a great beer but for me drinkability was just ok .  m : sharp carbonation is pretty overpowering , and any refreshing aspects of the smell and taste are lost .

boozy aroma with vanilla and oak apparent , notes of toffee and coconut , roast and chocolate , faint licorice and figs . great texture , full without being heavy , moderate carbonation that provided an airy mouthfeel , a bit of astringency from the kilned grains and wood , slightly sticky .  mouthfeel is on the light end .

s : very fruity , dark fruits ( raisins , plumbs ) and malts . t : very fruity , specifically raisins .  the mouthfeel starts off kind of watery since this seems to be a light to medium bodied brew and leaves a dry , but sticky feel to the lips .

very interesting bouqet-smells very much like a moscato d'asti frum the muscat grapes . also floral , sweet honeyed bready malts , and fresh ( not roasted ) nuts in the nose . medium to full-bodied and viscous , this could present a cloying sweetness after a while and as such is not a session beer , but definitely something unique and worth trying .  a little thin .

nose reveals a unique combo coffee beans , dark fruits , brown sugar and roasting malts .  i always drink my high life out of cans ! it looks like beer , smells like beer , and tastes like beer ... to keep it simple . this is my go-to macro , and will always be as long as miller keeps it the same ! prost !

really really strong nose - very sweet with notes of baking spices , vanilla , vanilla cake batter , pumpkin . there is also something about it that i 'm not sure i 've ever smelled before ... and i love it . t : lives up to the smell .  mf- raw resinous and sticky , becoming oily , medium carbonation , slightly astringent , dry and grainy in the finish d- well rounded ipa , but not the best around .
a very nice hazy orange color with a huge off-white head that subsides slowly and leaves lots of nice lace .  m : medium body but the finish is not as crisp nor as clean as it could be .

* subtle but complex aromas of dark chocolate , ripe cherries , sour fruits , currants , figs , beer bread and burnt sugar . taste is not as complex as the smell , and almost underwhelming with more dark chocolate notes , unripened dark fruits ( plums , grapes ) grain and yeast .  m- average medium bodied beer o- great take on a saison style beer .

rich with oak and dark malts , the aroma is a mine of chocolate , malted milk , coffee , molasses , figs , vanilla , walnuts , caramel , spiced with plenty of caraway , anise , tobacco , and floral hops . increasingly smoky as it warms , and very interesting ; the akavit is not subtle but well-incorporated with the base malt aromas . tangy and earthy on the palate , with a crisp caraway entrance and a long , luscious chocolate finish . juicy and rich yet sharp and bitter , this one balances coffee , citrus , licorice , oak , and red wine and yet it is n't quite as complex as the nose led me to believe . possibly an excellent match for game , assuredly for chocolate and blue cheese .  the flavor is a bit harsh and a bit watery , but not too much .

the aroma is possibly the best feature of this brew . very sweet and flowery , almost of lemon , chamomile , and honey with very strong hop overtones . a nice light amber color , slightly darker than the 60 minute .  mouthfeel & drinkability : lighter bodied and less bitter than most other ipas , which makes for quite easy drinking .
the nose was definitely black currant . fully authentic , interesting and inviting . a lindemans trademark smell .  m - a little harsh , not as smooth as other ipas .

smell & gt ; sweet and resiny . a perfect balance of the two scents without much alcohol heat .  poured from bottle to tulip glass a : brilliantly clear pale yellow color with huge 3+ finger head that fades very slowly n : nose of a light belgian type wit with some light malts , touch of spices , toasted quality , touch of yeast t : starts with more malts and toasted quality , pretty light otherwise , a touch of light fruits and banana , slight earthy marzen quality , no spices m : very light and somewhat watery f : finishes dry and very crisp with a fading earthy marzen taste , would make a good session beer final thoughts : its a very light tasting oktoberfest/marzen .
smells heavy of cherries , very good smell . taste is just as heavy with the cherries .  mouthfeel is a bit thin , but thats a minor complaint .

poured with a massive head and beautiful lacing with a murky golden tint - i have to admit the pour was promising .  the rye is evident , as is a tangy almost sour note along with the bread . a little over-carbonated ... i found it slightly distracting and that it may have affected my enjoyment of the beer 's complexity . light-bodied and very refreshing . while i have little to no experience with beers of this style , i enjoyed this one and i believe that its a great refresher during the summer months .

appearance : light yellow in color with a large soapy head that stays around the whole time . the head on this beer is remarkable and deserves recognition . at first the beer was fairly clear but later i swirled some yeast in and the beer became cloudy .  mouthfeel is poor due to the overdone carbonation .

this beer has the most incredible smell in the world . '' the big wafts of vanilla , caramel , and butterscotch fill the nose and is absolutely delectable . i could enjoy the aroma of this beer for hours . one bomber was enough for me , and i was pleasantly surprised .  medium bodied with carbonation that was a little too high and too coarse for my liking , but it did n't turn me off completely . my only issue was the carbonation .
smells pretty decent as well . quite delicious , really .  m - surprisingly , its a bit thin and lacks carbonation .
smell is mighty fruity with loads of banana and some vanilla .  medium bodied fairly low carbonation .

a - pours with one finger of white foam on top of a perfectly clear , copper colored body . the head settles slowly and leaves nice , thick lace .  light bodied for what i was expecting , but then it does n't claim to be a porter or stout .

a : pours a bright light amber with a large dense head that reduced into a delightfully thick dense foam dollop that floated on top of the beer . very active carbonation and fantastic lacing . head stayed forever with very impressive retention .  mouthfeel : a little watery , but not terrible .

a very easy drinking doppelbock , with terrific aromas , and a surprisingly `` light '' flavor and mouthfeel .  m : lighter than it should be and very creamy and smooth , decent carbonation . f : long creamy chocolate vanilla smoothness .
really enjoyable . t : sweet malts and slight hop bitterness .  heavy hops , but not totally unbalanced . very quenching .

s- very delicate yet strong lemony aroma . t- great yeast character elevates the otherwise bland hop/malt balance to something very enjoyable . m- very smooth yet light .  my first tripel style beer , i spit it on my counter . the flavors of fruit combined with a bitter aftertaste left one bottle down the drain , and three still sitting in their case . anyone near me is welcome to the other three . while i am confident in the quality of this product , this style is definitely not for me .

aroma definitely has the jp funk , with some wet hay and mustiness , with a decent amount of light fruits - apricots and oranges . there is also a solid oaky tannin character to the nose .  the body is medium with decent carbonation .

no lacing was evident as i drank this aromatic ale . speaking of aroma , this ale wreaks of bourbon and vanilla with some burnt wood smokey notes to finish . close your eyes , or keep them open , and waft a smell and you 'd think you were sniffing a high ball . the flavor is bourbon upfront , charred wood , vanilla and brown sugar .  spritely carbonated and fairly aqueous . very good but i would like a little more body .

smell ; perfect balance of rich , nutty and sweet malts and citrusy hops . beautiful aroma and the american hops work nice with the rich malts . taste ; starts with a sweet , sappy , resin flavor , mixed with white sugar .  actually thought it might be bad but when i drank it there was plenty of carbonation . smell : a toasted malty smell with an almost cardboard smell . taste : very strong toasted smell but more of a bitterness then a sweetness . note : no date on the bottle but wondering if this beer had gone bad . will try another attempt at it but not really looking forward to it .
overall the beer looks and smells fantastic . it falls way short on flavor and drinkibilty .  mouthfeel : light/ medium body with excessive carbonation that somewhat hinders the flavor .

s : a very rich banana/clove mix , just about perfect . no hops , no nothing .  the body is thin and slightly anemic . a little more carbonation and body would carry this really unique beer into the stratosphere .

smells really really good , actually . i suppose old men are always less handsome when they take their clothes off .  mouth- thin ? it 's a little thin , it lacks depth , and too much raisin for my taste .

the smell- incredible . at first , very sweet smelling- hints of pineapple . for such a strong beer , it finishes very abruptly , leaving you with just a tad of malt . overall , incredible .  very low carbonation , strong , hoppy with lingering after taste , a very typical english bitter but not my cup of tea .

a- pours a light amber with a quickly dissipating head s- wow , this smells incredible ! it smells like cinnamon , nutmeg , graham cracker , pumpkin , and brown sugar . d- it 's highly drinkable , however the alcohol is not as well-hidden as in some other st imperials .  lightly bodied , perhaps overly so , with a passably dextrinous mouthfeel .

this reminds me a bit of pte with that ridiculously great aroma and bitterness but not quite having the citric hop flavor that i would normally want in a dipa . this beer is incredibly bitter on the back end and the hot alcohol make this beer difficult to session .  the mouthfeel is the only thing i think could be improved here and it very well may just be that i am having it from a growler .
very nice . taste : malty and strong with coffee .  the palate is somewhat thin for the style but it 's still smooth .
a large beige head forms with great retention and lace .  mouthfeel was not particularly big , enough that you knew you were drinking something real but not a facefull .

perfect fruit scent . clean , pleasant , and wonderful . almost erotic , even - i want this beer to have my abortion .  the mouthfeel was about what i expected going in , but i thought it might a little over-carbonated . the aggressiveness of the carbonation was a little distracting .

pretty pleasantly sweet smelling brew . taste and mouthfeel : tasted of pumpkin , ginger , plenty of assorted spice , and plenty of very sweet brown sugar flavor in this as labeled .  it was bland and the stout portion was overpowering . yet , for reason 's i do n't understand , the people i know from philadelphia all seem to love this beer .

a - pours an orange copper color with a layer of fine bubbles on the surface s - lots of piney and citurs hops , lemon , orange , just a totally amazing aroma t - grapefruit & orange upfront , sweet malt & a slightly bitter hop finish , a really flavorful hopbomb m/d - medium body with good carbonation , just a really drinkable beer , somehow its 10 % which you really have no way of knowing  m : thin , but with a bit of sparkle .
the aromas is astonishing , this is the most coffee like of any coffee beers that i 've tasted . excellent .  body is fairly thin , but that is expected for the modest abv .

a- the pour yields an opaque black body with a small khaki colored head composed of tightly knit bubbles . the head is long lasting and leaves complete rings on the sides of my glass .  wow this has to be one of the worst ideas in beer history . trying to cross a pale ale with a belgian and what you got is something that is a distant cousin to both . instead of leveraging the style 's strengths this beer doubles down on their worst attributes . a very hoppy tatse that fights like a strong ale . not a fun beer and a true shame that it might discredit weyerbacher 's other great beers .

s : bold and healthy hop aroma . perfect ipa smell . t : dry and hoppy .  flavour is better than expected- a little woody and slightly spicy , with a thick strong maltiness . i 'd like the hearty body on this one , were it not for the turbocharged carbonation .

intresting , very intens smell , very nice hop aroma , tons of hops , citrus flavour , very similar to pliny the elder , i want to taste this one t : similar to the nose but not that strong , wheat , tons of hops , citrus , sweet malts , nice slightly bitter finish , this could be the little brother of pliny the elder , but this is softer , not so strong , m : very smooth , very well balanced , d : very drinkable , alcohol is well hidden , i could drink this all day long , yammy , well done struise .  feel is thin bodied overall , but well bodied for the style .

nose is quite complex with some really nice notes of oak , vanilla , chocolate , roasted malt , and some light coffee . the taste does n't mix these together quite as well , but is still tasty . great feel coming from all different directions and quite drinkable for the big beer that it is .  taste is weak but odd at the same time with a mild rice-sweetness . this is the kind of beer you can share with your friends because most do n't appreciate the imports anyway . i drank plenty of this is my younger days ... when you look up headache in the dictionary it reads `` drink 12 budweisers and take a nap .
deep brown pour with a gigantic , rocky , tan head .  the mouthfeel is light carbonation , somewhat on the watery side , but very drinkable .

the beer arrived on the table black with a huge brown frothy head that was 2 fingers tall and lasted forever to coat the glass .  i have had ipas that went down a bit smoother but this one is n't bad it still goes down good but with just a little more carbonation and bite .

pretty good aroma wafting from this especially when warm , distinguishable espresso and coffee grounds with baker 's chocolate , coarse grains and a earthy woody note , not unlike campfire smoke with the addition of some licorice . great aroma and feel , solid overall .  the mouthfeel however is slightly taut . body is clear red copper with sustained carbonation .

s : smell is exceptional . tons of chocolate and brown sugar . o : a great smelling beer that just has too much alcohol taste for my palate .  as with several anchor offerings , i feel the carbonation is a bit overdone , but is n't powerful enough to be overly distracting .
very complex but i am at a lose for words .  very carbonated feel on the tongue .

rings of lacing were left on the glass as the chugging commenced - nice ! the aroma was of a fruit forward chardonnay . citrus and floral scents were immediately detectable , along with a sweeter malt characteristic and alcohol .  m - a little thin for my liking . the body is quite thin , almost watery .

light beige head is 1/4 inch on the pour but recedes to a thin cap . big gobs of sticky lace are solid down the sides of the glass .  the feel is the only drawback here . it was rather light in body , and thin feeling . carbonation was adequate , but it just lacked that `` near medium '' that i would expect from a dipa .

s : perfumy nose ( muscat ? ) with grapes and chamomile flowers , pungent , with hints of honeysuckle . t : there is a belgian yeasty estery upfront which is nice . after that the grapes really come out , particularly the gewurztraminer which i 'm a fan of since i love alsatian whites . but anyways , it 's a fun beer to delve into , tasty for sure . a marriage of northern french wine and belgian beer , it makes perfect sense .  ) i would like a little more bready/chewiness as the mouthful feels a tad more thin than what i 'd prefer for this style .

pretty hop-forward , but the taste does n't quite live up the incredible nose . the citrusy-pine aroma is somewhat over-powered by a faintly peppery and slightly acidic bite . not bad , but the nose really had me expecting something special .  the mouthfeel , i was not so impressed with .
burnished cherry color , fairly translucent , with a good 2 cm of vanilla colored head resting atop .  mouthfeel if very alive and crisp at first sip . maybe a bit overpowering on the carbonation .
it smells nicer than it tastes , imo , but is still a nice porter !  m : average , nothing of note .

appearance 5/5 clear dark brown with a good dark tan colored head that stayed around , and left good lacing as well .  the largest macro beer in the country is very disappointing . the feel of this beer is somewhat thin but i liked the bock feel that it had .

aroma is wow coffee , rich robust , you want it , it 's here , with a nice dark malt sweetness underneath .  the beer feels light but not watery . there is a little prickle on the tongue at the swallow .

very ripe strawberries and a bit of peach . not complaining , though ... one of the best aromas i 've ever encountered .  somewhat smooth feel , moderate-medium body for amber , but still feels a little thin .

a : nice transparent firey oranges with pleanty of carbonation rushing from the bottom of the glass . s : the first whiff provided an array of tropical fruit notes like mango , peach , pineapple . very much t : sticky resinous pine and bitter grapefruit are the most prominent flavors with hints of citrus coming through in the end . it also has a nice clear herbal finish .  m : crisp feel at first , mellows gradually before eventually becoming a little sticky/gummy . light-medium body .

appearance : a deep carmelly red/brown with a big-ass foamy , frothy , sticky off-white head . a hurricane of fine carbonation is billowing up from the duvel `` d '' .  mouthfeel is a little lacking ; like i said , this bottle had very little to no carbonation , so i might need to try again . overall , though , a very tasty sweet high abv winter seasonal that i wo n't mind drinking again to `` research the carbonation .
a beautiful , reminiscent of the normal guinness cream top decks this dark copper colored beer . blanket lacing .  the mouthfeel was lowly carbonated .
complex and strong aroma of wild flowers , banana , orange and coriander .  mouthfeel : medium body and a finish that is a bit dry . this beer almost flat .
thick foamy off-white head with excellent retention and lacing .  m - the reason i dinged it on mouthfeel is because it actually left some of that nasty coffee-mouth feeling in my gullet .

this beer pours really dark , with a nice tight off white head . there is good lacing throughout .  lighter body than i thought it would be with with very low carbonation..the weakest point of the brew . easy drinker for the abv and ignoring the mouth feel , a nice brew .

the aroma is amazing ! sweet bourboney ( sp ? ) aroma , along with just the right amount of hops and a hefty malt sweetness . very good . all the flavors and aroma go together so well , and the low abv make this a very sessionable brew .  the mouthfeel is light with a decent amount of carbonation .

great retention and globby lacing .  brownish gold beer straight out of a 40 ounce bottle . sugary sweet flavors of corn and grain . it 's not something i 'll buy very often . milwaukee 's best 40s are cheaper and taste better , even if they do n't have that signature bottle shape .

sweetish and beautiful . t : unfortunately , the alcohol flavor jumps to the front , and while it 's not quite overwhelming , it 's a large part of the flavor , which i do n't find pleasant .  it is astringent and medicicnal .

earthy , weedy , hoppy , piney ! a real west coast ipa . love it ! not for the faint of heart hop haters , but awesome for hop lovers ! definitely interesting with tropical fruit hints in this one . mouthfeel : deliciously crisp and oily .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied to me . could be a little thicker on the tongue .
delectably hoppy smell . taste is not bad , but does n't live up to the smell . it tastes thinner than i 'd like .  m - a little on the thin side .

the smell is amazing , strong coffee aroma , more so than any other coffee stout i 've had , easily the best aspect of this stout . the taste is a bit more reserved with the coffee as it 's hard to beat the strong aroma , but there is a good deal of coffee and roasted malt , hint of chocolate , and a decent bitterness in the end .  nice floral hops and malt starchiness in the finish . it 's a drinkable beer . heavy in the stomach .

d : this looked and smelled great , but the flavor just was n't that enjoyable , and the body was only ok .  the only complaint i have is that the texture left much to be offered . overall i great beer .

sweet banana like smell with a bit of spice . i really like this beer , but it 's pretty heavy and very robust and powerful .  the taste was very light and highly carbonated . overall i 'm really surprised at all the negative reviews of this beer . maybe it 's just the fact i had it on tap , or that it was fresh .

s - big chocolate aroma up front . allspice , pumpkin , and other spices in the background . the brewer put 150 pounds of local pumpkin in this batch - very cool . m - well balanced . i would have liked the pumpkin to stick out a little more on this one .  mouthfeel is decent , this beer seems to foam up in your mouth .

wow ... the nose on this is excellent ! tons of roasted malts , coffee beans and dark chocolate . very nice ... the taste is n't quite as profound as the nose , but it holds up well . i am really glad i had the chance to try it ... after all , it has been on my wants list for some time .  the beer seems to thin a bit in the mouthfeel . very clean beer for a triple , slightly thin in the mouthfeel , but that helps give this beer a nice clean dry finish .

aroma is very pleasant and soft sweetish malt with mild floral hops , hints of pine , slight citrus , it is a wonderful combination , i spent some time just enjoying the aroma . taste is a bit harsh grassy and sligthly lemony hops ; unfortunately the taste is soon gone and just pleasant and rather long lasting bittery aftertaste remains .  the middle is kind of hoppy , but somewhat thin . the finish is dry and quite hoppy . a decent light beer .

a : huge three finger head , constant carbonation , brown oil color .  t - again , bicuit and nut . nice and malty , virtually no hop bite , but tasty none the less . d - i have had this a ton in the past , but i only just got around to getting another one for the purposes of reviewing .

apricot golden body , tiny hop flecks visible and a classic ivory creamy , spritzy cap . the nose is very aromatic like a freshly prepped bowl of ambrosia . lots of ripe citrus in the nose , specifically tangerine and ruby red grapefruit . the taste is crisp , hoppy and i could tell upon first drink the mouthfeel is superb . i 'll say it , it 's overrated a little .  a- blackness with a espresso colored head s- coffee beans ground soaked in licorice coffee and dark chocolate really bold t- straight up coffee and espresso with bitter chocolate and a slight tang finish m- medium carbonation and a bit watery for the style d- i drink 3 cup of coffee a day who am i to judge ?

aroma is overwhelming with citrusy peach essence of hop . so sweet and spicy , very cali . i usually sniff for 15-20 seconds but this beer merits much more nasal enjoyment .  body is perhaps the one less thanexcellent area , as its a little too light and i would have preferred something heavier and slicker ( more like the maui offering ) .

this does throw a great looking pour into my glass .  it may not be for everyone but i think this is a beautiful product . flavor is far less sweet than the smell and look might hint , in fact this is gobs of sour black cherry . it 's an instant classic and one of only a handful of lambics i 've liked so far .

advertised as a belgian-style golden ale , from looks and smell alone it starts out as good as any of the actual belgian pale ales have tried . this is still a wonderful brew for the smell and balance alone , but as a belgian pale ale is pretty much my favorite style in the summer months i 'm probably more critical than most with this style .  the mouth is a tiny bit like flat soda which was the only off-putting part of this beer .

nose is fantastic ! uniquely fruity , like a cranberry-mango chutney . hops are detectable and make this a complex sniffer , probably the best smelling tripel i have ever laid nostrils upon . fruit levels take on the best from belgium , impressive . very nice brew , might be my favorite that i have had so far from the bruery .  mouthfeel : the body is oddly thin , and crisp .

hazy yellow body with short white head beautiful voluptous peach aroma . very juicy . simple and juicy , no bitterness or sourness .  mouth feel was pretty average , smooth , not very complex so i expected a little more from it in that department .
very inviting . malt beginning just sorta slides on by without really putting down stakes .  m : the thinnest , lightest imperial i can remember , but the intensity doesnt have to be overpowering .
powerful hop aroma , lots of citrus . pleasant , but nothing to get too excited about .  more watery flavored than i expected from this ... very light mouthfeel .

s-really smells quite like a full bore ipa .  this is very malty at the opening with a twinge of caramel . upon downing it , the taste resembles a very dark beer . very malty with heavy caramel presence that makes it a bit sweet . it also gives a bitter character that mellows into a sweetened deal . i 'll have to try it from the mug in the near future . it may turn out differently due to more carbonization released , making it less bitter , dare i venture to say . but , straight from the bottle , it is easier to imbibe if you 're used to dark , bitter ales .

still , the beer does n't follow through on a great aroma .  taste was pretty balanced with a bit of malt sweetness . overall i liked this one . this is the first beer i have tried from boulder . based on this one , i 'll have to try some of the others that we can get in ct . the website says that a secret spice is added , but i can not really taste any spice . maybe i 'll figure it out by the time i finish the six . good brew .

appearance : pours a perfectly clear , deep yellow body with a tall , bubbling , white head . looks nice .  m : slick mouthfeel with a medium amount of carbonation that can be prickly at times . body is medium and has a bit of resiny stickiness to it .
