enormous thick and lasting beige head , colour is very dark brown , cloudy .  it feels very thin in the mouth , close to water .

a : beautiful beer ! it 's a perfectly clear light amber color topped by a big-bubble , thin but foamy head . lacing is alright , but the beer looks so good it makes up for that in other areas .  it has little to no head on it with a soft pour . this beer has a good balance of spices that is not overpowering . the aftertaste is mellow . this is one of the darker ales that i have drank but all in all i would give it another try . especially on a snowy winter day .

nose is great on this - grassy hops , estery yeast and sugary , bready rye . very nice , everything comes together extremely well . yeast seems more tripel than saison , but compared to the smell the yeast is quite tame unfortunately .  like chocolate carbonated corn syrup . body is light and watery ... good carbonation level helps it feel thicker than it is and hints at being creamy .

great chocolate smell as soon as the cap came off , smelled just like a candy bar .  the body was only medium , this was not unexpected as it is an ipa style , but i though it could have done with a bit extra .

pours a hazy amber/orange color with a small white to light yellow head , very bubbly . nose is amazing , fresh and fruity , mango , grapefruit , pine and sweet fruit juice . taste is much less fruity than the nose , but it 's still top notch , for a regular ipa it sure packs a hop punch , very bitter and palate tingling . a really nice addition to lawson 's hoppy line up !  the mouthfeel is medium , slightly watery .

this brew pours a very large head of creamy fine light brown bubbles and opaque black brown body .  incredibly light with cereal grains , very grainy taste , hops are nowhere in site . there are way better summer beers out there .

smell has vanilla everywhere , like i was punched in the face by the vanilla . i like it . as it warms , the bourbon , booze , and roasted malt come out . i wish it was a bit more complex , but the bourbon , vanilla , and booze just take over .  m : a touch thin .

s : boozey up front , with some vanilla and whiskey barrel charateristics , followed immediately by caramel and white grape juice and an interesting hops profile , which is mostly citric , somewhat resiny , and with a deep earthiness to it . t : sweet and everything you 'd expect from the smell , except for a noticeable sticky molasses cigar linger . this is malt heavy , but well balanced with hops that are n't overly bitter . it 's nice , maybe a little too sweet with a dry malt extract coating on the mouth , but nice .  md-light body and sharp moderate carbonation . foamed pretty good going down the drain .

an immense hop punch to the nose . extremely fresh , bitter hops practically leap out of the glass . further in i get notes of orange and citrus , wrapped into a pleasing sweet malty undercurrent . superb nose . t. alas , after such a superlative smell , how could the taste hold up ? it 's a fantastic smelling , `` lite '' double ipa that is easy to put down .  ) it has very low carbonation witch makes the mouthfell very average with about that of a tap bud lite , only a little tingle from the carbonation .

a - dark as night with amber hue creeping in with the light . thick head that lasts the entire time drinking it slowly and leaving very nice lacing .  the mouthfeel is just a touch too syrupy , though it does n't detract much at all from the enjoyment of the beer .

aroma is a big mix of roasted grain , alcohol , malt sweetness , slightly burnt toast , coffee , chocolate , raisin , and cigar tobacco . unfortunately this did n't taste as good as it smelled . my expectations were raised by the aroma and then i felt a little left down as i did n't get the same complexity on my tongue .  smell was sweet , with a citrus hint and strong english ale smell . initial taste was interesting , and i was n't sure about whether i would like it . by the end of the bottle , it had become one of the best beers i 've tasted . i would n't recommend it for any parties , but in small groups of like minded people i would say good call . very drinkable beer . looking forward to trying more from the brewery ( if i can find it )

roasty bittersweet belgian chocolate . all low notes , tiny musty . surprising spiciness accompanies the stout yet without much depth .  taste is dominating by anis with some candi sugar . body was above average and alcohol was well hidden .

i enjoyed this stout as it warmed up to room temperature . this is as black as you can get which is expected for a stout .  the beer is somewhat oxidized , but still highly drinkable very light bodied bitter , true to the the style . this is a prime candidate for a session beer . at 3.8 % abv , it 's alcohol content makes this a clear choice for something that could literally be consumed all day long , starting with your pancakes !

( s ) - very aromatic . very dynamic & layered . again , a good taste that followed suit to the smell . great aroma . lends itself more to a better drinkability score due to a lower abv than alot of strong ales out there ; thicker than most too , but it fits it well . this might benefit from further aging , but its great now .  nothing special here .
a - beautiful beautiful golden orangish yellow color with fine and soapy bubbles . retention and lacing is excellent .  medium-bodied , maybe just a little bit thin .

i was incredibly excited to get a can of this stuff in my recent trade with tripelhops from what ive heard , its basically a can of hops . s : damn juicy in the nose : big grapefruit hops and creamy , fruity malts . love it . t : good candy sweets and light , drinkable hop-bitters on the front of the tongue ; herbal and a bit funky , even . good , balanced flavor . o : very drinkable a great ipa for the can .  mouthful : somewhat over-carbonated but generally decent mouthfeel .

unique and quite nice aroma . taste is medium sweet upfront mixed w/medium hop bitterness .  drinks a little heavy because of all the sediment but feels watery and thin on the palate . adequate carbonation but not incredible lively .

12 oz bottle poured into an '08 osa pint appearance- pours a deep brown with a large dense tan head , sticks around forever . incredible head retention and lacing .  boosting the carbonation would help .

batch 265 a - pitch black body with a huge amount of coffee head that is frothy and sticks around s - chocolate cherries with some sour and funk laying around t - just like the nose .  very light bodied , but carbonation seems too low to me .

and lists it as a strong pale ale aroma : grapefruit flowers on a sugary base . mouthfeel : medium body , a bit oily overall impression : nice and easy , a bit boring maybe , but thats more about me than the beer .  m - a little thin , sickly-sweet finish .

i gave it a good rating for smell just because it 's so damn unique . taste is sweet malts , some hops and a bitter finish .  mouthfeel : pretty heavy for a porter but very drinkable even in the heat .

aroma starts off with some vanilla and slight chocolate , but really comes to live as the brew warms . banana 's , plums , lots of malty goodness . taste is caramel , dried fruit some alcohol as she warms . definately worthy of the hype .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin , spicy , moderately dry , and has a distinct saison flavor in the aftertaste .

that 's what i get in the nose . fresh hot bowl of oatmeal delivered fresh to your nose with dallop of caramelized brown sugar and a heaping of fresh raspberries . a deep burgundy/purple color , it almost looks like a shiraz . i love the complexity and uniquness of this beer , but it tastes too much like a wine cooler for me to love . i just ca n't handle all of the fruit .  smooth and to the point , bit of a sweet aftertaste in the sweet sticky beer way .
nice downward bubbles on pour ... dark brown to black with a slight ruby edge , a tan creamy nitro head , and lace like wallpaper .  mouthfeel - a little gritty , though a light body to it .

this smelled like freshly ground coffee , chocolate , muffins , brownies , and finished with a roasted woodsy character . wow . i want to dip my whole face in this beer .  mouthfeel : a little slick , thinner on the palate than i expected drinkability : a fine porter , would definitely drink again .

heavily hopped with three different american hop varieties , the hop aroma and flavor are citrus-like and pungent . very strong hop aroma - primarily cascade hops , so this e.s.b . 's aroma reminds me of a dry-hopped pale ale in the pacific northwest style . overall , a satisfying ale - not exactly true to its style , but very good nonetheless .  m : medium to light bodied . feels a touch watery .

s- excellent . wheat , yeast , and citrus immediately hit the nostrils as you pour this one . t- initial taste of sweet malt and citrus .  mouthfeel : medium body , a bit chalky , tingly carbonation and a dry finish .

the nose is deep , thick , prodigious coffee and some raisiny dark chocolate notes , and roasted dark sweet grains .  m - medium body , with moderate to high carbonation . a bit too carbonated for my liking . slightly thin , would like a bigger body from a stout . the mouthfeel is lacking , and sweet flavors of vanilla and chocolate make it too much like a dessert beer , one is all you need .
aroma , port , sherry . it 's sweet but very inviting . sherry quality very present in the taste .  mouthfeel is a bit thin and resinous , this is really the only fault i can find .
pours a rich , opaque sable with a nice thick tan head .  for the mouthfeel , i found this stout almost watery in consistency .

aroma is funky and enticing ! smells like a farmhouse ale of the jolly pumpkin style . i 'm disappointed ; freetail can do much better .  m : full bodied and creamy , the slightest touch of carbonation and a smooth , somewhat watery finish .
it is very nice however .  do not know if this was an aberation , but this caused a lower score in mouthfeel .

very nice nose . sipping is quite sweet . however , this was much more than i was expecting ; very nice .  i 've always liked this beer , and if they beefed up the abv and gave it a little more body , it would be the perfect porter . why grant 's beers share these characteristics i do n't know , but if they ever did beef 'em up a little , they could truly be a contender .
smell is pretty dang good . smells like cherries and more cherries .  mouthfeel is rather thin and average .

smell is a tart , floral aroma with crisp , clean edge ; simply put , it 's delightful . this ale 's taste is a crafty hop blen dover a clean , crisp start .  seems a bit thin , with very soft carbonation .
s- banana aromas dominate with subuded peppery yeast notes .  m : thinner than i expected , pretty fair amount of carbonation , once again a little more reminiscent of a porter than a stout .

aroma packs an immediate bourbon punch and is balanced by rich vanilla and milk chocolate . molasses , raisins , brown sugar and caramel with very little roast , burnt or hop aromas . non-existent alcohol and the sweetness is very pleasant and smooth . flavor is similarly smooth and balanced with surprisingly more of a milk chocolate , vanilla and molasses presence than in the nose . bourbon is still present , particularly in the finish , but never harsh . warming throughout , yet the balance between the barrel and base beer is remarkable . mouthfeel is slightly thinner than hoped for , medium thick with light carbonation ; slightly milky in character . i do n't feel like this detracts from my enjoyment of the beer , but for the style would have expected something a little more robust .  body is a little thin .

very heavy hefe pour . thick , deep yellow gold that glubglubs out of the bottle and leaves a giant head .  it was pretty smooth for stout and for for the alcohol content . i tried it with a few other beers .

a - this looks darker than some stouts i 've drank . great looking head .  trying to think of a sweet red wine , not one i can place , but its defintely tannic , bitter and sweet ... the taste is super interesting , not say its good , but interesting . chocolate wine comes to mine , light feel though . what i do know is that 8 months is too long as it totally changes the beer into something new losing almost all stout character .

the aromas of a black pepper-like spicy hop and light earthy grain blend together to make the mouth water .  its a bit thicker on the palate than american crap beer , but it 's your basic `` serve cold , swill it down , catch a buzz '' beer for the masses .

this brew has a delicious smell of peanut brittle and roasted malts .  again , dried dark fruit seems to be the dominating taste , and as it warms , a sweet cherry-like flavor comes in m : at first i found this beer a bit too prickly and highly carbonated for my liking ; i purposely agitated the beer by swirling and enjoyed it a bit more when carbonation was less severe great beer that i would drink anytime i needed a belgian fix .

a : pours a deep , hazy plum body that resides beneath a three-finger head of creamy pinkish-tan foam ; good retention and tons of lace . probably the best-looking barleywine i 've seen . beautiful .  m - a little thin-bodied and watery and a little low on the carbonation .
pours deep red , with some f*ing amazing head on it .  m - the hops lingered a bit too long and had a metallic feel at times .
the smell is exceptional . it smells like candy the mouthfeel is really smooth , and not very thick .  mouthfeel is a little too tingly for me with the carbonation .

aroma packs in big notes of freshly-brewed dark coffee . nutty caramel notes and an earthy hop presence are in the mix as well . surprisingly , this beer did not overwhelm me with coffee , but despite the excellent balance the nose is still dominated by the bean . overall , i was expecting a bit more from this highly-touted coffee stout .  it was an average imperial stout with a thin mouthfeel made exciting with some fruit .

a-pours a cloudy orange ... i 'm docking points because pilsner 's should have good clarity ... also excessive head ... s-outstanding aroma ... spicy , floral and somewhat fruity ... very inviting and the type of beer you could sit and smell all day long . but i found it an exciting , and tasting brew ... .one of the best smelling beers i have ever experienced .  a bit thin , but a very good stout flavor develops in the mouth . i 'd have preferred a bit fuller body .

the appearance was a perfect deep color with a incredible head .  m - fairly zesty and zingy carbonation that left me feeling a touch bloated after a third of a glass . medium-light body that also has a bit of grain character .
light amber beer was topped by a thick head that left some of the thickest lacing i have seen in my career .  the mouthfeel is a little lacking in carbonation too .

pours an intense orange/cherry with a full finger of fluffy off-white head .  like drinking sour grass , probably the best way to put it m - low carbonation , slightly astringent d - not very drinakble , i had to leave a third of it
overly sweet at times , but still nice . if it was n't for the mild astringent smell i 'd give it a 5 .  mouthfeel is not too bad , sharpness coming more from the carbonation than hops .

i 'm picking up in floral and citrus . hops linger in the mouth for a couple minutes and slowly fade into a nice , mellow finish .  out of all of the blueberry beers i have had i would have to say this is probably my favorite . very fruity with a somewhat dry finish to it . the blueberries are definitely the star of the show . overall this is a very drinkable beer and makes a great summer brew .
appearance : pour is dark chocolate with brown edges . perfect two-finger tan head .  mouthfeel was medium with a bite in front and back and made the roof of my mouth tickle ( odd ) .

s : super hoppy . i love it . t : i 'm having trouble believing this is a barleywine . i know american bws are supposed to be hoppy but hot damn is this awesome . destroys your palate with an intense amount of hops .  i can feel it in my cheeks . it does n't have any off aromas specifically , but it definitely has the acidity for it . undrinkable , i 'm pouring it out .

aromas of tart cherries right off the bat mixed with nicely roasted malts and a woody bourbon aroma as well . i really enjoy the tart cherry integration .  m : carbonation is a little weak ( especially since i poured moderately , and received an aggressive head ) leaving a mouthfeel thatis not strong enough for me to consider it cask-like . a little watery ... d : all things considered , i really enjoyed this beer .
it is good , but one at a time .  the mouthfeel is larger light with a very , very slight fizz .
the hop aroma was very good , while the malts were only so-so .  the mouthfeel was medium bodied with adequate carbonation .

the aroma was simply outstanding . i have tried a number of the best coffee beers but none even came close to the nose on this one . pure and simple . every time i smelled this , i imagined myself walking into a coffee shop . the flavor profile was not quite as coffee heavy as the nose , but it was indeed more complex . malty rich up front .  it goes down smooth .

smells like sweet cinnamon at first , followed by strong aroma of nutmeg that dominates any other existing aromas .  best as it warmed , when the malt flavors of chocolale and toffee become a bit more complex and the mouthfeel seems fuller .
the appearance is red brick with a light tan head and supreme lacing .  the only fault is that its a little thin bodied but that 's what makes this brew dangerous .

smell : this one is all about that distinctive fruity grape note ( thinks welsh 's grape jelly filled grape bubblegum ) in the beginning that then gets washed over by a classic cantillon urine and yeast wave . truly unique and highly enjoyable . taste : same as the nose but more integrated and not as grape dominant as the nose .  this beer poured nicely with a creamy white head , giving off nice citrus aromas . the flavor was shocking , however , reminding me of kool-aid orange flavor , and with almost as much sweetness . i could n't distinguish any hop bitterness , though it could have used some to balance out the excessive sweetness . this beer tastes as though all the yeast were filtered out , and then orange kool-aid added post-fermentation
this smelled like the kitchen while my mom bakes banana bread .  m - moderate carbonation , medium bodied .
this beer looks very impressive .  the mouthfeel was medium with a syrupy sweetness on the palate .

poured into a pint glass ... appearance-maybe the best head i 've ever since on a hefeweizen . considering many hefeweizens bodys look similar this is getting a 5 . frothy 3 finger head that i 'm enjoying just sit there and watching the bubbles slowly pop .  medium bodied , it seems a little flat at the beginning , but there 's sharp carbonation at the finish , which is a little watery and silty .

beautiful golden bronze colour . head retention is superb , an easy 4 fingers . these certainly do have a tendency to 'explode ' upon uncapping , with foam exiting the bottle for several minutes afterwards .  mouthfeel is pretty typical , and if anything is a little undercarbonated or slick .

one of the nicest smelling dipas ( imperial pale ? ) i 've experienced t : initially starts out with lots of bitterness from the hops .  the expected lactose or creaminess is absent in the flavor as well as the mouth feel given that this is a milk stout . the carbonation , again , is more soda-like in the mouth instead of frothy or creamy . the drinkability and mouthfeel improved with time as the intensely carbonated head withered away .

absolutely amazing grapefruit , lemon , and orange aroma . also has a touch of sweet toffee and vanilla . this was a beautiful hazy golden pour , with typical cask frothy head . very well balanced flavor , then a wonderful dry bitter finish . this is an amazing brew , and the cask only adds to it .  the mouthfeel is a bit too light for my liking .

s- strong cherry and rasberry charachter . a pretty strong tartness is every step of the way as well t- very strong tart charachter , not as sour as i was thinking , nicely fruity at the start but it stays too sweet at the finish which is a little off-putting , however some of my friends realy liked it .  pretty average mouthfeel overall .
the smell was delightful . sadly , it ended there .  the body was light and there was not enough carbonation .

by far the best smelling pumpkin beer i 've had , and one of the best i 've had , period , in a long time . t- not quite as good as the smell , but still pretty good . cinnamon , nutmeg , pumpkin , orange creamsickle , and alcohol .  long , super bitter piney bitterness , aftertaste almost of pine-sol but i love the hop attack . problem is that it 's too sweet and slightly syrupy , especially evident in the middle . a little harsh and unbalanced overall , big beer and it shows .

the aroma on this beer is perfect . absolutely no off smells and wonderfully balanced . as one would expect in an imperial , it has the requisite dark and roasted malt smells , but delightful hints of chocolate and raisins add to the aromatic complexity .  in the glass , the elderberry dominates . the taste just off , sour in a nasty way , more like rotten fruit than any sort of pleasant tartness which might be expected from the berries . we gave this a decent try to see if it would get better , but in the end just could n't drink it .

super sweet citrus tingle with a fresh evergreen aroma . a fitting caramel malt finds its way in the nose as well . wonderful exotic hop scents all the way through with this one . scary good drinkability for the style .  mouthfeel - a bit too carbonated which overrides the wonderful taste at first .
poured a malted milk , inch thick head . firm and abundant lacing .  4.5/5 m : crisp , medium body .

brown bottle , there 's a spot for a bottling number on the back label but it 's blank , poured into a pilsner glass . appearance : pours a crystal clear golden yellow , lots of carbonation bubbles rising inside . probably a good one to bring to a party , as it looks similar to the macros , but tastes much better .  picked up a few of these `` oil cans '' at a local liquor mart . this is the only place i 've seen them . i like the regular fosters occasionally , and have fond memories of it from various parties and times in life . after looking at the color , noticed that the can said `` caramel coloring added , '' so nothing real to go by there . i liked this , i guess , but the drinkablility was hampered by a fakey sort of bitterness that did n't hold a candle to the fuller 's and young 's of the world . kind of caught in my throat . i pick up the regular if it 's on special , but for a real bitter , this ai n't it .

wow , one of the best smelling old ales i 've ever smelled . as it warms up so many different smells come out , yet it stays balanced . i thought this beer smelled amazing and was very complex and balanced . while the taste was a step down and a tiny disappointment after the smell , it was still very good . i thought it also had an amazing mouthfeel and while definitely a sipper , the abv is well hidden .  m - lots of carbonation maybe bordering on too much .

pours a deep , rich plummy color topped by a lively head of sloppy , sticky looking foam . this has a very healthy head that sticks around and laces majestically .  mouthfeel : medium and semi-smooth . bottom line : this is one of the most bland beers i 've ever had .
appearance ; beautiful black color with an attractive tan head .  the palate is thinner than expected but not bad .

s - oh shit . dark chocolate , charcoal , campfire , wet ash , cigar smoke , dark chocolate coated coffee beans , birch bark , cigarettes , and a vague hint of sweet count chocula marshmallow cereal . ridiculous ! cigar smoke , woody campfires , wet firewood outside of an old cabin , gentle hints of sushi with soy sauce , and `` musty ( but pleasant ) old house '' notes if that makes any sense .  s- smoky wood and scotch , one of the more interesting noses on this beer t- malts , with some nice roasted flavors that come through and then a hit of alcohol m- lighter bodied than expected d- a very interesting and drinkable beer , but one i need to be in the mood for

smells amazing . the pine and citra form a wave of hoppy goodness .  an amazing brew . medium strength carbonation with a wonderful complex flavor of hops barley and corn . somewhat similar to pbr , but upper canada has an after taste that pbt ca n't compare with . usually i do n't care for beers to have much of an after taste , but with this brew it 's all good . i would recommend this beer to anyone who can get their hand on it .

the smell is really where this beer shined - a rich aroma of nicely roasted barley - coffee and chocolate predominated as well as a milky lactose aroma . this beer fell flat on the taste ( or maybe that 's just in comparison to the nose ) - it started off sweet , but never really delivered on all the flavors i had smelled . still , kudos for the nose . i probably wo n't be purchasing this again .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied with low carbonation and is a bit watery .

a- poured a dark black , with a nice head that faded quickly . the head was chocolate brown in color that had minimal lacing . i was very excited to taste based on looks .  it was creamy with an average carbonation level and also average alcoholic strength ( 6.0 % abv ) . overall : awful .

s - easily the beer 's most remarkable feature . wonderful aroma of blackberries and blueberries with a slightly sourish tint . t - although it does n't quite live up to the aroma in terms of complexity , this is still quite good . early palate some sour dark fruits are balanced out by a moderate caramel flavor .  mouthfeel is a bit too thin , especially in view of the heavenly head and ample lacing .

smell is strong and at first of piney , grassy , spicey hops with some citrus not all that different from an ipa . some caramellly and toffee smelling malt and a bit of booze hits the nose as well to differentiate it . taste at first is boozy . it is supported by the hops , but they are n't nearly as dominant as in the aroma . plenty of malt sweetness is there , but some fruit flavors appear as well . overall a very good beer , but it falls a bit below the expectations set by the aroma .  mouthfeel is a bit thin for my liking .

pours golden orange with a thick white head , impressive retention , good lace .  sweet caramel and an herbal bitterness m- clean , but a bit watery with mediocre carbonation d- i do like to drink this beer every now and then .

luckily , the aroma of this beer is quite good . a butterscotch maltiness was immediately noticeable and complemented perfectly with floral and spicy hop notes .  m - not as thick as i 'd like it to taste considering how rich the smell is . d - very drinkable , with the lighter mouthfeel it 's easier to forget how much you 've had .

i could see chunks floating in the glass and swirls forming as well . to me , the look was almost like blood . it looked really neat with the light of the fire bouncing of off the glass .  the only downside of this beer was the mouthfeel , which was fairly flat and watery , probably due in part to the low % abv .
s - good smell , lots going on .  m : light to medium bodied and highly carbonated .
nutty aroma with lots of caramel , hay and oats seem to scream out at me .  m. a little too sticky , it feels syrupy , but without a sweeter taste it fells a little off .

aromas were the strong point for this drink . deep blackberry aromas mixed with bready , wheaty textures . although nice and light for a summery day , its strong blackberry taste ( albeit weaker in comparison to the blackberry smell ) did not really make this too refreshing or crisp .  very basic but very good m= average carbonation and average weight .
the look is awesome : clear golden color with a great head and excellent lace .  m : finish stays around for quite a while , almost too long , really coats the mouth .

very nice presentation . aroma is forresty ( real word ? ) with grassy , herbal , piney , sprucy hop notes along with citrus notes of grapefruit and lemon rind .  m : mouthfeel is a bit thin , considering how robust the initial flavor is .

a : beautiful deep dark red , with a foamy , rich head s : unbelievably fragrant of cherries t : this is a sweet cherry beer . yummy .  if you closed your eyes and smelled this you would think your smelling a good octoberfest beer due to the scent of carmalized malt and faint hops . has a carmel toasted nut flavor on the tounge and finished dry . i like the fact that this irish red is a little more bitter than most red ales but still not overpowering . tongiht i will be reviewing 4 of hook and ladder beers as i bought a gift pack that came with 3 bottles of 4 different beers . the beers i got were backdraft brown golden ale pipe and drum irish red ember amber ( a type of black and tan made with their backdraft brown ale and golden ale ) . try these beers if u can find them they are good

very enjoyable smell , roasted coffee , chocolate , combined with a truffle like fruitiness . the alcoholic notes get more and more present , and totally unbalanced .  definitely a little too carbonated for my taste - the mouthfeel was a little too creamy , masking the flavor .

smell : citrusy , with hints of spices , very powerful if you can wait a minute or so before you drink it .  smell is cocoa , touch of coffee , licorice , slight vanilla , a whiff of smoke . taste is thick creamy , dark and bakers chocolate , touch of espresso , end is dry and slightly bitter , a woody aftertaste .

phenomenal appearance - golden with just a little haze and a large , lacey , and well-retained white head .  m- the weakness of the beer - moderately light body feels a little weak to me . light carbonation does n't add much .

poured a deep , uber cloudy orangish color with good carbonation leaving a nice white cap s : loads of faded hops , fruits..apricot and others with booze t : big faded hops powered by fruitiness and booze .  body was medium with med/high carbonation and a dry finish .
very nice . the taste is quite good , mostly dominated by malts .  mouthfeel : i 'm a bit disappointed by the mouthfeel .

250 ml bottle from supermarket in nice pours amber/golden with large and soft head with excellent retention as the head lasts till the end of the glass , patchy lacing .  mouthfeel , i would like it have been a bit more carbonated , but it did fine .

appearance : almost perfect . it 's black ( or nearly black ) with a delicious looking head that coats the sides of the glass with its frothy goodness .  magic hat usually disappoints me , not that their brews are n't good , it 's that some of them just are n't tasty- till now . magic hats roxy rolles is right up there with ithaca 's cascazilla and troegs hopback amber . a definite seasonal must have for me . great ! ! !

pumpkin pie spice is felt throughout and makes it absolutely wonderful . absolutely amazing . going into this , i knew that southern tier made some great beers . i had no idea this would be one of their best !  under carbonated .

s- great smell like a realy fruity white wine , dark raspberries , some of the cereal grains come through , no hop aroma . it doesn ; t over power though .  this one is a bit light and watery but does have a decent taste .

just great . dark berries with a light mouthfeel . it lacks a bit more flavor that i like in stouts but it 's still really excellent with the smell being the best part .  the mouthfeel is a bit overcarbonated for the stle but not bad .

12 oz bottle cloudy , dull golden amber color with a massive , creamy light brown/off white head . very dense and foamy , the head hangs around forever and leaves a lot of lacing .  this is the least impressive quad from the trappist breweries ... do n't get me wrong , it has a similar taste profile , although not that perfect as a westy 12 or a rochefort 10 , dark fruit , plums , candy sugar , but i did n't like the mouthfeel on this one . too much sparkling going on ... pretty funny thing is i just absolutely endlessly adore the la trappe quadrupel oak aged batch 1 version ... so so so much better then the regular one , especially when the oak aged version , bottled this summer , is coming around fantastic ! i like their dubbel more too .

big aroma for such a little head ; bright fruits , dried fruits , plum , cherry , red grapes , slight caramel and a smooth yeasty character . fruity malt character also displays some earthy , hearty grain notes and much of the same fruits as in the nose . nice medium yeasty twang marries well with the fruit notes .  it smells of rotten banana peels , rotten apples , and molding compost . the flavors are very sweet and kind of medicinal . it leaves a clove laiden aftertaste behind , making you think you just had an artificial banana milkshake . i just do n't understand what two brothers was going for on this one .
pours a nice dark black color , with a huge , chunky , creamy tan colored head , great retention .  m - somewhat lacking in mouthfeel .

s- this beer smells great , typical ipa smells ; pine mandarin , pineapple , grapefruit .  nothing to write home about when it comes to mouthfeel . kind of a club-soda feel to the beer , tingly . though there seems to be a strange `` romanian roulette '' effect where every sixth beer is kinda soapy .

the appearance is nice and perfect to style : pale orange in color and crystal clear .  i can see why the word peat was used before in a review the mouthfeel was medium to light i will agree it needs some more body to it this is a good brew and with a little tweaking it could become world class .

s - smell is phenomenal . right after you uncap it you 're hit with cinnamon and nutmeg and plenty of pumpkin .  shockingly light carbonation feel . i think the mouthfeel is off from what it should be .
really nice . t - red wine grapes , cherries and leather stand out to me , as does the vanilla and wood from the barrels .  i feel that it felt a little light on the tongue after it went down .

4.5 s : dry hopping has done wonders . tons of mango . after that comes pineapple , grapefruit , and orange . balancing maltiness with caramel and breadiness from the yeast . 3.5 d : decent , but nothing special .  the mouthfeel is a little on the thin and watery side though .

color was a little hard to see as it was fairly dark in the bar but appeared to be a very deep red , that while really dark was no opaque . slightly off-white head that left excellent lacing on the glass . not sure if it was the branded oversized wine glass or what but this was probably the second best looking beer i 've ever seen .  come and drink this corn syrup !

appearance : this brew pours with a wonderfully thick head . lacings are plentiful and surface spiderwebbing is consistant and lasting . color is indeed a reddish amber . excellent first impression .  cake/nutty malt up front with a huge , thick spiced tea hop flavor headbutt with the swallow . not just season 's best , but saranac 's best . i usually find them to be just an average brewery but this stuff is nice .
pours a light tan , two-finger head , fades slowly and leaves a good lace . nice clear , deep amber color .  m - decent body with a bit more carbonation than i 'd like from this style .
the smell was everything you would expect from a beer as hoppy as this . the smell of hop oil was big .  mouthfeel : hoppy and rough , but a bit fuzzy .

s : this is seriously the best part of the beer . the smell is a pronounced chorus of woodiness , vanilla , chocolate , and booze . is this nirvana ? t : starts out with a creamy chocolate taste which is followed by a sharp stab of flavor and alcohol burn on the tongue . d : overall a very impressive beer .  malty and corny .

comes out of the tap looking brown and alive . absolutely perfect lacing . one of the best looking beers i 've ever had the pleasure of admiring .  m -- slightly too watery , does n't really coat the mouth like i would hope but it washes down clean with no bad lingering tastes d -- this is it here , i think this is the beer i would use to introduce someone new to ipa 's .

a great effort from smutty ; this bp pours a saturated opaque espresso brown , leaving a rich dark bronzed brown head . very well bittered and rounded in the mouth with sweet roasted malts , carob and tongue tingling acids .  this is a very good pumpkin beer . picked a 6 pack up at the local market , came home on a chilly night here in rural mi , and my girlfriend and i finished the whole six pack . lots of pumpkin taste , beautiful color , and an overall great seasonal choice . i would n't drink it in warm weather , but on this cool fall night , it hit the spot . i could see picking this up in the future to bring to a bon fire , or to enjoy while i hand out candy on halloween . cheers !
this is , to date , the finest smelling pilsner i 've had .  mouthfeel : tingly and not quite substantial enough . seems to be the only point where this beer loses some ground .

decent lacing left behind . s - wow , great aroma here . immediately there is a lot of pineapple and coconut aroma making it clear that this has been barrel aged . lots of stuff going on here .  the taste is also fresh but a with bit of watery mouthfeel .

may be the blackest black i have ever seen .  m-its a little undercarbonated but the balance of the sweetness with the malt and subtle hops make for a relitivly complex october beer . d-easy to drink and very nice to have this time of year , easy to session .
poured a nice orange/golden color with a very large bubbly head which remained for a long time and left average lacing . an excellent looking beer .  mouthfeel was my only complaint .

5.0 s : wow ! this is n't the strongest smelling dipa i 've had ( it 's up there ) , but it is the most harmonious mixture of citrus i 've ever experienced . pineapple and mango are the most intense , followed by orange , tangerine , and grapefruit . 3.5 t : the taste is a bit disappointing after the nose . 3.0 m : lighter medium body , but it strangely lays heavy on the tongue . 3.5 d : pretty good , but one of the reason i really like dipas are for the awesome creamy mouthfeels .  perhaps a little watery , fuzzy . quite drinkable but somewhat sweet .

s : i absolutely love the smell of this brew . citrus hop notes . toasted malts . a lingering sweetness . d : good with appetizers , something vinegar-based ( maybe fries ... ) . extra stats from the botm newsletter : serving temp : 45-50 d f ibu : 26 abv : 5.4 % malts : pale , caramel hops : apollo , willamette  its sucks to know that in a different format this could be so much more . body and carb is okay , but by this point i 'm already at the meh stage .

on-tap at the clark street ale house . awesome yeast funk and they really nailed the look .  flavor is very light malt with a slightly sour pucker at the end . finishes clean with minimal bitterness . overall , this is a very good summer beer . it 's light , refreshing and mild , so it 's a good intro beer for those that are n't into intense beers . however , it has enough of a belgian twist to keep more advanced beer drinkers interested . versatile enough to enjoy one with a meal or multiple at the lake or playing cornhole .

the aroma is strong thick sweet and syrupy . including pine , alcohol , vanilla and oak . overall it 's very nice , i 'd like to see how it would do with another year or two to tame the hops down .  light carbonation and light-medium bodied . starts as sour apples becomes more sour like lemon juice , dry finish ; easily the least enjoyed belgian i have had . 750ml bottle - gift from vintage cellars blacksburg , va .

it smelled of fresh lemon zest and pine and as it warmed i got notes of warm brown sugar , like fresh cookies which was most likely a result of the honey used in the brewing . the beer tasted very good , bitter but also smooth however the mouthfeel got a bit harsh nearing the end with the ethanol burn .  i thought the mouthfeel was a touch watery but the whole packaged seem very much an alluring strong-lawnmower , early evening session beer .

s : smell on this beer is amazing . i gave this beer a 5 . the beer smells like a cream stuffed pumpkin . d : drinkable for the style but still 1 bomb is good for me .  mf : relatively light body with medium to high carbonation . would like a little more body , but the flavor more than makes up for it .

dark fruits and double fudge with a wisp of grass ... .nice ; profile is a bit of a letdown from the aroma . a very good approximation of a london stout although a tad thin for an oatmeal stout , it is very decent .  mouthfeel lots of fizzy carbonation , lighter bodied , finishes dry . the high carbonation combined with a thinner than usual mouthfeel really did throw off the beer making the flavors less prominent than i feel they could have been had the aforementioned two things been toned down a bit .

it smells amazing -- a sharp alcohol bite ( it 's a 21 abv , for crying out loud ) but surrounded with sweet citrus and pine and caramel and hops .  an american classic . good fall back beer , or one to enjoy when a less complex brew is desired .
just about perfect for a true winter beer .  mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium to high carbonation .

aroma was intensely hoppy yet smooth and balanced . piney and floral hops , citrus and fruity esters came through strong along with a touch of candy-like sweetness . cascade hops and hop oils soon became bitter and biting and left a noticeable film on my tongue . unquestionably , this was the most bitter and unbalanced ipa i have had to date .  spicy and yeasty on the finish , this beer is medium-light on the palate with a high level of carbonation , much higher than i care for , really foaming up in my mouth .

amazingly strong - smells of syrupy semi-sweet chocolate and very deep roasty and toasty malts ; smells like very fresh brewed espresso ... actually , the `` freshness '' of the smell is really quite intense . taste : very burnt and roasty malt characteristics that are reminiscent of fresh brewed espresso and grounds ; faint flavors of semi-sweet baking chocolate ; i have to admit , this would be an amazing morning drink .  m : the body is medium and so is the carbonation .

a nice balanced nose with caramel malts , floral hops and a nice dose of sweetness coming from tropical fruits . the fruitiness keeps reminding me of pink bubblegum .  mouthfeel : thin body and medium carbonation overall : a nice geuze , a bit too watery for my liking though .
that creamy two finger nitro head looks damn sexy .  m - exceedingly bitter . needs to be a little creamier for this style d - not a session beer .

i 'm a huge fan of strong , hoppy pilsners , and this is just great . tons of fresh grassy floral hops , a touch of pale malt . definitely enjoyable , regardless .  mouth feel is sharp and crisp , with a high carbonation level .

smell : funky dog , tart , lemon , peach . mouthfeel : medium body and medium-high carbonation overall : nice to try , but unbalanced .  i think i 'm a bit parial to this beer for 2 reasons . it 's not by any means a `` specialty '' beer , it 's your typical lager and since it 's been around since before any of us were born it 's got a nostalgic feel . excellent beer in my books , average for most .

the smell is very rich in aromas . i detect very strong honey notes , like wild honeysuckle . the taste is actually not as exciting as the smell , but still delivers a great complexity .  t- roasty , sweet malts , coffee and dark chocolate m- starts off nice and creamy and full , then towards the middle loses a bit of it 's body and seems to get watery , only to return with a solid finish .

poured into a new belgium snifter a - a beautiful clear dusk sunset color , 2 finger head that lingered and lacing through and through and awesome tiny bubbles for days s - pine , citrus , malt , floral , cotton , sweet , grains and maybe a bit toasty t - very nice bitter sweet , pine , orange , melon , pineapple , very hoppy and yet super bitter sweet malty m - coats the mouth a bit with some super bitter sweet lingering .  mouthfeel - the one noticeable drawback to this offering is the lack of carbonation . otherwise it felt very good in the mouth .

anyway , it had a great head , probably because of the nitro , but it was large , white , creamy and fluffy . great lacing to boot . kind of milky , gauzy .  this beer has a lot of flavor for a light . too bad its not a good flavor ! nothing impressive at all here . i 'm not sure what they are putting in this beer but its not worth the 7.99 they are charging for a six pack . i would recommend pabst blue ribbion over this any day !

the appearance is the best part about this beer . pours badass and the head stays with it the whole time of drinking .  the nose is caramely and very malty . a little too carbinated for a traditional barleywine but lines ones gut like the best of the bunch ! being a sucker for barleywines i have to give this beer high remarks .

the appearance is outstanding ! s : expresso like smell with subtle malty aroma .  it 's a black colored beer with ruby edges . fairly nice nose , with a variety of dark fruits , as well as a bit of chocolate and coffee . really nice nose . flavor is fully packed , loaded with dark fruits ( blackberry , plum , cherry and currant ) , as well as some notes of dark chocolate , coffee and a light hint of alcohol . i like it .

poured a slighly cloudy light orange copper with a 1.5 finger head that left a 1/4 in . lacing was n't all that sticky but was there .  light bodied though , almost watery . in a way this is an ipa-light - some similar desirable flavors and aromas , but less bitterness , less alcohol , and lighter bodied .

this smells amazing . like perfumed hop elephants . but damn ... this smells amazing . i could inhale this all day . which sounds odd .  this review is from notes in my `` travel journal . '' obviously the beer is now `` retired . there is some berry in the attack . the flavor smoothes out to leave a clean finish . it is a very drinkable beer , but not what i normally seek out .

the aroma was that of raisins smothered in chocolate , dried plums and cherries and some alcohol . a chocolatey start that gives way to dried fruits ( rasins and plums ) mixed with some bitterness .  the only real flaw for me with this beer is that it 's a bit thin , but that 's a bit nit-picky and did n't detract at all for me from this wonderful beer .

a - this is the first time i rated the appearance of a beer so high and it 's well deserved . deep yellow , almost tangerine colour , nice and cloudy , nice puffy head that stuck around for awhile . excellent and appetizing overall .  crisp taste - not heavy as expected ... hints of smokey , woody flavors - has the appeal of a coffee porter ... mouthfeel is average .

the smell is very fresh , crisp and clean ; truly wonderful . lots of citrus and pine aroma coming off immediately , mostly grapefruit with some floral grassiness as well , with some biscuity malt in the background . i could smell this a mile away and loved it . t : taste follows nose for the most part , leading off with citrus-pine hops with a sweet biscuity background . it 's fairly bitter , but the malt sweetness balances it just enough to keep it extremely pleasant and crisp . the taste was very fresh and very clean , ending as it began with a gentle , bitter , floral hop bite . the smell is exquisite , and the taste is juicy and not as dry as many similarly citrusy-bitter ipas , making it a bit more drinkable . with all the smaller breweries popping up in boston , and many focusing on more boutique styles , it 's great to see a new , local ipa that seems to be doing everything right without reinventing the wheel .  mouthfeel can be too fizzy if you do n't make sure to pour high for tall head . when i 'm drinking more than one beer , this is my favorite second or third , as it 's got enough hops to satisfy , is not highly alcoholic , and sells for a real good price where i live .

the smell is very oaky . there is a good bit of vanilla .  dare i say it seems a bit on the thin side . the meatiness in the flavor is not backed up by the body . not bad , but just a little disappointing ... this is a fine stout .

one of the most refreshing smelling beers i have ever sampled .  feels quite creamy at first , almost in a draft-stout kind of way , which struck me as odd . would rather it be crisper and a bit more carbonated , though .
excellent lacing . a great looking beer .  carbonation is ample but the body lacks a little texture .

the aroma was like a big hop garden bouquet with a little sugared pixie dust spread all over . i was ready for the taste and ready to be blown away , but was not .  the body is sufficient to carry the 10 percent alcohol which is impressive by itself . some spicy notes and an effervescent type of feel to it .

smell : lots of chocolate , toasted malt .  m : light-medium body with an oily mouthfeel , and a dry and resiny fade overall , not a bad beer , though it does stray from traditional belgian dubbels in a few aspects : not as sweet or yeasty as the classic belgian examples , a little hoppy for the style , and its too light .
smooth melted creamy chocolate with tart raspberry , kissed with dark fruits ; plums , prunes and blackberries .  m- seems a little thin , but nicely carbonated .

a : the beer is a medium orange in color with a 2 finger fluffy white head that has excellent retention and lacing . the beer has minimal haziness to it and is nearly 100 % translucent s : citrusy hops abound on the nose .  medium-high carbonation .

nose : oaky vanilla , caramel/toffee and apple skins dominate this so-called imperial ipa . insanely sweet and syrupy like most of dfh 's `` super beers '' ( ww stout , raison d'extra ) .  mouthfeel : i 've always thought this was a little off ... not quite enough spine to offset the sweetness .

i do n't know if the age helped , but this smells fantastic ... deep milk chocolate ... . nice bourbon and vanilla notes ... hints of brown sugar and cinnamon ... really a great nose . flavor loses anything from the nose ... a bit of dark cherry essence rounds out the ris flavors ... fudgy toward the finish.. oak seems a bit musky/tannic.. medium body with good carbonation .  this has the syrupy goodness of the 90-minute , but with an added syrupiness ... robust and smooth , like a desert sauce , you could pour this over a bowl of vanilla ice cream instead of a caramel sauce , with its own french vanilla creaminess ... the only thing that detracts here is an odd light metallic twinge at the finish that didnt seem to fit . otherwise , this is a beaut of a big beer with a light profile .

not overly complex , but interesting enough to keep your attention . d-i polished off the bomber effortlessly . really goes down nicely , and the alcohol is hidden fairly well .  surprisingly light mouthfeel makes it a fairly easy drinker for a 9 % er

looks perfect . mounds of off white maybe pretty much light tan head , and has a clear dark copper colored body .  the mouthfeel was the only thing that detracted from the beer in my opinion , as i found it to be a little to watery for my personal preference .

smell - i thought the nose on this beer was the best part . malt with grassiness . fresh smelling , almost floral . taste - wow ! that 's one bold and bitter finish !  i 'm not getting much in the way of bitterness anywhere here , which combines with a medium thin body to provide very little in the way of a finish .

smell is fantastic ! nothing but chocolate covered toffee in the nose , the lightest bit of roastiness , and a hint of nuttiness . i love it .  quite watery for the big flavor this one tastes and smells different from the main stream craft ipas , which is a pretty new category i 'll give it that .

s- super hoppy and sweet with a mixture of predominant pine flavor and underlying grapefruit notes ... absolutely exquisite . t- taste is very reminiscent of pliny the elder but possibly better balanced .  if you aerate the beer in your mouth , it really releases the co2 . it would do well as a beer to server with medium to strong cheese .

excellent aroma . lots of fruits both sweet and citrus , doughy yeast , something unknown but floral and distant anise perhaps .  very nice m : medium bodied-a bit thicker than i expect from an ipa or a dipa , but it works well with the oaky sweetness of this beer .
s : raisins and dark fruits with a mild white wine aroma .  little fruityness . light to medium body , oily , light carbonation . could be a little more carbonated .

appeared orange-golden with a monstrous , and i mean monstrous , frothy head and excellent lace retention . this is a beautiful looking beer .  this is a man 's beer . none of this flowery wine swilling critique lingo . light color , smell and mouth feel , who really cares . outstanding dry & hoppy flavor without sweetness . when bought in the 30 pack , cost is about 50 cents each . the best macro being produced !

s - roasted grains , caramelized sugar , wood smoke , charcoal , fireplace and campfire aromas abound ! wonderfully smoky , earthy , outdoorsy , and roasty ! i also smell some nice cheese notes hidden behind the smoke , and some solid hops are there too .  too carbonated , the mouthful of liquid seems to almost crumble right away .

aroma is on point with many ipa 's out there and really doesnt smell like an apa . very attractive nose . taste falls short of what i expected but still nice and balanced . has some sweet pineapple like sugary aftertaste that is appealing but throws me off from the lack of hop bitterness .  m : still a bit watered down , but again , it 's better .

this smell is really on the money and superbly enjoyable . tasted honey sweet with dark malts and dark fruits that fades into a smoky birch bark and a really dirty lime or rhubarb sourness .  m : a lighter body with good carbonation which yields a sensation akin to chewing on a cloud .

very nice looking beer .  this was followed up by a sweet , orangish tang on the tongue , followed by a sweet finish , especially in comparison to the berliner wiesse , which i tried earlier . the introduction of the lemon slice to the beer increases the dryness , especially at the finish . a good , summery beer with a name that invokes `` the simpsons . ''

a : i love the color ; a hazy gradient of orange and red hues that is literally shining in my glass , it would make a perfect sunset . beautiful .  mouthfeel too prickly and astringent but medium body is appropriate for style .

s. malty , with a hint of hops . most distinctive is a strong spice scent . t. sweet , and again malty and spicy , with the hops much more prominent than in the smell .  a good beer . comes in a .33ml brown bottle , part of a 6 pack sampler from brouwerij van steenberge . a sweet and dark beer , where hops has taken a back seat to the malt profile . not light , but not heavy either . give it a try .

the beer pours a nice 2-3 finger beige head with great retention and a lot of beautiful lacing on the glass .  t : wood chips , obviously , tastes like a sauna smells , charcoal , molasses , savory like breakfast sausage , soy sauce , real sharp sweetness that 's broken down by hops lurking in the background and that 's absent at the finish m : medium body , very low carbonation , i 'm surprised this was n't the cask ( it was n't but they did have it ) , dry bitter charcoal finish . the mouthfeel was a big drawback for me , it was very flat , considering this was the draft veraion .

reviewed 1/12/2010 ( bottle ) : pours a dark reddish brown color body , big fluffy head , off-white , lasting .  the carbonation is interesting , but a little too fizzy for me , i feel like this beer has a watery quality to it which i do n't particularly like in a porter . it starts out watery , then the carbonation kicks in .

aroma has pleasant vinous overtones , port . superb taste is exactly as expected from the nose . the figs are turning .  drank in a chalice from a bottle in brussels at delirium cafe.. this is very good lambic . it smells great very sweet with cherries . the beer has a beautiful red/brown color with a white head , not a lot lacing . it tastes sweet with cherries dominating but has a nice sour kick too .
reviewed 12/30/2009 ( bottle ) : pours a very dark almost black color body , ca n't see through at all . big light tan color head , somewhat lasting .  m : smooth on the palate .

it 's hard to make a stout i dont enjoy but i am not so sure about this one . the color is most excellent ( pure pitch black ) and it poured with a nice head but unfiortunately it did n't last and left very little lace on the glass .  mouthfeel is the only real negative to this one , medium bodied and a bit thinner than i 'd like .

amber highlights s- smells of nice mild hops and a nutty undertone t- has a rich caramel taste .  the colour is a light straw , probably the weakest colour i have seen in a pale lager , the head is very pleasent and has some serious glass cling ... the aroma is very skunky when first opened but quickly disappears and the taste is highly sweet malts on a thin body , very nice for dining , not a stadium brew ... i first reviewed this brew in march of 03 , approx 10 monthes ago .
clear brown color with a strong pillowy off-white head .  mouthfeel is bubbly crisp and slightly creamy , but overall rather watery .
a- it looks really good poured in a glass .  carbonation is a little light though .
fantastic stuff t- it 's ... really bitter ?  easy drinking but it has a different mouthfeel , it almost leaves a film in my mouth .

smells and looks like a hefeweizen . tastes banana , tropical . citric . extremely refreshing , great summer beer .  mouthfeel : a bit thin in body but makes up with an even overall texture not much carbonation very wine like with each sip .
s - mostly raspberry , which i found quite appealing . some caramel and roasted malt .  mouthfeel is a bit thin and watery .

appearance- fairly standard for an imperial stout . smell- huge malts bombard the nose with notes of chocolate and coffee . the spiciness was really surprising here .  parching on the tongue . almost no flavor : slight sweetness up front , trace of bitterness on finish . really .

the smell is a big whack of fresh sweet raspberries . damn , the taste does not live up to the pleasant smell . the alcohol burn is way too strong and blurs out the other flavors that hopelessly tries to emerge .  on tap this poured as a golden straw colored ale , clear and bright with less than an inch of head . there is an apparent hoppy aroma that followed with a similarly dominant slight-hoppy taste followed by the expected bitters - very tasty . i stopped with one . not to discount its drink-ability , there are just several others i wish to try .
pours a bright , clear , light orange color with a nice looking head .  lively carbonation is a bit excessive , but the body is quite smooth .
there is a strong , heavy caramel smell to the beer .  the body was a bit too thin for my tastes in this style .
pours a promising nearly opaque with a brown creamy head .  m- medium body that was slightly under-carbonated . with more carbonation , all the flavors would bite that much more .

a - pours a light golden brown with a slight haze with two solid thumbs of light pillowy head with an insane amount of retention .  m : the feel is creamy and medium bodied . rather light for a ris and that really detracts from the beer in my opinion . the mouthfeel is lighter than what i come to think of when i thik of a ris .

s : as soon as i popped this one , i loved the smell of it . i was hoping after the great smell , it would have a taste i loved , but unfortunately not a taste that suits me .  the nose of the beer is strong and gives off a nice floral hop aroma . the flavor is sweet and semi-tart with fruity tastes . behind the sweet fruit , there is a slight but smooth alcohol presence . the earthy hop bitterness comes in at the end and fades away with the semi-dry finish .

exceptional aroma . very hoppy , and you get it at the first sip , then the sweetness , finishes bitter , with all the hops of an ipa but more subdued .  taste/mouthfeel : this beer is slightly oily , with a very limited carbonation .

nose is amazing ! huge assertive orange spice . the single most assertive bold orange spice nose i may ever have smelled . beautiful . mouthfeel is rich and lightly creamy with nice carbonation and a nice texture and feel . flavors are just plain weird . there is an herb quality and character to this beer , initially stange and offensive that become very appealing . i suspect that one will love or hate this one ; and , it deserves a taste ; it 's unique .  m : a light-medium feel to it and kind of syrupy .

a huge aroma of starbucks mocha frappuccino jumps out of the glass . sweet chocolate and nice roasty smell mix in for quite a nose pleasing aroma . cappuccino leads the way in the flavor of this brew .  mouthfeel is ok. fairly light body , more than i 'd think it should be at this abv .

epic 's version has a great scent , faint spices , with a slight smokiness . it 's definitely much more bitter , with an almost a lemon pucker factor . the alcohol content also seems to add a bit more 'warmth ' than the dc brau version , which is n't entirely a negative .  i sent it back thinking it had gone bad , but the bartender tried it and assured me it was ok. m - average for a macro lager .

a- pours a brownish color with red hues noted against a white background . the clear nature of the beer allows me to see the carbonation , which is modest looking at best . the head is plentiful and puffy looking , retaining well and leaving behind a thick film of dense foam on the glass .  mouthfeel- medium body with very little carbonation .

right after i removed the cap i got this instant burst of fruitiness on the nose . then when i began to pour it , the aroma segued into a toasted bready , creamy , yeasty , and neutral hopped balance . i was sold before i even tasted it . fortunately the taste was just as endearing with a bold body and a sharp bitterness nut-like quality concluding with a pleasant dry hop finale . this beer really hit all the pressure points in a good way and is highly recommended .  m : medium bodied with not much creaminess or silkiness to talk about .
smell - a really nice roasted malt and bready smell .  body is medium , mouthfeel is oily/creamy , carbonation is low but adequate .

smell : loads of coriander , yeasty nuttiness and clove phenols , with a heavy dose of of bubblegum , yummy ! mouthfeel : very carbonated and full body notes : excellent . different and similar to the original at the same time .  color and mouthfeel are average for the style and fine .

aroma is very malty : my schnoz detected caramel , spice , wine-like notes , and a certain booziness . we had beatification , allagash black , westvleteren 8 and westvleteren 12 before this beer , so maybe it was just upstaged and i might have thought it exceptional on any other night .  but it has quite a few pros : this beer is intended to be consumed with food . if you want to have chinese food with a light drink then this one is just what you are looking for ! it 's a typical lager : crystal-clear blonde , discreet taste and weak aroma . i usually do n't drink lager beers but this one i can have by the barrels while there 's food on the table . this beer is what you want to drink when you do n't want to drink !

the nose is impressive . easily the most enjoyable part of drinking this beer .  this is an enjoyable , smooth but tasty strong polish lager . the aroma is fresh , toasty sweet bread , hint of lemon , pine , and rather nice . it has a bit of a czech lager taste to it and the alcohol is essentially unnoticeable . the taste is clearly alcholic , but very smoothly so , with nothing rough opr unpleasant . it has a light caramel quality , bread , and nice , warm spiciness , it 's a bit rasiniy , sweet and spicy with a light bitterness coming to the fore in the finish . it does not taste quite as strong as it is .

smell was deep with plenty of sweet chocolate aromas and bitter grains .  medium-full bodied mouthfeel with below average carbonation , the latter being ( beside the appearance ) one of my few criticisms .

smell : strong spice and citrus , bubble gum taste/mouthfeel : thin but refreshing , banana , spicy hops this witbier was very good . i think the appearance of the beer itself lacks a little but the smell and taste makes up for it .  this is n't the fault of the brewer so maby it had great head . the main problem with this beer was infection . i 'm sure it was an infection because when i sniffed it i thought for a second maybe i was at the movies about to dig into a 12 dollar medium popcorn . past the buttery flavor i could taste blueberry almost which i 'm sure was n't intended either . it 'd be interesting to taste one from a different batch .

underneath is roasted chocolate malt , light vanilla , and citrus , providing good complementary variety .  medium bodied with medium carbonation . i only wish this average mouthfeel was supporting an average taste .
clear walnut color with a lot of fine streaming bubbles and a rocky , long-lasting head .  m : surprisingly thin , slightly sticky body with low carbonation . a little weak .
great head , expected cascading upon serving .  mouthfeel is a bit of a problem for me . the carbonation level is also a factor , making it hard to enjoy in gulps .

from notes a - good dark black body with a medium brown head s - delicious sweet chocolaty bourbon t - dry smoky bourbon and vanilla . o ( d ) - tasty , great smelling . a 6 oz bottle split 4 ways can make it difficult to judge . but very enjoyable  feel is kinda harsh .
pours a very dark brown with red around the edges and a large tan colored head . a small head remains throughout and leaves great lacing . looks good .  carbonation seems spot on .

s - very nice . sweet . i like it a lot . very different than most beers of this style .  mouthfeel is a bit light , to me , for the style , though it seems appropriate for the flavors that this beer brings to the palate .
aroma - dark fruits with a caramel and sweet malts .  mouthfeel is a little bit thin .
nose is superb -- very much pumpkin pie . delicious and a new pumpkin ale favorite !  m : okay , mostly wet and satisfyingly quaffable , but with a noticeable alcohol presence in the finish .

a - very good , very light golden orange - pretty decent head retention s - the most unique citrus nose of any dipa i 've ever encountered . upfront dried fruit basket and grapefruit blast to the senses . i can pick out the citra hops , that for sure . bitter dry , crisp finish . very , very good beer .  not sure if our north american brethren appreciate this but this is , as far as i can tell the first fairly widely available american style ipa brewed in the uk . the american craft brewing industry which has been accused of being derivative is really starting to influence europe which is great . i am all for my uk brewing industry but i do get a little board of the vast variety of often samey real ale bitters populating manypubs . we definitely have a shortage of hopheads brewing in the uk ! and before anyone shoots me down , greene king ipa is not an ipa ! ! !

color me surprised that this is a stout at all and then an ris ? big ipa nose . big old ale taste - tons of smoother , sweeter dark malts . more like a normal stout , i suppose .  a bit on the light side of medium in body , with a dryish spicy finish . aftertaste seems watery .
poured into a tumbler it produces a 2 inch head that persists and clings to the glass in great clumps . the appearance is perfect pale and slightly cloudy .  m - felt a bit thin to me .

nose was erupting from the pour with plenty of darker malts , some dark wheats , a bit of a roasty and toasty aroma , a very slight chocolate , some dark fruits with a bit of fig , hint of booze , some toffee , and lots of dark wheat aromas . taste starts with darker wheats and malts again , a slight caramelized wheat flavor , some brown sugar and molasses , plenty of toffee , darker wheat flavors , a bit of a cola like syrup flavor but just a hint , some darker malts , roasted malts and some toasted malts , slight chocolate again , more fruits , fig and touch of a nutty flavor , hint of coffee , fairly complex , and even a hint of warming booze , that comes out a bit more on the finish but never heavy , very slightly sticky and hint of sweetness but dries slightly .  mouthfeel is a little thin and aftertaste is a little too much ... like the brew has gone stale , although i know it has n't .

a - golden brew with extremely intense carbonation large head fueled by the bubbling .  a very special thanks to zeke at the speakeasy for sharing a bottle of this 1995 treat . it still had carbonation in it which was crazy . the beer was very dry at this point . the spiciness of this beer has been cut down from the aging .

the flavor is not quite as complex as the nose would suggest but it is still quite good . it starts out with some dry oakiness followed by dusty cocoa .  feel is smooth and well-carbonated though a bit on the thin and watery side . medium-full body , not too heavy . leaves a nice sticky coating around the mouth . a bit thicker and less bitter and it 'd be great .
pours hazy light brown with some orange tints . great head and great lacing .  the mouth feel is heavy with a decent amount of carbonation .

black with a nice brown head that leaves good lace rings .  had this during o'briens wet hop festival . pours clear orange with a white ring of bubbles . lots of caramel with some tropical hops in the nose . kind of like a fruitcake . earthy , yet citrusy in the taste . bit sweeter than your normal ipa . grapefruit and blood orange . good stuff .
s : creme brulee ? the nose on this beer is amazing . loads of vanilla , caramel , cream , butterscotch and a tad bit of roasted malt .  m : over carbonated - fizzy .
what a great looking beer .  mouthfeel- light-moderate mouthfeel . carbonation is moderate-high .

i was much more impressed by the pour and visual of this beer than by taste or drinkability . nice puffy styrofoam cloud of a head .  creamy , light toffee . very mild bitterness . mild carbonation and foamation , could be a little more vigorous .

nose is roasty coffee , caramel , roast chocolate , herbal hop , and fruity , spicy and nutty yeast products . crazy . the first thing that hits me is fruit bouquet , then herbal hop ushers in phenols . good if you do n't think of it as stout .  i purchased this beer in a mix and match pack at the recommendation of the guy working at the liquor store = error . the look of the beer was clear and it drank smooth , but it was accompanied by the 'sour beer face . ' the taste was a combination of failure and shame ( with a hint of fruit ) all leading to the grand finale of a quick pour into the drain .

there is something hypnotic about watching the beer cascade into a jet black liquid with a wonderful tan thick creamy head . to me , the head on this is the best of almost any beer , and has a unique look .  m - this one finished a little dry , too much so for my liking , but the carbonation was nicely balanced , making it very smooth .

poured out of a 16.9 oz bottle into a tulip style glass . i held it up to the sun on my patio and admired it for a few seconds . ( cue music ) there were two inches of white head that led to a nice white cap that never dissipated .  mouf & gt ; easy , average .

nose speaks of a wonderful sweetness , malty , yeasty , and fruity , but most of all carries a unique candy-like scent . excellent . taste is malty and semi-sweet initially , with some spicy hints lingering and a bit of hop dryness .  rich , almost like chicken soup broth , and very low carbonation . in the world of bocks , this could be a new favorite of mine .

nitro-tap , nice pour into a pint glass at henry 's 12th street tavern in portland . color is brownish-black , thick tan head has excellent retention all the way to the end .  my first taste of it was great , however it lacks in the balance of the malts , and has sort of a over roasted taste . altogether though , this beer in my opinion is the best of the coors brand and i would recommend for something new . not a everyday beer though .
boisterous smoked malt aroma , meaty , beaty , big , & bouncy , with light noble hops accompanying .  this one was surprisingly thin in body .
appearance - really dark with a very nice looking mocha/tan head . looks incredible .  even with the earthy malt flavor , the overall feel stays on the thin side .
poured a 4 finger fluffy white head with excellent retention .  mouthfeel works just fine , but is a little watery . highly drinkable .

i look at these two next to each other and woder if i have not walked into a paint shop and someone mixed my color swatch perfectly ... the aroma is fantastic . it has all the elments of a wonderful malt bomb , and just enough hop remnants to keep it interesting .  m/d - mouthfeel is nothing special , the steely hop bite takes a bit away .

very nice aroma here -- spot on for the style -- as notes of fresh orange peel combine with soft coriander spice and a hint of lemon .  mouthfeel is lightly carbonated , a little thick ( like a dark lager ... blech ) , and generally mediocre .
the aroma is deliciously hoppy with some citrus notes .  m- thin to medium in body . highly attenuated with a soft carbonation .

appearance this oatmeal stout was almost black with a monster head that just blew up on contact with the glass . it was dark tan and left some good lacing .  a bit more body would 've made this an excellent brew .
the head looks really nice and has nice retention . lots of sticky lacing .  medium bodied , highly carbonated .

a - solid black brew that allowed not even the slightest bit of light to peep through ; medium brown head that was retained throughout the session and left a nice coat of lacing s - smell of alcohol was certainly present and the aroma was mostly that of whiskey , with a whiff of coffee scent t - the flavor profile was more balanced than the aroma suggested , with whiskey and coffee as the most prevalent characteristics , though there was a hint of chocolate m - smooth texture with a somewhat sticky finish d - overall easy drinker , but the whiskey flavor lingers a little too long as a result of the sticky finish .  unfortunately , it is basically flat , with a heavy mouthfeel . overall , this beer would be unbelievable with good carbonation .

i smell a fruity and floral characteristic along with a strong citrusy hop overtone . this is a classic ipa and the brewers knew what they were doing with this batch .  m : very very mild carbonation .
pours a beautiful dark orange/copper color with a good head retention and lacing . i love the color of this beer .  the mouthfeel is a little off , too light and thin .
the appearance of the beer was beautiful - the color was a rich black , there was nice head retention and some lacing . overall , this was a terrific and memorable beer .  heavy mouthfeel .

a very attractive beer . powerful aroma . moist , sweet raisins at the forefront , with bitter chocolate , roasted malt , soy sauce and sweet sherry behind .  mouthfeel is slightly thin for the style or maybe just thin for how much is going on there ... .like you are expecting more of a stout mouthfeel .

beautiful aromas of freshly baked banana bread , vanilla coke , toasted candied coconut . definitely will be cracking some more of these open in the future , alcohol is well hidden and i tend to consider rr a bit too hyped but this is a very nice beer .  if i had to log a complaint , it would be that this stout is too thin and less of a cream offering . however , it is full of flavor and easy to drink despite being 6.5 % abv .

bubblegum , banana and cloves . smells just like i 'd like a hefeweizen to smell . the taste does n't live up to the nose , however .  this is about my only complaint of this beer-too much carbonation ! carbonation gives a foamy/frothy mouthfeel .

smell is incredible . a big sugar smell is predominant accompanied by nice dark malts . there is a nice thickness to it as well , that makes it incredibly smooth . drinkable beer for a strong abv .  very good light lager . hints of barley and hops , with a smooth slightly dry aftertaste . this brew had a short lived white foamy head and lower than normal carbonation . i would highly recommend this to any light beer drinker .

i do not really know who hiroyuki fujiwara is , except that he is an illustrator , makes these limited editions out of hitachino , and everyone seems to think he is the coolest guy . yellow opaque pure white head .  carbonation is n't bad , with fairly good activity after each drink . mouth-feel is a bit dry .

2008 vintage a- almost stout-like in appearance , no head , fizzy swirl of carb in the middle of a color-devoid structure ... s-vanilla , cherry , oak , intense , strong , amazing smells ... .omg ... .there is n't a single hint of sour beer behind this nose . simply smooth vanilla and cherry ... awesome ... .ca n't remember a better nose on a sour ... . t- starts off smooth , nothing much going on *served at 39 degrees f.* then spice , phenols , tartness , tanginess , oh man ... this is great ... . m- solid brick of a mouthfeel , with a few glimmers of carbonation ... nothing exceptionally nasty about the 'brick ' that i speak of , but it is different ... .all together a different beer but for mouthfeel , i 'd expect something flat to taste like this , but in all it provides the right amount of carbonation ! duchesse on crack ...  m-a bit watery for my tastes but the taste makes you forget about it being slightly thin .

a : beautiful . three fingers worth of foamy mocha colored head . lots of lacing here .  it has constantly proved itself to be my favorite local utah brew ( this use to be called the 2002 unofficial ale ) . if the pour makes your mouth literally water , you know it 's good . damn good beer ,

a : pours a vigorous 4 finger creamy white head with excellent retention . lacing is amazing considering the light body , with layers clinging to the side of the glass like a ruler .  rated as a stout the mouthfeel is a bit thin , the carbonation is a bit high , and the finish is a bit less than one would expect .

a-pours a dark copper color with two and a half fingers of off-white , dense head . d-very confused by this one ; everything about this beer , besides color , screams porter to me , not marzen .  the mouthfeel has a strange little zing that seems inappropriate for the style .
beautiful , beautiful honey color with a thick , but not creamy , head .  mouthfeel is a bit light .

a : this pours an entirely transluscent orange color with red hues and a finger and a half of slightly off-white head that laces better than any beer i have ever seen .  mouthfeel is fairly carbonated , a bit sour , finishing dry and crisp .
