seems very complex , i love it . t : disappointed from the smell .  m : meh . disappointingly flat . i 'd like more carbonation .

s-what comes through first is a perfect balance of sweet caramel malt and a blast of citrus hops . d- this brew is pretty awesome . brews that emphasize the citrus/spicy hop combo are hard to come by and this one does an excellent job with it .  taste : a bit thin for a porter , almost to the point of being slightly watery .

the aroma is amazing . major chocolate aroma with a dose of roasted malts , vanilla , toffee and cocoa . sort of a letdown on the taste .  medium to thick body , light almost too light level of carbonation with a sweet almost sticky mouthfeel .

s - extemely sweet and malty , with hints of floral aroma hops . the flavor and aroma are good enough to have couple of these beers , but there is n't much to want to bring you back .  ginger is one of my favorite flavors . this beer has a wonderful ginger taste , which is exactly what i would expect from a beer with this name . further , there is a decent bitterness & a slight sweetness as well . i 'm not a huge fan of spiced beers normally , but this one is really nice . recommended .
appearance perfect looking . the frothy , sticky head is everlasting .  a really really long aftertaste in the nose .
a-pours a midnight black color with two fingers of dark brown head .  lowish carbonation and a slightly thin mouthfeel .

s : some malty caramel and butter . tons of ripe fruit . t : malty and buttery again with some honey .  the mouthfeel of the beer was , like most porter and ale styles , very average . however , the mouthfeel did not detract from the overall feel of the beer .
this is probably the most impressive smelling amber style ale i have enjoyed .  the mouthfeel was medium/light bodied with a fine , prickly carbonation .

a : beautiful head about 2 fingers thick that never goes below a half finger thick , ever . golden/amber in color , looks like honey . honestly , one of the best looking ipas ever .  s : candied pineapple , yeast , and hops well balanced t : a typical ipa taste with accents of pineapple ; yeasts and hops , well balanced m/d a bit thin , carbonation too small and too much , abv on the high side and quite noticeable good beer

brown/red/amber , on the clear side , nice head that lasts . maybe give it a touch more opacity . edit : if they just called it a winter warmer and dropped barleywine from the name , why , it would probably just be average and not bad .  i wish the carbonation was a little more noticeable in the mouth .
a : a much darker brown than most brown ales . poured a thick creamy espresso colored head with good carbonation showing .  could use both more body and carbonation .

what struck me first was the phenomenally fresh smell . the roasted malt and slightly bitter hops hits your nose and just stays there , begging you to take a sip . while the beer is great , the taste did n't quite live up to the smell . a bit thinner than expected and a bit less complex than i had hoped .  thin body ample carbonation overall : this is slightly better than bud light but still not really worth drinking

s - great smell . dark fruits such as raisins and plums maybe . o - good over all .  taste is more of the same ... some wild floral flavors , hints of citrus ... seems like the dominant flavors have switched from the citrus to the floral characteristics . i like it , for sure , but could use some balance . i 'm not a big fan of the bitter taste left in the mouth ... but it 's still plenty drinkable . a definitely above-average ale , but not the best .

well , the label says brewed with peaches and pecans and you get tons of peach on the nose . and it 's a real peach smell too , not the kind in gummy candy .  m - thought it was a little flat , but not bad .

a : beautiful , clear , dark ruby body under a majestic two-finger head of creamy , sticky tan foam . tons of lace . truly spectacular . s : a little underpowered - light acetic sting , some sweet fruit , and a bit of husky malt .  the beer poured hard but the carbonation ended up being low and the mouthfeel medium .

beer also appeared to be quite carbonated smell : hot-day-amn . the smell of this one is trump tight . the eastern spices are like aroma therapy . those clove-ish spices blend with the hops and a sweet fruit scent to create an enticing aroma . taste : from the second this one hits your lips you just know that this is an `` americanized '' tripel .  the body is rather thin though .

a : a clear and deep golden-coloured liquid , with a nice-looking white head that leaves a nice ring of retention . beautiful .  palate : medium body , thinner than expected actually , but goes down smooth .

this is the only barley wine i have every tried , and chances are it will be the last . some people love this stuff , not me , not my taste buds .  pours a three finger light tan head that fades quickly to a ring leaving a little lace . dark cloudy amber color . light carbonation and light bodied . caramel nose . starts balanced but then a caramel flavor that stays to a clean finish . a tasty wheat . $ 2.49 for a 500ml bottle from john 's grocery iowa city , ia .
with that said ... nice look . chestnut brown , reddish tones . good , soft , dense head .  mouthfeel was avg ; like a nice dark beer .

no head retention or lacing huge oaky , fruitty boozey nose , beautiful t : dryness , raisins , dates , & breadyness with a slight booze presence up front .  the mouth is a little lighter than years past .

light tan head for a second , poor retention and lacing ... the aroma is sweet with lots of nice sweet bourbon on the front . its a really nice smooth bourbon , makes you really want to drink it ... the taste really lets me down sadly .  mouthfeel is fine - it 's a very light lager .
smells pretty good .  m : um . it was carbonated and did n't leave any odd off flavours on the palate .
see-thru orange with a massive frothy head that does n't leave crazy amounts of lacing , but is to be commended for its excellent retention .  m- light in body and light to medium in carbonation .

smells very tasty .  sprecher brewing company is one of milwaukee 's first micro 's and in fact its the one that really got me into quality beer tasting and home brewing . this is one of my favorite octoberfest beers as far as drink-ability as many octo 's are a bit overly heavy for me . this one really leaves your palate refreshed and ready for more . i lived in germany for two years and never found a beer at a octoberfest there that was like american octoberfest style of brews but thats why i like them they are unique even if maybe they are n't trying to be .
s : strong enticing smell of toffee , vanilla and butterscotch . t : much the same as the smell .  3.0 m : medium body . smooth , but not creamy .
the smell is sweet , spicy , almost vinous , and very complex . each time i think i have an aroma captured it changes into something else .  mouthfeel is a little thin , though .

s : a pretty complex smell , though coffee beans tend to be the dominant auroma . it 's nicely accented by a faint hint of sweet chocolate . t : there 's a real bright fruitiness that i do n't really pick up on in the scent that compliments ( but not well ) the coffee flavor that is n't so much roasted anymore as it is just kind of bitter . both are underwhelming to say the least , but this taste is n't as bad as it is disappointing .  my only gripe with this beer was the mouthfeel . it was rather thin and watery with a mild yet large bubbled effervescence .

the appearance is a deep coffee color , heading almost to burgundy . the light tan head is large and resistant , preventing me from quickly getting into it .  m : somewhat thin body , slightly watery ; could do with more carbonation also .
smells nearly exactly like pumpkin pie . this was my first pumpkin beer , and it 's not a style i 'm particularly enamored with .  m- low carbonation and very low mouthfeel .

pours a lager-yellow , huge creamy white head that dissipates down to a film leaving very much lace . nice looking beer .  a delightful golden color graced by a pale yellow head . i did n't get much lacing , but i believe that was due to a freshly-washed glass ( served at a bar ) . nice hops come through in this one . it is a little bitter and spicy , but also has some good vanilla and tones of malt . not the most fantastic example of its style , but tasty and very drinkable .

pours jet black with 3 fingers of brownish , mocha head that just screams ice cream float . tons of sticky lacing & very good head retention s : roasty malt , rich , dark & fruitty with woody hops , & booze once warm t : roasty malt , dark choclate , herbal hops along with molasses , leafy & minty hops up front .  mouf & gt ; nice , nothing special drinkability & gt ; sure thing

pours visibly effervescent and a cloudy maple amber with a huge stiff off white head that decomposed in 3d , like an ice cream float , with a good amount of belgian lacing left behind .  there is a very little carbonation factor in this beer .

plenty of citrus fruits and pine , along with some other fruitiness ( maybe strawberry and mango ) make this an alluring smelling gem . the tastebuds are greeted with the expected large dose of hop bitterness , but balanced nicely by a little bit of sweet malts .  perhaps a bit thin for the style , which i suppose makes it a good pale ale for summertime quaffing .

this had a wonderful nose of tropical fruits , sugars , and malts , with a little herbal hop bitterness thrown into the mix as well . the taste was more of the same , fruity , sweet and delicious . this did have a medicinal , somewhat metallic , after taste though that kind of reminded me of orval .  slight hint of the hop flower but the malt dominates , sweet , crisp , fresh and pleasing to the senses with the start lightly sweet , satisfactory malt presence , and top light to middling in feel . this is a style where i like the lighter body , as it lets the flavoring hops shine through , quite quaffable , a damn fine session beer me thinks , and i thank royalt for this bottle .

this poured out wonderfully with a growing tall head of very tight frothyness of light tannish color sitting atop a glowing deep mahagony , rubyish copper highlighted gem of a bottom .  m - at times , a bit of a metallic feel to the beer .

bottle : poured a golden color ale with a huge pure white foamy head with great retention and lacing .  no sediment at all when bought fresh . this really brought out flavors you could not taste beforehand . a wedge of orange or lemon is a nice touch also . best served a little warmer than most beers . goes really well with food . a beer you could drink all night especially during a good bar-b-que .

poured from a 12oz bottle , into a 16oz glass mug , color was a beautiful hazy golden , with a huge 3 finger+ fluffy head .  mouthfeel is carbonated , but creamy and smooth . lacks the dry bite that i look for in a dipa .

n : nice nose ! ( why thank you-i just had it fixed ! ) mocha , french roast coffee with milk and sugar , choco-roasted malt , brown bread , and a touch of molassas . pretty awesome in its intensity and complexity . p : slightly watery newcastle brown with some roasted malt , seltzer , and dock of the bay tones . m : medium carbonation , medium to light body , crisp , clean and fresh finish , slight lingering malt , slightly sour .  feels thin .

pours to a very dark brown , only slightly ruby colored liquid with a massive fluffy white head that coats the entire circumference of the glass in a perfect frilly victoria 's secret crotchless panty-style lacing . she really is quite sexy looking .  much like the ingredient list on the back , there are scent of malted barley , malted wheat , hops , and yeast which gives it an almost caramel scent . starts out making you think this will be a heavy tasting beer with its malted ingredients like a stout but instead it finishes rather light . drinks rather smooth as the malted ingredients really hit the taste buds . finishes rather clean smooth . a decent beer with a rather interesting drinking experience .

the aroma is sensational . sweet , fruity , yeasty .  had some fruity and clove flavors but was covered up due way too many hops for the style - not to mention that it was bitter . i barely finished it . other reviewers liked this beer and seemed to have a much different experience than i did which leaves me to believe that they have consistency problems or maybe they use different formulas for each location ? btw this one was sampled at the brewpub near the fleet center .
the aroma is sweet fruits and some spice including coriander , orange peel is present as well .  mouthfeel is a little thin , but not offensively so .

s- as only a good british beer can smell , luscious . very complex . t/m- ok , the taste lets down a bit after the luscious aroma . a good beer but disappointed that it is n't a great beer .  just the right amount of hops . even though you can taste the fruits and spice , you can also taste the high alc % . drinkability : very drinkable , but if you more than one in a session , watch out : ) overall : a better than average tripel .

pours a hazy amber colour with one of the most impressive head i have ever seen . a frothy rocky mountain large off white head .  leaves you breathless -- groping for words to describe what is one of the worst beers i 've ever tasted . i have had enough bacterial beers to recognize the usual flavors .

a - a nice looking beer with a dark brown color reminiscent of a good black coffee or coke . head was a good two fingered tan froth , that retained quite well .  m- a bit over carbonated for me , but other than the crisp nature of most kiwi beers , nice malty and dry .

the aromas were inviting and very exciting . t : dark and sweet fruits at the beginning of the sip , hints of alcohol in the middle , ending in a pretty strong bitter kick .  m - moderate carbonation-almost too much , dry finish , medium bodied due to the carbonation .

a - extremely dark brown body with a dark brown head to go along with it . the thick and frothy head started out at about 4 inches and ever so slowly faded down leaving a thick humocky topography .  m : surprisingly on the more carbonated side with a slight fizzy mouthfeel .

this beer pours a very bright yellow sundrenched tint that just beckons to be drunk .  a light- to moderate mouthfeel , hints of sour flavor linger at the back of the tongue after the swallow . i do n't pick up much of a hint of carbonation in the mouthfeel .

lighter and brighter looking than i expected , nelson poured without any `` redness '' i typically , and erroneously , associate with rye beers . a clear hay golden hue , with a beautiful cream white head ; excellent retention and lacing .  mouthfeel medium body for the style with sharp carbonation .
pours an opaque thick looking black , with a fat beige head . very attractive .  the mouthfeel is thiner but still good .

aquired through a trade with xpimptasticx , thanks wanted to try for a while a- well , it looks harmless , it looks like a regular dipa except it had hardly any head and no lacing but ... that 's where the similarities stopped s- incredible smell : blood orange , booze , hops on performance enhancing drugs and a faint mango in there t- sweet booze , like a orange hop liqueur or triple sec .  there is little ( hardly any ) carbonation here , and the mouthfeel really does n't pack a punch at all .
great retention and great lacing .  m : light bodied and well carbonated .
s - nutty , chocolaty , malty aroma .  mouth feel : a bit thin on the palet , or maybe the aroma and taste make you expect more in the way of mouth feel .
very sessionable , but only an adequate porter with the exception of the nose which is amazing .  m : very carbonated .

allspice cinnamon and nutmeg all very strong a beautiful smelling ! t-the spices hit upfront with an impressive strength .  mouthfeel suffers a little bit as i feel a higher abv would 've left this coating the tongue a little better . it seemed a little too thin to match its flavor profile .

however the taste is a shadow of the wonderful aroma , which is a disapointment only because it smelled so nice and i was excited for something special . nice , but i wanted more . overall it is a nice beer from a solid brewer .  a little less carbonation and this probably enters `` special '' territory .

great black appearance with cascade of bubbles when poured that lasted a minute , leaving 1/2 inch tan head that stayed until the glass was empty .  the carbonation is heavy and it adds harshness to the palate . medium-full body .

stunning ruby red/black beauty with superb head retention .  take this beer for what it is ... a nice `` treat . '' it 's not something you will want to drink all night long . but for a nightcap , or change of pace this beer fits the bill . the vanilla taste is not overpowering , it 's there , but not so bold and overpowering that it seems fake .

smell : extremely tart , cherries , acid , mushroom , funk/barn/horseblanket , leather and oak taste : extremely sour , i could n't get the taste of this one out of my mouth till dinner the next day . similar to the smell , vinegar , lots of must/mold , leather , oak , and sour/tart cherries .  thin to medium bodied with moderate carbonation .

s - smelled like delicious spiced pumpkin pie with clove and spiced apple undertones . this is an excellent beer .  mouthfeel was a bit heavy and undercarbonated , but that may have been more of the fault of the bar i was at , and not the beer its self .

a nice white head , great retention and lacing ... the aroma is fantastic , so fresh , just plucked pine needles with pineapples and an assortment of tropical fruits ... taste is equally great , bitting pine and alcohol of a dipa , but muted and so drinkable .  the mouth fell was a little thin for stout .

330 ml bottle consumed at a certain way , on to the beer : it 's black with a some hues of ruby red . the head formed on top is extremly thick , is tanned in color , and still holds on top until the last sip . did i mention is shows some rings of lacing ?  m/t : light to medium body , watery and a good amount of carbonation . however with the light body , low bitterness and virtually zero aftertaste , i could session this beer .
nice copper color smell : could totally smell those pumpkin pie spices . nice !  the body was medium to medium light .

pours out a completely opaque dark brown colour with some ruby edges . big frothy one inch head has some serious staying power . of course that leaves lots of sticky lace .  mouthfeel : slighty watery good .

the aroma , oh the aroma of clean fresh blueberries was awesome ! ! : a cooking note , it makes a great smelling pancake addition to your mix .  mouthfeel : typical red stickyness drinkability : i love this beer .
pours a beautiful light honey color . have n't seen a pale lager with such nice color .  mouthfeel is high carbonated foamy and slightly mouthcoating .

from a brown 12 oz.bottle , cute dog , no date . poured a cloudy golden orange with a thick , dense , white head that almost topped the bottle before i began to pour , and left nice lacing .  tart and dry feel , but not overly so . lower carbonation detracts a little , really the only flaw in my mind .

pours a opaque black no light showing thru this bad boy with a thinner mocha colored head , wow the aromas damn where to begin heavy on the dark roast coffee , bitter chocolate a hint of almond extract as well just awesome.flavors are heavy in the coffee department for some it maybe to much dark roast coffee and chocolate malt flavors with a malted milk type flavor , nice creamy , silky mouthfeel glides down pretty easily.if you like strong coffee and bitter chocolate you 'll love this beer .  mouthfeel is light , and carbonation is set at medium .

aroma is pungent with grapefruit , sharp citric hops , with cloaked , faint suggestions of oranges , apples , and toasty grains .  thin bodied , and just sufficient carbonation , but i suspect the growler is at fault much more than the beer .
appearance : black in color sporting a two finger creamy head that lasted a long time .  m - crisp and bitey , high carbonation - the bottle overflowed when i opened it .

the head recedes smells great , rummy , oak-y , sugar cane , caramel , coconut , spicy , very layered and complex nose . there 's a little hop bitterness in the taste but all else is overpowered by the rum and oak taste .  the motuhfeel is moderately carbonated and slightly watery .
2006 appearance , great head and retention . easy to create head .  mouthfeel is on the thin side for a stout .

the aromas promise a dandy ; juicy dark fruit ester , roasted coffee , pineapple , chocolate powder and molasses , and hints of bubble gum . a silky mouthfeel , slightly oily , and a sharp carbonation that does n't bite too hard is quite enjoyable . dark fruits , plum , sweet tobacco notes and some coffee and cocoa but not like the nose indicated .  nice aroma of hops but i would hope for a bit more being a hops lover . the celebration ale , from the same company , seems to hit the spot more than this beer but still worthy of a place in the fridge and still better than many micro beer ipa ii . sierra nevada seems to me to be the only mass beer company that brews excellent beer for `` mass beer '' prices .

s : big yeast smell right up front . the yeast and hops work really well together . excellent nose . t : wow . d : very nice beer . still excellent beer all around .  mouthfeel was ok , not too thin , right amount of carbonation .
heaps of coco in the nose . roasted malt on the tongue , but the taste is surprising fleeting .  the carbonation is around medium . there is a watery texture to the beer which is not pleasant .

it 's really smooth and i appreciate the level of authentic bourbon present in the nose . the flavors consist of chocolate , roasted malts , light coffee with cream , vanilla , barrel and alcohol . the 9 % is n't hidden at all and after the nose , is pretty surprising . and it is n't the bourbon that is overpowering , it 's the abv of the beer itself .  guest two usually drinks michalob ultra , coors light , or busch light . since this is my girlfriends dad he knows about my passion for quality beer so i 'll often encourage him to sample what i am drinking . he rarely enjoys any of them and most of the time makes a look of disgust after the first sip . he drank two bitburgers in about a half hour without one little peep about the taste . i noticed these reactions before i had the opportunity to sample this beer myself . later in the evening , after the music was turned down and the midnight snacks were partaken of , i tried one . they were right , this beer sucks over a year later i have grown to like this beer alot .

the nose is heavy on the rye malt- showing a more pure breadiness with fruity tones of buttery apples , white raisin , faint cinnamon , light brown sugar , plum . the parallels to rye whiskey are awesome in this . the medium bodied palate is caramelly sweet up front with a mild bitterness that ushers in the rye maltiness- drying and spicy with lots of fruity tones .  m : very carbonated - almost too much .

pours with a beautiful long-lasting head and a very nice effervescence ; there is a constant stream of bubbles rising from the bottom of the glass till the last drop .  m - fairly thin body and medium carbonation . nothing special on the mouthfeel .

the smell is bright and strong . lots of clover but also a healthy dose of lemon and banana . it is a quintessential hefeweizen smell . the body is a bit weak .  the taste is sweet and smooth , with a hint of hops but the most prevalent taste is of lemon . finishes with a very refreshing aftertaste . i would defiantly suggest this beer to even non craft beer drinkers .

really cool head color : it is mocha with a red tinge .  the flavor too is ever so slight wine barrel aging with a weird and awkward type sour . it 's really off putting . this barrel aging was awful . this beer is weak and severely overrated . it was awful both times .
absolutely wonderful ! t : unfortunately , does n't quite live up to the aroma .  m : not too bad , there was a little bit of body .

smell : the highlight of this beer ... beautiful clean aroma of light fruits with a backbone of belgian yeast and a moderate citrus hint .  this feels thin for some reason . carbonation is good and proper .

this bock pours perfectly with a tight forming bright white head that stays around for a good duration .  mouthful mouthful is okay . has decent carbonation , but i 've had better as far as carbonation goes .

pretty simple , but really pleasant . 3.5 t : similar to the nose only very much subdued .  despite the nearly opaque black color , the flavor of this one is surprisingly light . there are sweet malt notes , a delicious fruitiness and some fairly rich yeasty , estery notes . i keep over-looking this brewery , but every time i try one of their beers im usually pretty impressed . this particular beer is tasty , refined and very drinkable . recommended .
in the original struise glass it looks really great .  mouthfeel is ok. a litte too dry for my liking though .

the aroma is really great . big hop presence and a flavor profile that screams west coast .  very ashy , very charred , and it really lacks some body and sweetness to back up the astringency . feel is very light , a shame , because a thick , chewy , silky body is a necessity in the style .

scent was very pleasant with loads of dark roasted earthy malts and chocolate . very rich nose - with a touch of malted milk also . the head , lacework and scent of this beer were outstanding !  it was my first fruity beer . it kinda tasted like an apricot . i was expecting most of a fruit taste like wine , but no . and i liked the picture on the bottle . and since it came ithaca i just had to try it . over all the beer was worth it . it 's good . : )
smell was strong with bananas , sweet , bready malts . an interesting beer , and one that 's good as a crossover beer .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied and syrupy with a bit of sharp carbonation .

appearance - pours dark enough to block out all light . a big bubbled mocha head springs up and i have to quell the pour a bit to calm things down . it caps off and forms a nice creamy cover with large spacious bubbles of foam below it .  mouthfeel - very enjoyable borderline complex character .

lively grapefruit , bright citrus notes abound . what a lovely burst of pineapple and fruit aromas . so very inviting . taste - resin and oily entry , coating the tongue with the expected presence of hops to the max .  taste : mirrors the smell , but the flavors are weaker than their aroma counterparts because of a thin mouthfeel .

a very good porter , poured dark ruby brown color with strong tan head that i impatiently dove into smelling its aroma of chocolate , burnt malt , sweet caramels and hops .  mouthfeel is fullbodied , and slightly cloying .

smells and tastes of molasses , raisins , brown sugar and bourbon soaked oak barrels . very pungent and boozy in the nose and finish as well .  the only thing i felt was it could use a little more carbonation to balance the tart flavor and make it more perky .

pours with a fat thumb head , with decent stout lacing ... smell is amazing , lots of sweet bourbon and chocolate plum ... lots of bourbon upfront but it really is remarkable how enjoyable it is , despite the fact that its like sipping straight bourbon ... this beer would age soooo beautifully ! a wonderful beer that i was honored to have tried at a really fun event , but that open bar kicked my butt in the end ! !  body is on the thin side of medium and the finish is both mildly astringent and slightly bitter .
good head retention thats lasting the entire beer .  mouthfeel : bubbly and light body . the mouthfeel is a little peculiar and affects my experience .
there is a good strong malty and coffee like smell .  the mouthfeel is decent , but could be a bit more robust to support the flavors .

the aroma is of chocolate milk , or maybe the chocolate chips used for cookies .  muted roastiness and chocolate malt notes . deep black body with a decently firm and lasting thumb thick head . roasted coffee beans int he fore followed by toasted and burnt bread and some mild chocolate notes int he finish . finish is dry and coffee tinged great classic porter .

the smell of this brew is grassy with some minor inclusion of earth and peppery notes . a faint note of funky cheese blends with some vinous aspect of white grape skins . fairly decent across the board but on a day like this , it paled in comparison to some of the other geuze offerings sampled .  m - a little strong on the carbonation for my taste .
very promising . and then : the taste is a bit disappointing after that great smell . good , but not exceptional .  mouthfeel - rather bubbly , fairly thin .

bottle pours a beautiful chestnut brown with a rich ruby hue . a small tan head fades to the edge of the glass . very unassuming aroma .  decent palate , a little thin like the others in the series , but fairly smooth .
the nose had a definite saaz quality to it .  it has a pretty high carbonation .
very nice start of a semi-grainy and fully malted pilsner barley . delicious .  im augustus gloop : ) m - carb a little low , a little on the sweet side .

a : very lively , clear , beautiful orange/light amber color , borderline perfect head .  not too many micro 's that come out with a light ale . hats off to them for bringing this to market to allow folks who are used to drinking american mass producted swill to move into a easy drinking michigan micro brew . lighter than sam adams but more flavor then the bud and miller 's of the world .

smell - strong sweet vanilla smell . maybe popcorn , or rather , popcorn flavored jelly bellys . but in a good way . does n't get a perfect score on smell though , cause i 'm not really picking up any pumkin character .  nice flavors , with a nice two-row malty sweetness and a huge piney and slight citrusy hop flavor that is very much in front ; good overall , but very unbalanced , even considering the style . goes down fine , but there is quite a bit of hop scratchiness .

bottle into a pils glass pours a clear , deep copper orange with a one and a half inch off-white head which holds up well throughout from lots of carbonation release . it also leaves some nice looking sheets of lacing down the sides of the glass . ca n't ask for a better looking beer .  m : a bit overcarbonated , dry , thin , light-medium bodied .

: ( looks and smells awesome . dark chocolate color with a small tan head that does n't stick around for too long . this smelled of chocolate before i even managed to get my nose near the glass . smells like hershey 's . i really really wanted to like this beer , but it was tough to get through the bottle and i was sharing it . if only it tasted like it smelled , this would have been great .  it 's sort of smokey but in an artificial way . rubber and alcohol . the rubber turned into a slightly smokey malt flavor but still lingered in there . alcohol dominated any sort of flavors coming through . i just did n't enjoy this beer at all . if i ever cross paths again with this beer i 'll re-review it .

s : chocolaty , coffee , roasted malt , maybe some caramel tones . the appearance and smell had me so excited for the taste , only to be let down by a watery drink .  the mouthfeel is light , but hey , its a light beer ! for drinkability , again , one of the beers that could probably never offend me .

aroma is a terrific perfumey blend of spruce and crushed flowers and an underlying malt sweetness . very inviting . soft malt up front is washed away too quickly by the surprisingly watery mouthfeel .  the palate is bland , sweet , and clean . the strongest aspect of this beer is its mouthfeel , it is medium , sturdy carbonation , very basic but appropriate .

pours to a brilliantly clear pale golden , forming a tall soapy `` pure as the blown snow '' white , with excellent retention and lacing . great looking brew .  mouthfeel is a bit fizzy , and another beer where bottle-conditioning would have a positive impact .

poured a gorgeous amber pink , with a thick white fluffy head . plenty of lacing .  i like a little heavier of a mouthfeel than this offers , but the lighter feel is not surprising considering the crystal appearance .

poured into an imperial pint glass . color was a dark amber with a slight reddish tint to it . head was initially 3 fingers , but dropped down to 1 , and consisted of off white foam , almost like a meringue that clung very well to the sides .  carbonation is fizzy on the tongue where it should be soft and creamy .

the nitro-can produced pour is indeed a sight to behold . beautiful black on bottom with fascinating cascading brown in the middle with a moderately sized tan head on top . the taste was weakly creamy and very thin with very little body .  slightly under carbonated for my taste but not really a flaw .

burnt amber with a fluffy , light tan head of good size and staying power . lots of foamy lace left in the tulip as the head never really dies but eventually falls to a cm or so in height . there 's still some retention before the glass is finished . very nice .  but there are hints of dark fruits that seem to disintegrate on your tongue , slight astringent alcohol tate/smelll this is defiantly a very drinkable brew .

500ml swing top , vintage 2006 a - pours dark brown , nearly black into my snifter . when held up to the light the faintest brown hues shine hrough .  feel seems to be about medium in body , but slightly watery , with a lingering semi-bitter dark unsweetened chocolate/coffee bean aftertaste .

as others may have observed , this is more like `` pumpkin pie ale '' than `` pumpkin ale '' . picture a nut brown ale , with a pumpkin flavor , and the nose of cinnamon & nutmeg and you have this one .  mouthfeel was ok .

the aroma is very enticing ... it 's fruity and easily smelled from afar..thankfully this is not overloaded with cinnamon as was my fear ... instead , there is a rich perfumy sourness of rotting apples , musty basement and faint tobacco . very nice , and not tainted with fusels as i have noted in ron 's prior entries .  feel is a bit coarse , but just a bit .

when i went to smell the aromas , i was very impressed with the assumed banana and clove . they were very prominent and defined ... i couldnt wait to taste ( damn it has a strong aroma that belies its appearance .  perhaps another way to explain the feeling would be a textured shandy . noting the high praise this saison received , i have trouble fathoming such a bad experience .

pours a very appealing ruby red with a tan-ish 2 inch head that leaves some of the best lacing i 've ever seen .  very pleasant indeed . great hop character . this is a fairly balanced ipa . hard to say , it might just be because this particular bottle is more on the room temp side , but i would like more effervescence . a good beer all in all . i will be sure to drink it again , only a little colder and faster . more drinking , less typing ... .

p : crystal clear yellow-orange pour with an intense white foam that came almost over the top of the sam adams glass . foam slowly lowered with huge globs of lacing and a very thick cover .  smell is a cross between musty and estery at first , then just corn . tastes like corn , but considerably worse than a typical macro . it has some off flavors , that i ca n't really identify . bad .
smells very nice . very peppery with spicy yeast , bananas and pineapple .  on the thin side , and i dont get much carbonation .

pours a beautiful burnt sunset orange with crystal clarity , finger of foamy head has good retention .  wonderful flavor , with deep malt tones , a great smokiness , hints of peat , and a touch of caramel . goes down quite smoothly , but it does have an odd , almost generic , flavor on the tongue at the very end .

2009 vintage a- deep violet , crimson red just a beautiful awe-inspiring color and massive towering head that seems to be independent of the beer and an entity all onto itself .  s : slightly citrus , faint banana t : citrus & yeast & candy sugar m : bit thin , but not uncommon for a triple o : i am sure age did this one well reading the prior reviews ... think i paid $ 3.50 for it , well worth the price and a good brown bagger at a tasting .

s - great hoppy but aromatic aroma with a warming malty finish . lovely hops they are using .  it is medium-bodied with soft carbonation and seems perhaps more watery than i 'd expect . it leaves the mouth feeling a bit astringent .

s : holy hops ! strong citrus and pine hop aroma , sweet and fruity , not very bitter smelling . t : follows the nose , tropical fruit and citrus hops dominate , followed by piney flavors . o : this beer gives me a rock-solid .  mouthfeel is somewhere between ultra clean and a little soapy - if that makes sense .

appearance : rich frothy head , close to 3 , hangs around with very sticky lacing .  mouthfeel is a little light for a beer this big , but that would likely improve with age . carbonation is a tad too prickly for my personal tastes .

s - huge pine aroma that is quickly and easily enjoyable . massively beautiful from the get-go , with underlying citrus notes . a perfect , varied aroma that promises wonderful delights within t - slight pine taste , bit of grapefruit , pure hops abound . d - very nice , but perhaps lacking a bit of malt balance making this a bit more difficult to enjoy .  being from the adirondacks i quickly likened this to adirondack brewery 's bear naked ale , yet a lager version , and a bit more wheat-filled . the mouth-feel is nice , but nothing special ( not flat , not too bubbly ) . in short , its a dandy brew- we all enjoyed it and thought it was pretty cool to have something that is only currently available in growlers from the brewery ( spring seasonal ) , drink up !

floral pine caramel . t : at 99 ibu and 6 % i was expecting a hop bomb that was crazy unbalanced but the scottish golden grain holds up against the hops . real bitter and dry mouth with a little astringent flavor d : besides my mouth being super dry and bitter its a great session beer . one of the best ipas ive had considering the flavor of the beer .  it seems to light and over carbonated for a stout .

a : pitch-black , a thick , frothy tan head very slowly settles , on top of lively carbonation . looking very good indeed .  my only complaint is that i wish the mouthfeel was thicker . it was smooth , but a bit watery to me .
upfront the smell has alot of oak and toffee . no alchohol .  the carbonation is mild ; there are almost no bubbles at all .

pours a straw hue , hazed due to the yeast pour . quickly develops a rocky and dense white head which fills the glass , then slowly sinks to leave large , sticky patches of lace .  yack ! i 've had this lots over the years , but this time it got a major problem with butterscotch . aroma smacks me down wth that butterscotch - ugh . but , somewhere in there is some malt and a little chocolate , good malt . flavor is butterscotch - blaaahh . ca n't finish it . draft lines are clean here too . no more , pleeeeze

s - bourbon , bourbon , bourbon , buttery toffee , roasted cashews , malted vanilla milkshake , tiny amount of hops , pecan pie , and harsh booze . this is the best smelling barleywine this nose has ever smelled . perfect . t - harsh and boozy , but delicious . caramelized sugar up front with tons of bourbon .  carbonation is a bit low for the style .
a : orange colour and a huge 4 cm head that sticks around due to the high carbonation .  m - it drys out in the mouth a little too quickly for me .

the nose is very complex , a mix of fruity , spicy , earthy and oaky tones . black licorice or anise also comes to mind . there is also a drying , acrid presence . drinkability of this one is lowered by the fact that i do n't really enjoy this old ale . i was really excited when i opened the bottle and i feel let down .  mouthfeel medium full for the style with carbonation that is a bit too strong for my taste .

smell : strong citrus aroma boasting orange , pineapple and sappy resin . they really knocked it out of the park in the smell , what an inviting and pleasing scent . has west coast written all over it . overall : a pretty impressive brew from cisco brewers .  too cloudy and not nearly enough hop profile . at first i wondered if the waitress had given me the wrong beer . i would have characterized it as a weak summer wheat beer had they not told me it was a plisner . there was nothing objectionable about the beer itself . i drank it all . it just was n't what a pilsner should be .

smell is of bourbon barrels , alcohol and some deep plum and cherry/chocolate on the nose . taste follows with notes of the barrel and a very lingering close ... nice.. good feel and the drinkability is extravagant given the potency , as the alcohol is present on the nose but not on the tongue .  medium carbonation .
smell is of citrusy hops , a bit of malt , and some bitterness .  m- the mouth feel is a bit overly carbonated , yet not thin .
wonderful . just the perfect amount of fruit mixed with the belgian wheat goodness .  mouthfeel is medium with more carbonation that i expected due to no head showing up .
very good smell . t : roasted sweet caramel & malts .  m : thin , do n't take that the wrong way though but easy drinking .

wonderful aroma . really brilliantly done . moderate in strength , but fascinating . t : wonderful apricot fruit esters perfectly complement the wheat foundation .  light to medium bodied , carbonation seems to be at the right level .
s- lots and lots of chocolate here . roasted malts as well .  m : the mouthfeel was a bit thin compared with other sours , although this did not detract from the overall enjoyment of the beer .
s- very wonderful aroma here . very nice hop smells come from this .  the last 2/3 of my beer was a bit thin , but this was quite refresing and very easy to drink .

wow . thick bourbon and aforementioned flavors , mostly caramel . lovely beer , quite exceptional .  m- actually the mouthfeel is n't that bad but it was really hard to focus on that while i was drinking joan rivers perfume .

s - lots of hop presence , a strong floral aroma . unfortunately , there 's a lot of alcohol present too . i wished the hops ' taste was as present as their aroma . last but not least , the alcohol , a strong scotch like taste .  mouthfeel is too thin for my liking .
a- light copper body with a creamy white head that laces and stays to the last drop . d- highly drinkable .  mouthfeel : both the carbonation and body are on the higher end of the light range .

label is shrink wrapped on the can , not printed . bright and glowing copper orange color . plenty of foam , visible trails of rising carbonation . a substantial head that laces well , with a skim that never breaks on the surface .  mouthfeel is okay , no carbonation to speak of .

light-sucking black with a monumental 2.5 finger head of a nice deep tan . great retention and lacing . ca n't ask for a better appearance than this .  mouthfeel - foam is scarce and small bubbles and light caramel that fades quickly . slightly thin .

aroma is huge apricot honey-butter you smell from across the room . amazing . super wowowowow . an incredible rich aroma : great smelling beer . taste is an underlying sweet walnut toffee with apricot honey-butter with a huge fruity citrus hop bitterness that lasts forever .  slightly sour , a bit thin , highly carbonated . quite drinkable .

for the record , fresh - this might be the mightiest tasting ipa out there . smells like mango , citrus , pine needles , pineapple , melon etc . also has a nice sweet malt aroma in the background . lots of piney resin with a pineapple/mango twang . o : overall , a finely crafted ipa . among my favs all-time and easily my top 3 from out west .  mouthfeel is medium-light , and carbonation is medium-light .

a : nearly black in color , a very dark cola color with a thick , foamy cocoa head . great retention and lacing .  average feel for the genre i 'd say . it 's pleasant in sips and gulps and a few of em would be just as enjoyable as one .
appears pitch black with a thick light brown head .  mouthfeel the beer is slick on the tongue with strong carbonation . the body is a little lacking , medium-light .

upon opening the bottle you receive a pleasant aroma and on pouring the smell is obviously even more intense . the mouthfeel is actually kind of weak and bitter , surprisingly , given the pleasant look and smell of this beer .  bought this over a month to two months a go and decided to give it a go . it is an ipa so it does have a nice bright orange to copper color . the taste and the smell are sweet and fruity , the only bad thing i have to to say about it , is the taste of tea is very lacking . i cant pick it up but , other than that i wish that stone , ishii and baird made this more as a yearly offering , cause its really good

a : pours a yellowish orange color , like apple juice with a little fizz ; head is huge and rocky , foamy and thick , like something out of a bubble machine ; yeast sediments sink to the glass bottom upon pour and settling s : everything you 'd expect from a belgian strong ale ( dark or light ) , with complex , sweet dark candied and dark fruit aromas ; however , there is a hint of dry , hoppy citrus and bitterness just underneath the heavy sweetness ; definite booze smell as the beer warms t : the first flavor is alcohol , but not in a sharp , unpleasant way ; it 's there , but tempered with the great and significant sweetness only found in belgian strongs ; great maltiness ; sweetness ranges from tropical fruit flavors to bits of caramel , vanilla , cloves and banana ; m : smooth and heavy up front ; warm , tingly on the tongue ; finishes with a surprising and welcomed touch of dryness that finishes in a refreshing and crisp way ; amazing ! maybe i 'm just an american , but this one 's damn good .  average body and carbonation .

pours black with virtually no light around the edges . towering cap of light brown foam that grew on the pour like one of those ash-growing snake things from a fireworks stand . retention is great , as is the lacing .  it 's got a little bit of a piney finish that 's quite refreshing . maybe closer to watery , but not bad . d- very drinkable esb .

a velvety mouth feel , really enjoyable .  had this today on tap @ hibernia in boston . diacetyl ? in an ipa ? and what 's with the low hop profile and mega-sweetness of this beer ? my pint was quite cloudy too . beer drinkers of the world ... this is not an ipa , and it 's a pretty crappy beer to boot .

s - big fruity hop aromas , primarily citrus notes but a bit of tropical fruitiness mixed in as well . grapefruit and mango both come to mind . orange comes through as well . o - what appeared and smelled like a great ipa didnt quite come through on the taste .  m - it 's a bit thin for the style .

i had this beer tried next to or , poured from a bottle into a pint glass ... a : a pitch black color , very tiny white thin ring of a head , pretty poor looking ... s : smell is awesome . tons of hoppy citric and grapefruit notes , with some sweet honey and vanilla ... t : wow . a bit of a letdown very little hop bitterness and a strong cloyingly sweet flavor with little complexity ... m : smooth , could use more carb ... d : a decent enough beer , but its the worst between either and or !  this beer is not awful but it is not good either . if use to be better , i think , back in the days before aluminum cans and pull up tabs . beer is fizzy and gives a good head and that is about the only good quality it has .

the aroma - mango , pineapple , & exotic flowers - is delightful . smells like hawaii in a bottle ! not as grapefruity as i usually like , but i did n't mind the lack at all ; a very pleasant surprise .  maybe a touch too much carbonation .

smell is boozy , very wine-like , lots of fermented fruit and little bit of sour malt . never-ending , and very complex . taste is very yeasty , a little old , and very thin . overall , very disappointing .  mouthfeel is pretty thin and wine like tbh the beer has more wine qualities than beer , carbonation is also a bit high .
very enjoyable beer . highly quaffable and deliciously decadent .  mouthfeel was medium with a mild lager sweetness accompanied by loads of off flavors , including apples and grapes .
a huge foamy white head sits a proud of a light red brown body with slight hazing and tempting look .  mouthfeel : medium bodied .

right when i opened it the first wiff was a great strong smell of piney hops . outstanding smell . the freshness was still there .  some hop aroma and flavour , a little to light in the body for my liking .

fantastic nose of bananas and wheat . i love it . very malty on the palate .  ran into the maui brewing company while killing time until our dinner reservations were ready . there was a very slight bitterness in the aftertaste but was well hidden in the passion fruit sweetness . found the beer to start like any average golden ale but the aftertaste was what i really liked about it sorta like an ice tea aftertaste .

it really fits the style .  i did notice after a while that it has been pulled from tap that it acquires a lack of a better word , a buttery taste that really dos n't go good with anything . i do like this beer and i 'm not bashing it . the buttery taste in my opinion did not take effect until thirty or so minutes after pour . i do keep some in my fridge . i have shiner before to make burgers with , which turned out great . good beer for beer lovers .
smells rich and sweet with a nice peaty smokiness to it . overall it 's nice .  mouthfeel was a bit thin , but the taste was clean and minty on the tongue .

s : very citrusy and fruity upfront . some sweet pineapple escapes as well . hoppiness is evident .  i could drink this one all night long . just the right amount of sweetness with a little more than expected carbonation . pale yellow in color , lemony aroma.very clean with little aftertaste . easy to drink and very enjoyable . will definately drink again .

the aroma of this beer is amazing ! hops hops and more hops ! very deep and complex . citrus , spice , pine ... but not much of the barley makes it through . wow this is hoppy !  m - very carbonated , to the point that it almost stings on the way down .

s : wonderful fruity belgian goodness . caramel malty dubbel is a smell warms me up even on a hot evening . allagash has some of the nicest smelling belgians that come to mind .  a : solid black , modest lacing even at the beginning , but once the beer was gone so was the lacing s : malty , chicory , lingers nicely t : dominated by coffee ; bitter stout ; the oak comes through nicely ; not very complex m : casked , so it does n't really buzz in the mouth overall , a really good beer , but not as complex as i was hoping ; still , very worthwhile

aroma : lovely , substantial fruit aroma without overpowering the malt of the beer .  it 's almost too sticky and thick to be pleasureable , kind of like a toned-down bourbon county stout . i 'm not a big fan of the finish , which comes off like sweet wort of a stout ( oily and a bit thin ) . m : very thick , with some relief , but then a lingering silkiness .

smells rich and nice . the taste has an earthy hop profile , not as sweet as the nose , very rich and peppery , not as smooth as it could be .  initial taste of a sparkling mouthfeel with a puckering sour cherries that coat the mouth incredabily . the palate duration is average . medium body .

smell : the best part of this beer in my opinion . extremely complex ! i smell the chocolate and coffee but i am also overwhelmed by the super sweet heavenly smell of vanilla . taste : i was so happy that the taste was so refined , understated , elegant and smooth . drinkability : love it love it .  the mouthfeel goes a bit aloof here and has too much carbonation .
aroma is awesome . yeast .  the only knock here is that it was a little thin . m = is it possible to be creamy and watery at the same time ?

perfect looking beer .  have you ever canned tomatoes ? if you have , you should be familiar with the smell and flavor tomatoes have when cooked . this beer had an overwhelmingly strong odor and taste of spicy stewed tomatoes . it was too strong to drink . i know this is not normal for this beer from the other reviews of it i have read ( and the style does n't allow for many strong flavors ) , but it was only days past the best by date and had been stored in a refrigerator . there was also some floating particles in the beer which i also assume is not normal , pilsners typically being filtered . i will come back and rerate , but i 've been told by some fellow raters that i should take this beer into account for my rating .
nutmeg , cinnamon . enjoyed !  m- the mouthfeel is a little lighter than expected , almost watered down .

the aroma is very deep -- anise , fennel , mocha , coffee and a burning alcohol nose -- awesome . really a marvel . strange .  m : lighter body , medium carbonation , somewhat watery thin feel to the body , with a crisp finish .

s - heavy red wine , oak characteristics and obviously a brett brew t - follows the smell , close your eyes and you might be deceived that you are n't drinking a beer almost .  well , so ... if it 's a barleywine or imperial or whatever , well ... then it 's probably thin on the mouth , eh ?

the smell of this thing is very lively , wow , its all over the place , funky as hell , smokey banana and smoked salmon or bacon , dull lemon , musty horse blanket , soft rubber , and feet .  this beer has a fairly heavy body , a bit too much for my tastes .

the smell is quite pungent . i can smell the glass from a foot away ! sweet caramel malts are picked up in the nose , but are nothing in comparision to the huge hops assault . it is very hop foward ( understatement ) . this is easily one of the most unique and bitter beers i have ever had . the hops oils make it quite slippery and oily going down .  mouthfeel was moderate , not super heavy or light .

the aroma is very nice . taste - the taste is all strawberries as predicted .  it looks like a pale ale should , there 's some yeast on the bottom of the bottle and the head stays for a bit . i 'd rather have a bit more malt presence , it 's just too hoppy and bitter for me . drinkability , if i had to choose between this and a macro , i 'd take this . edit on 10-3-04 i 've raised my review score , since i 've either started loving the hop , my tastes have changed or the fact that this is one of the few decent beers you can get around here on a night out and i 've become more accoustomed to it .

goose island 312 urban wheat poured clear , straw yellow in color topped by a fluffy white head . 312 is a great looking beer .  the mouthfeel is slightly buttery but leans more towars a syrup-like feel . carbonation would be greatly appreciated and add a very unique feel for this beer .
pours a dark brown with an excellent light tan head that billows and floats for minutes .  m : fine , nothing special d : probably too sweet for a lot of people , but i 'm a fan .

as it warmed i started to swirl it and got a lot of booze in there too , which really added a nice touch . a lot of really good stuff going on here , but i find that with most iipa 's that , if they are using a huge amount of hops , they tend to smell better than they taste .  a : dark reddish copper ; flat head ; strong carb ; not much lacing s : strong raspberry aroma , very inviting ; occludes other smells t : expected sweet -- it is n't ; the raspberry dominates , but it 's quite sour , draped over a wheat-beer-like base ; i must confess , this tasted terrible to me ; it tasted like nothing else i 've had , so i do n't think this is something against the genre m : good carbonation redeems the experience a bit overall , a terrible beer , for me .

pours out to a clear copper color , forming a modest whipped yellow head with excellent retention and solid sheets of lacing . this is how i like my pale ales to look . beautiful !  m - pretty watery and thin .

pours a nice dark toasty color but not so dark when heald to the light . red comes through if you hold it up to dome light .  mouthfeel is a bit of a letdown.. crisp but not as crisp as i had hoped . overall drinkability is good , the taste makes up for what it lacks in mouthfeel .
pleasant overall unlike some other fruit beers .  the beer feels just a bit thin on the tongue .

huge waves of vinegar and tartness on the front followed by a very sweet cocoa character on the finish . very interesting . t : like the nose , the sour character of this beer makes a huge appearance .  mf : a bit thin , light body , medium to high carbonation d : another winner from sierra nevada .
pours a nice bubbly clear gold under a 1.5 finger what head with very nice contour and retention , and outstanding lace . really looks nice .  mouthfeel is just a tad watery .

i 'm really enjoy the sweet fruits and big malts in the aroma , red grapes , sour dates , soft and tangy with chocolate malt and a dry-sour yeast aroma that is really nice . mild heat at the end .  slightly thin ( but not watery ) on the mouthfeel , which turned me off initially , until i could appreciate all that was going on in this beer .
black color , pitch black .  mouthfeel was very thin for the style , but added to the higher level of drinkability .

smell : great aromas of licorice and chocolate . overall , the beer is a bit rough around the edges , perhaps from importation , but that is certainly part of its charm .  m- medium body with medium carbonation . a bit to high carbonation for this brew but still has a light creaminess to it . nice blend of flavors just mouthfeel is lacking a bit imo . also the head could of been a lot better especially due to how much carbonation .

served cold , poured into a pint glass , it has a great amber red color with excellent clarity . the creamy head sticks around a good long time but slowly settles leaving a sheet of lacing on the glass .  the mouthfeel was a little on the watery side but i did n't feel like it ruined the experience .
has my favorite froth for this style , thick and sticky , goes nowhere fast and the color looks bread .  m -- light carbonation . good body with a lightly soft mouthfeel .

the aroma is full on citrus hops . love it . the flavor is much more balanced than the nose . the citrus blast is there but the malt `` grinds '' away at it . overall another great beer from surly .  kind of leaves your mouth feeling very acidic .

nose is amazing ... sour cherry , earthy soil , fruit leathers , saddle leather , cranberry , pomegranate , craisins , dark chocolate ... i mean this nose goes on and on and on ! then saddle leather , peach pit , cranberry ( big time ) , raisins , dried black figs , dried berries , fresh black berries and on and on and on ... the best avery sour i 've had , and one of the best sours i 've had produced in north america ! awesome .  mouthfeel - medium body with a very active carbonation .
lacing is n't quite as impressive as the head retention , but a great looking beer .  first sip reveals a much thinner body than i expected and average carbonation .

average lacing & head retention s : coffee & a bit of chocolate , grows stronger as this warms t : coffee grounds , black patent malt , a bit of mocha & herbal hops up front .  m : medium body ( maybe a little light for a stout ? moderate carbonation ( more than expected in a stout ? ) . mildly dry in the finish .

the smell is great , very fresh , yeasty , sweet and fruity . some dry straw , scattered by the wind , some strawberry , some peaches , some plums . after these heavenly aromas , the taste appeared surprizing and a bit disappointing . almost like an eku maybe ... deeply chocolaty , but with an annoying alcoholic character . after tasting the beer , even the smell gets less interesting .  mouthfeel : the carbonation seems oddly low , but the body is medium light which gives the beer a little bit of oomph that it needs .

excellent . t- sharp hop bitterness with a floral blanket overall . slightly sticky d- smooth , smells great and tasts great .  m - this is where the beer ranks fairly average for me . under carbonated and a little bit flat , would have liked it to be heavier , stickier , and have more of a bite .

a dark body that exhibits a reddish tinge when held up to the light , with thick lacing spiraling down the side .  a beautiful creamy white head rests on top of a medium body . appearance is a transparent mild orange with a light brown hue . carbonation appears heavy but on first sip is found to be more moderate than apparant . heavy lace is left a head that never seems to go away . aroma is floral , clean , and crisp . flavor is hoppy and slightly bitter . toffee like flavor is prevelant in its aftertaste .

a - wow , the gentlest of pours brings forth a beautiful ( slightly clouded due to my misjudgment ) light orange brew with the most ridiculous pillowy head i have ever seen , four fingers to start , sticks around for what seems like forever , and leaves great lacing s - pear and apple , along with a little cut grass , lemon zest , lots of yeast , clove and pepper t - smooth maltiness , slightly tart , with a lot of green apple , a little fresh hay , some yeasty goodness .  it was a little thin .
really loved the nose .  m- a little thin , but not too bad . nicely carbonated , with a slight bitter hoppiness at the tail end .
nose presents juicy flavors of dried mango and apricot with a bit of citrus and rosewater .  mouthfeel : it feels like an astringent hop bitterness , but i sure as heck ca n't taste any hops .
smell : the aroma is full of brandy . nice red grape , molasses , caramel , smooth malt notes .  m : light body , watery touch , smooth with low carbonated in the mouth .
a fantastic malty aroma , scents of autumn air , sweet and with just a touch of hops .  the body is light but somewhat creamy .

s : full bourbon whiskey smell as i find out of all the bruery 's barrel aged stuff . nice vanilla as well .  m- smooth , but a tad thin . carbonation is good , as is the thoroughly smooth finish with a tad of warmth .
appearance : great stout , dark brown color with a coffee colored head .  carbonation was fairly low , with thin to medium body .

it smelled of the mediterranean sea and beautiful , long-legged , not to be fucked with , italian women with sensuous lips . a very sweet , lemony ipa that is excellent for what it is , and enjoyable , for a time .  4/5 m : surprisingly thin side of medium , slightly tongue numbing , spritzy .

the aroma was strong with amarillo hop presence .  taste some roasted chocolate flavors . flavor lingers on the tongue after each sip . not quite what i would consider a savoring beer , but tasty none the less . i could drink this beer around the fire in the winter or after raking leaves in the fall .
i can also catch a slight nose of peaty scotch if i catch it the right way . fantastic aroma here .  the mouthfeel is a little thin , very dry , but well carbonated .
i am intrigued . t. malty and a bit sweet , borders on sour .  m : pretty light-bodied . i was expecting something more viscous .

appearance - perfect ! black with brown 2 finger head tiny bubbles smell - very pleasant as one would expect..malty , chocolatey , caramel and a very slight smokeness taste - very balanced as usual from a uk brewer .  m - medium body , not a lot of carbonation .

exceptional head and lace . big , rough , chunky , substantial lace . impressive to look at and earns full points on that count .  a malty mouthful without much carbonation . resiny flavors fill the mouth but do n't obscure the big malt . this one is quite drinkable with an interesting mix of flavors that rise out of the basic malty sweetness .

appearance : good frothing and great head retention , the pale amber hue shows an active carbonation and a brilliant clarity .  the carbonation is moderate high . i think it is a bit high for the style but the carbonation does not take anything away from the beer .

huge tan creamy head on top of a super black viscous liquid .  mouthfeel : high carbonation gives the impression of a thinner mouthfeel , and the carbonic acid and alcohol bite knock this one down a little in the mouthfeel rating .
very pleasant complexity that is worth lingering over .  light feel with lots of carbonation .
insanely sticky , a spectacular pour .  the mouthfeel has average carbonation and ismedium bodied yet feels a bit thin at the same time , as it falls off the toungue quite quickly .

but honestly , the more i smelled it , it truly just smelled like banana bread . smells fantastic and tastes ok . i ca n't imagine buying it again .  m : the only thing that let me down was the thin and carbonated mouthfeel .

drinking it in a pint glass poured from a 12 oz bottle ... huge , thick head . awesome . beer is opaque and black .  the body is is a serious letdown , nowhere near rich/full enough and it crosses the line into watery . the carbonation is appropriately subdued , and does n't overtake the lackluster body .

appearance - jet black in color with a very nice one finger light tan head that lingers while drinking . perfect for keeping in the flavor and smell of the beer smell - very light on the malt smell , but somewhat heavy on the bitter hops .  thanks walter a-a nice rich amber , good head , some lacing that turned into a small bubble ring s-a slight bready smell , some citrus ( makes me think of citra hop ) slight sweetness and then tart t- close to the same as the smell , there is a slight tangyness in the middle of the drink , it 's a good thing m- it 's moderately lively not as much bite and tingle i was expecting , a clean wet finish o/d- overall i really like this , it 's not the craziest ipa but it 's more than just decent , drinkability , i can see myself finishing this growler , this is a tasty beer and one i really like

the ale smelled of flowers , honey and orange peel . this would be an outstanding lawnmower beer .  m : i feel that this could have used a little more body and less carbonation , but overall ... not bad .
very heady pour . nice lacing .  m : earthy with a little grapefruit at the begining and a little pine at the finish . light carbonation .

from a bottle , chilled , it pours a pale gold color with some haze , along with 1cm of white bubbly head that sustains nicely .  i know some ba 's knock this onw because its not rare or amazing but i love it . if i am in a bar that i do n't think has a lot to choose from sam adams is the first word out of my mouth . its not too expensive and tastes good for what you pay .

it pours a rust-colored brown with a roasted 2-3 finger head . this looks as good as any of the big ipas made by stone , smuttynose and company .  the carbonation and the color were good , but this did n't make up for the off taste and smell .

really smells nice . the taste mimicks the nose ... .nice balance between the cloves and banana notes ... also some subtle but enjoyable caramel maltiness .  body is light and a bit watery , not too syruppy at all .
pours an opaque darkness with a huge stiff dark brown head that decomposes like an ice cream sundae , massive 3d lacing present .  mouthfeel was week and its not complex at all .

i noticed a nice hop bouquet on the nose which suggests it was dry-hopped . maybe it was n't , perhaps just really fresh as the beer had a born on date suggesting the beer was less than two weeks old .  it 's light on body , and not especially interesting - but as fruit beers go , this was excellent .

t : after the aroma onslaught , the hoppiness on the palette is rather subdued . still nicely bitter , with a good pine , grapefruit , bitter orange flavor . d : the aroma is a bit of a tease , but the taste does n't entirely disappoint - certainly a beer i could have again .  ambrosial start , lots of malt , the top skimpy in feel with the finish having a delightful hop spicy bite , the carbonation moderate and the aftertaste droughty and long lasting .

notes from 6/16/10 pours jet black with a lovely tan brown head crowning the top . the head lingers and sticks to the glass creating lacing art on the sides of the glass . this is one of the better dark beers i 've seen come out of a bottle .  the body is pretty light though and clean .
a wonderful sweet , almost fruity smell after opening the bottle .  ( m ) - this is where the beer starts to fail in my opinion .

at first , the nose was lots of tart apple and/or pears . after the drink sat for a bit the nose became mostly bananas and vanilla .  mouth : such a light and watery mouthfeel that it becomes distracting pondering the feel when you should be appreciating the tastes . drink : the nearly too-light mouthfeel is redeemed by the drinkability of this brew .
very complex the joys of the smell were almost problems with the taste .  light bodied d- in moderation , this beer is perfect for a 2 beer session .

a : russet or ruby hued , with great clarity ; the beige beer head comes thick and tightly frothy ... remaining 1cm thick throughout the drink . overall the taste fights against the tide with its thin-ish body and without sufficient hop support , while the lack of fizz makes it slightly too flat on the palate .  had a typical pilsner mouthfeel .

poured in my struise glass the beer looks very nice , dark with a creamy head . it 's a pity that the head disappears after a while .  feel left me a bit disappointed , however , as it was thin -- too thin for this big of flavor .

amazing . taste almost supports the smell but not to the degree i 'd hoped . if this veered away from the spicy sweetness it offers in the mouth toward the cherry vagueness of the smell i could see this being an absolutely impeccable ale .  m : medium-full bodied , zero carbonation , silky . d : lacks the warming feeling that is usually related to a winter warmer .

heat is starting to mellow with a year on it , and the fruity development of the nose compliments the flavor beautifully . freshness indicated that this beer needs some time , and boy was i right .  m : thin to medium viscosity , wet and distractingly acidic at times on the palate , with moderate carbonation .

a dark orange color beer that is very cloudy with a long lasting bubbly head . quite a citrus filled aroma with some cinnamon mixed in and some ginger .  the body is lighter than i expected , and the taste is a little more burnt than i would 've preferred .

aroma is `` off the chain , '' as the kiddies say nowadays . rather than compete and muddle all these scents meld into a unified aroma of awesome . perfect .  a medium to full body . possibly a little too thick ( syrupy was mentioned earlier by easyr which sums it up well ) as it took me a while to make headway down the glass ( unusual for me ) .

my first 5 for appearance , and it 's well deserved .  hate to say it , but the bottle/case i have is absolutely awful . other than a hint of coriander spice all i got was an overwelming sourness that made this one of the few i had to pour down the drain . they obviously put wayyy too much orange peel in their mix . if you can get past the sourness it is par for a wit bier course . i 'm hoping this was a bad/expired batch because ... .as far as mill street goes imo , stick to the coffee porter ...

quite nice overall . taste : bit of a letdown here ; there are mild caramel and nutty flavors , but not much depth ... there 's a bit of biscuit on the finish and it 's kind of acidic , almost tart actually , and some mildly fruity flavor that i ca n't quite place and is mildly annoying .  the taste is very good , it could use a bit more body but the flavors are great . tons of chocolate and roastiness dominate the profile but there is also some caramel and hops . the bitterness is at a great level in comparison to the sweetness , especially for the style . the guy below me has it right : not quite edmund fitz or blake butte but this one is one of the supeb examples of the style .
aroma is whoa grapefruit ! nice brew , maybe a bit over the top , but for an anniversary brew , you do what you have to .  great big head , perfectly tempting aroma , somewhat thin mouthfeel .

the aroma is very nice , a heady mixture of malt , honey and alcohol . unfortunately the flavor does n't come close to fulfilling the promise in the aroma . the body is carbonated with a rather lager-ish character .  m - not much fizz , easy drinking if you like it .

one thing of note on this beer is its beautiful appearence , dark caramel coloring , and nice thick head .  the mouthfeel has a little bit more carbonation than i would like a brew of this calibre to have , thus the 3.0 .

12oz bottle to pint glass a : very creamy brown with a puffy tan head that has decent retention and some lacing . i think the look of guinness is my favorite ... does n't get much better .  a tad thin .

aroma is mostly complex stages of hops , it 's easy to believe there are 10 varieties , there 's the big american c hops character combined with the refined english ones . very relaxing to sniff on and ultra-complex , like a touch of vanilla on fresh citrus ( grapefruit ) . in mouth this dances on the tongue , nice effervescence , creamy , full-bodied , complex malt sweetness and an obvious balancing yeastiness . this is a delicious big generous beer . tasting this with my buddy martint , we came to the conclusion that given the choice to pick only 2 beers from a same brewery to have an infinite supply of , hotd with fred and adam would probably win over quite anyone .  mouthfeel is pretty good , but a little on the watery side for a chocolate/dessert beer . with the abv at 6 % and the body a little thinner than other chocolate stouts , one could have a couple of these in one night .

a : pours a golden amber color with light copper edges against the light . has a frothy off-white head that retains pretty well at a fingers ' thickness , and deposits nice lacing down the glass .  m : a little thin in body d : good .
s - smell is terrific and pops way more than a lot of nitro beers i 've had .  as for the go-down : thin & lightly carbonated , not aggressive but not annoying either & no aftertaste .

smells exactly like strawberry jam with a very subtle hint of tartness .  i wont go through the details but if you are looking for an ipa do not drink this beer . it may sound novel , but black ipa is a retarded name for this , its not an ipa whatsoever . no hop flavor in the taste , not even close . im pissed i paid 4.30 for this . ridiculous .

a- pours a light hazed golden yellow color . two finger white head shows medium retention . long webs of lace are all over my glass .  m - medium/light body with little carbonation good with spicy food .
smell : oh baby can you say citrus hop bomb ? loads of grapefruit and a touch of lemon .  very dry with a bitter finish . a little sticky from all the sweetness .

the aroma was amazing , especially for a beer of such humble stature . chocolatey rich to the extreme . steaming hot fudge instantly came to mind . sweet and creamy with strong notes of vanilla and a touch of oak . dark chocolate came through strong up front . black coffee was noticeable in the center . this was a smooth and tasty beer with an aroma that was to die for . at 5.7 % abv , this porter was surprisingly drinkable .  maybe a little bit of caramel malts to balance out that chocolate . the body is ok - seems quite normal for what you can buy - but i 'd just like it a bit heavier . ) they could increase the body a little , maybe go heavier on the caramel malts and add a few more bittering hops .

almost black with a cream colored head measuring maybe one finger . i love pouring it out of the gan into a pint glass and watching it mix and cascade turning from the color of mud to the color of .  now i understand the meaning of the word `` swill '' . i have an enormous amount of respect for european beers . avoid . trust me .

well there is no way i can fault the look of this ale..its perfect for style darkest of black with a huge frothy light brown head..beeee-u-tiful .  the beer really lacks in body . carbonation is great . overall this was a good beer but the body creates a void .

the smell on this one is incredible , and leaves little to be desired . a lot of chocolate hits the nostrils as well as bitter espresso . this is by far the best porter i have ever smelled , thus far . the taste is not quite up to par here .  mouthfeel : medium-bodied with moderate carbonation .
a - moderately vigorous pour yields an over the top , dense , styrofoam khaki-colored head . decent sticky legs , too . impressive !  mouthfeel is fairly thin but not unpleasant .
dark brown with good clarity , this beer has a dense , light brown head with excellent retention and lacing .  i found the body to be a bit thin carbonation medium to low .

its smell is its best characteristic -- floral hops , malty , a hint of wheat -- really beautiful . the taste is sweety & malty , as well as bitter .  ( m ) smooth , oily , and flat . it 's a solid beer , or a solid base of a beer that could be improved only with a better mouthfeel .

s- big nose , this is got it all for a west coast ipa , grapefruit , pine , and light citrus notes . this is sort of sweet smelling , but not from the malt . o- this is the last i had from the hop box .  the huge head tipped me off and my first taste confirmed that this beer was infected . as a homebrewer , i 'm sure to sample every beer i brew before i give it to a friend . a little qc goes a long way .

smells of extremely fresh raspberries . seriously , about as real as it gets with the fruit scent and something many others ca n't accomplish . still , about good for drinkability to me . the tartness and somehow a tad too much malt make this less drinkable than it should be .  m : the feel is slightly creamy but on the lighter side of medium bodied . could be a bit thicker here ... d : if you like coffee beers i could see someone drinking good amount of these .

a - dark as night with a tall creamy dark tan head .  the aroma was quite pleasant ... cirtus and floral hops with a light , bready malt . strong citrus hops up front , but it quickly became bitter , finished bitter and left a strong aftertaste . this is the first beer i 've poured out in a long time .

the aroma is so spot-on for the style that it makes me wonder how skull coast did it ... how do you get that much non-artificial-smelling watermelon aroma into a beer ? just exceptional , with juicy , fruity 'melon notes backed by a hint of wheat and hops .  i found that the beer smelled and tasted rather skunky , unlike most other beers that i had tasted and was deeply disappointed by it . it felt ok in the mouth and looked very nice in its green bottle but was not worth my time .

appearance : beautiful translucent orangish copper with a thin white head . the head dissipates quickly leaving behind a white glass ring . good lacing .  m : full bodied but way too over-carbonated .
