looks great , nice head , not too much lacing ... just like a stout should .  the mouthfeel is the most appealing part of this brew , unfortunately i just ca n't escape the sour flavour .

pours brown with ruby hints . there are two healthy fingers of head ( boy , is this a live beer ) and the retention and lacing are top notch .  mouthfeel is light body , medium carbonation . fairly nice .

produces a huge , thick and creamy head with superb retention throughout the entire glass . just a beautiful looking beer .  golden in color , slight haze ( nothing wrong with that ) , definite aromas of honey sweetness . lingering sweetness in the palate with a slight funk . interesting beer and something that one might only need to consume once .

on tap at strange brew in manchester , nh 2/2/11 a : light yellow , almost hay colored , hazy . 1 1/2 inch fluffy white head , leaves tons of lacing , almost completely covering the glass .  velvety . good amount of carbonation .
a : dark black , thick brown head that dissipates slowly .  mouthfeel is nice and thick and well carbonated . the best part of the beer .

a - pours jet black with a towering tan head , which stubbornly refuses to drop for several minutes . when it finally falls to a rocky couple of inches large clumps of lacing are left behind .  the mouth is thick and malty . as far as drinkability , i have to say that i would be really happy to have one of these if i was alive 4000 years ago but for now i 'm going to have to go for something else .

smell : very fresh citrus immediately hits the nose smelling of fresh lemons and orange zest . absolutely inviting . taste : the taste was not as vibrant as the nose , but it was still a nice blend of wheat , citrus ( especially lemon ) , and yeast . again , nothing too impressive -- about average for a wheat beer in my book .  m : medium-light body ; moderate carbonation ; smooth and clean mouthfeel .
it poured a beautiful dark amber into my glass . it poured very dense , almost like syrup , which is very inviting .  meidum bodied and relatively smooth .
great looking beer !  mouthfeel is light and refreshing making the beer overall a decent session beer .

a : pours opaque jet black with a formidable tan head -- nice retention .  smooth with a creamy but dry finish . i walked away thinking that the `` smoked vanilla , coffee , and birch '' was meant to be flavor descriptors rather than actual ingrediants . all of these elemtns were way too weak to be appreciated for what other beers can do with them . call it a single , nix the mention of the adjuncts , and this beer would be alright .

my first `` imperial pilsner '' a- a very clear rich golden , maybe slight orange . well formed fluffy white head builds on top , a thin layer sticks around .  really nice body all around ... overall - i would really enjoy this beer if it were n't for the bubblegum flavor , it 's really off putting and not very pleasant .
) aromas are in the background and define it with a rugged , backcountry character .  mouthfeel is fairly creamy , with a lighter , dry body .

a : this is a very beautiful looking beer . the head is absolutely amazing , with perfect color and form . the color is a very dark brown or black , depending on how much light is on it .  mouthfeel- medium mouthfeel ( for the style ) . carbonation level was perfect for bringing out the bittering hops .

quite close to black with a fine textured tan head . i love the way the beer horizon ( the separation between the beer and the head ) looks . it stayed that way throughout the beer .  m & d : very good , sits well and fairly easy to drink once you get the first one down
a - clear ruby brown with a thick white head that has excellent retention and fairly decent lacing .  m - oily , medium body with a fantastic amount of carbonation .
a : pale straw , great carbonation , crystal clear , and a lovely full head .  the feel was pleasantly smooth , but was unimpressed with the drinkability as seemed to reform a head with every drink .

really good stuff .  the flavor that by far took the lead was chocolate ! there 's an overpowering ( and for me , disappointing ) chocolate aftertaste in this beer . mouthfeel- smooth , no complaints here . drinkability- well , the bottle looks cool as you drink from it !

750 ml bottle cage & cork & gt ; chimay gob deep , dark amber color , red hues with a blissful carbonation with a two-finger deep head at first , solid white , thick and dense and lots of life , the retention is as good , if not better than any i 've seen . amazing look .  taste : slick and creamy mouth feel with a sharp biting carbonation , malt sweetness almost goes over the top .
this beer poured a black body with a thick dark tan/black head . a beautiful sight to see .  mouthfeel is medium-light bodied , a nice creaminess to the carbonation .

the beer poured into the glass a brilliant clear gold with a thick , dense white head , te head retained well , and when it did recede it left a chunky lace on the side of the glass . a stream of champagne bubbles rise from the bottom , a testament to the carbonation of the bottle conditioned beer .  m : creamy and nice . decent carbonation keeps it from sticking to you .
pours a amber ale color with a super looking coffee colored head with tight tiny bubbles that also remits some great lacing .  feel is good - light , crisp , medium bodied .
appearence : pours an incrdedibly clear light orange with a huge , creamy , frothy , mountainous white head that stays forever .  has a nice medium to full body with light carbonation .

poured into a tall glass , pours a cloudy almost two tone fire red color . genuinely impressive , that i have never seen something like this before .  but it does n't make me puke ( and it tastes better than bmc by a sconch ) mouthfeel is nice . kinda creamy mixed with crisp .

looks like a cappuccino with a marshmallow melting into it . leaves amusing puddles of lace behind and seems murky and cloudy . exquisite - a marvel to behold .  m : medium body and very good amount of carbonation in my opinion .
poured a dark hazy brown , tan head , with good retention .  mouthfeel is light bodied with good carbonation .
what a crazy story ... a - a tall pour creates totally huge cascading that ends in a three+ finger head with awesome retention .  full bodied with a smoothy , creamy mouthfeel .

growler the bruery placentia , ca a clear light golden with a big and thick foaming white head . the head sticks around for quite a while and eventually leaves thick and sticky lacing all down the glass .  m : a nice , medium body .

pours a rich golden orange , excellent clarity , good carbonation , topped by a level one finger slab of snow white foam .  m- really good carbonation , low abv and the nearly great sweet/tart balance make it actually react quite nicely with the mouth .

appearance : as poured the beer is a nice lightly hazed golden apricot color with a 1 fluffy off white head that leaves rings , legs and small patches of lacing as it recedes .  mouthfeel is medium , carbonation average-high with some pleasant warming feel .
hazy/cloudy straw yellow coloe . great lacing .  m - good . a little sticky .

appearance : wow . gahhh . it settles in the glass with a creamy brownish white head that persists for ages and carbonation swirling around in the most beautiful pattern , as if this beer was alive . once that settles , a deep , dark brown colour takes over that is almost opaque , save for around the sides . head is small but very creamy and stays around forever . mouthfeel : kinda bad ... this beer puts so much effort into looking beautiful that it loses all of its carbonation .  mouthfeel : nice feeling on the tongue and also a good consistencty .

a solid five fingers tall , the head falls slowly , leaving behind a cragy , mountainous blanket over top of the glass with massive amounts of lacing . best looking head i 've ever seen .  the mouthfeel is fine . it is a low/medium bodied beer with good carbonation .
incredible looking esb . pours with the cascading effect and settles to a bright amber color .  m - good mouth feel . somewhat unique in feel .

s & # 8211 ; phenomenal smell . smoky , with pumpernickel , and spicy herbal hops . interesting flavors emanate from the aromatic elements in the nose , but they range between subdued to very subdued tones of them .  mouthfeel is spot on for the style , light and crisp and a bit dry .
a nice dark red/amber color with about 1.5 finger head of off-white creamy head . the head stuck around for about 3/4 of the brew and left some nice lace .  m - pretty good .
stunning and promising . t : a let down given the performance of the nose .  the mouth is smooth and light .

it has fantastic light floral hop aromas . the alcohol content is n't particularly high and their are some superior apas around .  m : medium-bodied with low and sightly creamy carbonation . there is a slight sticky feel and syrupy feel .
big aroma of alcohol and vinous fruit , almost christmas pudding-like .  decent carbonation , neither too intrusive nor too laid back .
pours a beautiful deep red ( more red than amber ) with two fingers of soft light brown head . leaves a ton of lacing behind .  crisp , good body overall .

makes a nice , thick head with staying power . deep , dark brown color with a lighter ( and nicely creamy ) brown head .  smooth in the mouth with nice , crisp carbonation . nice feel , but flavor is not there .
appearance very cool bottle art . beer is a deep rich mahogany brown .  m- decent carbonation , light and airy .

really nice looking brew , deep copper colored body with a creamy cap of head that lasts forever.very little aroma with only the slightest hint of spicy hop .  the mouthfeel is very smooth , with fine/sharp bubbles .
pours with a light two , five-finger head that stays forever , leaving a good lace .  mouthfeel is quite decent .

lacing is phenomenal , it sticks around the whole time , leaving great looking webbing on the glass .  hoping it 's one of those better in a bottle beers i 'm returning to give it another try . so far so good . maybe , and i 'm stretching , some neutral hop spice . this beer makes me try too hard . these hops should be hops should be ashamed of themselves . good malt base to support hops , were they present . bottle is equally bland as on tap .

smells wonderful ! t - flavor is a bit subdued , really disappointing after such an amazing nose . more tart cherry , with flavors of brown sugar , vinegar , tobacco , and high quantities of oak .  m : medium body and moderate carbonation .

a : pours a beautiful hazy orange colour . huge fluffy , rocky white head . lots of retention and lace .  mouthfeel is smooth , for sure , with mellowed out carbonation and a surprising absence of slickness , considering the alcohol .

man what nice looking beer poured a brilliant yellow with huge rocky head , watching it come down right now , smell was yeasty and slightly fruity.the taste started out a little yeasty with some slight fruity notes ending mineral like.nice complex ale even better than what i thought it would be .  decently carbonated mouthfeel , and medium-bodied .

app : nice copper color , tight white head smell : minimal hop aroma . some malt notes taste : med body , nice carbonation ... just boring to drink mouthfeel : nothing new or different than other sn beers drink : average ... good , but there are other beers i would go to first 2008 version a : nice copper color with tight bubbles and a good foamy head .  full bodied , moderate carbonation .

appearance - slightly hazed yellow/straw . puts a good finger and a half of white foam on the glass . a nice ring of lace frosting at the high water mark .  surprisingly , the sediment was n't hard and i did n't feel a corporeal presence in my mouth . coopers best extra stout was nice on the palate ; softly carbonated and creamy . to tell you the truth , i was a bit disappointed .
s : sweet dark frut nose come out followed by a chocolate toasted malt . on second whiff i am reminded of chocolate covered cheries .  the mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with smooth carbonation .

it is deep , dark and mysterious -- perhaps much like the ellusive rasputin himself . it mixes roasted coffee aromas , with the sweeter remnants of chocolate , caramel and toffee . there is also a nice , bold noticeable tinge of hops to the overall inhalation . in the mouth , this beer is amazingly bold and full . there is also a nice biting aftertaste , allowing its overall substance to be reckoned with .  m : very fizzy , light on body , about right for the style .

black in hue , opaque , it was served with about a fingers worth of beige head , which was surprisingly frothy . subsequent lacing was very prominent , bubbly lace dominated the walls of the glass . the appearance of this beer is near perfect .  orange , darkish color , looks a lot like the two previous hop project beers i had . the flavor also left a lot to be desired . the last hop project beers i had were both quite intriguing and sadly this was just boring as far as the hops were concerned . oh , well , hopefully i get to try more of this crazy series .

pours a very dark brown , black in the glass , with a nice tan head that maintains down the glass . excellent rings of lacing .  m - good mouthfeel . a little heavier thanks to the lack of filtration .
aroma is amazing - brandy , caramel , brown sugar , dark fruits , vanilla , and oak . bummer i 'll probably never have it again , as rare as it is .  this is a medium bodied , well carbonated beer .
very dark brown with garnet highlights and a giant , fluffy , dark tan cap .  mouthfeel is full with tiny carbonation and a faint alcohol burn as you swallow .

poured into a de molen sniffer . smell : great nose , full of dark chocolate , slight sour cherry , bourbon and vanilla taste : great taste as well , this beer is very complex and still very balanced . the smell and taste are wonderful , for me it seems an attempt of the molen to produce their own cuvee delphine from struise .  the mouthfeel is slightly creamy and very enjoyable . this drinks nicely . there is a lot going for this though , the mouthfeel in particular .
the appearance is very nice , with a large fluffy tan head and a body that looks very dark brown until held up to the light where it appears a clear dark ruby red .  mouthfeel is pretty good .
pours a cloudy yellow/gold color , with a huge thick fluffy white head . a good deal of carbonation helped this head hold for what seemed like an eternity .  medium mouthfeel .

the nose is nice . very nice . the nose just teases me with anticipation that the flavor never delivers .  this brew reminds me very much of delirium , and is still a taste that i can not seem to thoroughly enjoy . very malty , and the alcohol is quite present with some mild chocolate and serious bitterness . very strong warming effect as well , which is enjoyable and will be one of the few things that helps me finish this brew off . as far as my beer palate is concerned , this type of ale is one of the few obstacles i have left to conquer .

an agressive pour was neither necessary nor desired to result in a glass 1/3 full of beer and 2/3 dense , off-white foam . robust carbonation , with many small bubbles .  m- good mouthfeel , just the right carbonation .
i enjoy just about everything this beer has to offer .  mouthfeel - some good body , oily smoothness per the style . carbonation is moderate .

pours a deep chestnut brown , with a layer of foamy white goodness on top . laces amazingly . the more beers i try from this brewery the more i realize they sure know how to make a beer look good .  long , earthy , dry finish . interesting , somewhat unusual brew .

a : black with a huge tan head , great retention & lace .  i 'm thinking of a breakfast bed . the beer was thick and the foam was velvety . the drinkitbility was okay for its thickness . however , the taste was terrible . a quick slam of semi-sweet citrus that is too heavy on the lemon . the beer ends with an unbalanced bitterness for more than half of the drink .
this is a delicious looking beer ! dark with a creamy , full head .  m - effervescent with a full body and a very yeasty finish .
dissipates slowly and exhibits great retention with beautiful lacing .  m- mouthfeel is nice . medium body with a good amount of carbonation .
) pitch black colour , moderate brown head . the appearance is top notch , a very fine and lasting brown head .  mouth feel is completely crisp , refreshing , and clean .

bottle poured into a tulip glass . appearance-medium to deep gold , quite clear , moderate off-white head with moderate retention .  body is right- light , lively carbonation , not cloying or excessively dry .
a nice hoppy aroma .  the mouth feel was very nice however i really struggled to drink the whole bottle .

a : clear copper , fluffy white head , good retention and lace .  body was medium , and the liquid was fairly smooth overall . 3.03 rdev -19.5 % look : 3.5 | smell : 3 | taste : 3 | feel : 4 | overall : 2.5 1366

perfect appearence for an ipa , with a strong , full foaming head that lasts .  soft prickly carbonation does cleans the pallet , of this light to medium body beer with moderate astringency and warming alcohol .

that jibes with the idea of `` just beer '' a very nice puffy head fills up a quarter of the glass , but it does n't leave much lacing as i make my way through the bottle . color is a nice amber , but the aroma is almost absent .  mouthfeel is pretty good , it has a nice full body , and a good finish .

presentation : 750ml brown bottle , corked and caged , with great label , poured into a belgian-style chalice that 's been in the family for 3 generations apperance : absolutely stunning dark garnet brew with huge ivory whipped cream head , lots of carbonation with amazing cap retention smell : big powdery belgian yeast tones , a bit of juicy dark fruit , light phenols and spice ... it all melds together nicely , but nothing really jumps out individually , it 's a bit understated actually taste : much bigger/spicier than the soft aromas suggest ... .there 's lots of sweet spice up front here , with ( cloves ) ?  good carbonation .

impressive looking beer .  honestly as this has warmed it has become slightly undrinkable due to the sweetness m - medium bodied with a a good amount of carbonation . a slightly sticky mouthfeel as well .

pours a fascinating brownish black with little foam . very appealing to the eyes .  taste/mouthfeel : mostly hops . heavily malted finish . drinkability : a bit heavy and not quite as good as other european lagers . overall : probably the best gateway to this style .

appearance- beer pours a clear golden with a substantial two and a half finger head of eggshell foam over the top and lacing clinging to the sides of the glass .  the aroma contained notes of malt , hops and a discernable alcohol content of medium strength . it had a stong alcohol flavor that was very over powering the other flavors . it was smooth yet burned as it went down . truely a devilish brew !
aroma is lots of banana and lemon , very nice and assertive .  the mouthfeel is the pinnacle of this brew . full-bodied with a dry crisp feel .

poured with a beautiful , thick , creamy huge , fluffy , tan head with brown highlights .  a bitter spicy bite from the hops hit first . the light body and good crispness contrast the flavor pretty well .

the smell is exactly like a cafe mocha -- dark chocolate , buttery , and quality roasted coffee . the taste is very intense on the chocolate but the roasted coffee malts come through nicely too .  mouthfeel - it does have a pleasant rich/buttery mouthfeel .

this beer pours a light straw yellow with a massive 4 inch , pancake batter thick , cream head that left some serious lacing down the sides of the glass . really a beautiful beer .  this beer tastes like sheep shit . this may appeal to some people , but it 's definitely a very unusual belgian ale . i enjoyed drinking half of this beer for the experience . it 's so pungent i laughed out loud . it 's always fun to be exposed to a radically different flavor profile than you 're used to .

smell : smell is impressive to say the least . huge oaky brandy smells , with rasberry , chocolate and an imposing roasted malt presence . taste : everything good about the smell is in the taste , although unfortunately it still has a bit of a raw bite to it .  the mouthfeel is pretty good its not watery at all like you get with some lagers .
while it pours beautifully with a deep copper color and wonderful head , this brew is all looks and no personality .  mouthfeel is good - medium-bodied , good carbonation , smooth .

it has the perfect color for a lager , dark but not to dark .  m - the brew is wet at the lips but finishes quite dry . impressive . ~ unfortunately i 'm going to struggle finishing this because of the flavor .
s - classic belgiun smell.. sweet dark fruits.. caramel and brown sugar . t - pretty bland and tart .  nice crisp carbonation to keep it refreshing .

( a great place ) poured a wonderfully rich yellow color . it was cloudy with a half inch of creamy white head . nice lacing with this beer .  mf : smooth and wet . complements the flavours of the body .
wow . the nose was so great . what happened ?  m - full bodied , medium carbonation , really smooth . seems appropriate .

there 's something indescribably beautiful about a stout in a pint glass s - a wallop of chocolate and dark roasted coffee , some malt and alcohol notes , but the smell of fermented hot chocolate rules the day t - same as the smell .  m - good carbonation and a nice balance .

poured from a bomber into a snifter a - exceptional ! dark , almost ruby like color when held up to the light .  lovely thick aromas of blackstrap molasses , dark bitter chocolate , strong coffee and deep roasted malts ... awesome aromas to this one ... lazy and flat tasting ... strange bitter almost sour taste present ... . not much in common with the aromas ... thick oily mouthfeel is great but i ca n't get by the taste of this one ... drain poured this one ... maybe a bad bottle but as is , a big disappointment ...
appearance : pours orange in color with a huge fluffy white head that stays around for some time . lots of bubbles floating to the top .  mouthfeel : good .
smell is immensely yeasty with hints of clove , orange , and vanilla . decent nose if you ask me .  2.5 t & m : mouthfeel is fairly viscous and silky .

brett poured a beautiful slightly hazed golden-orange color producing a massive white head of assorted bubble sizes which was a bit hard to tame .  after smelling , i picked up on a semi-complex mix of belgium candy , malts , cherries and alcohol . it sat heavy on me and did not taste refreshing to me . i enjoyed this beer and can tell there was definitely quality & craftsmanship involved in it 's making ; but it 's not the best tripel i have ever had .
very pretty beer . deep dark brown , with a huge , tan head that stays for a while and leaves lovely lacing around the glass . just gorgeous .  the mouthfeel was full and sweet .
s : beautiful west coast hop aroma with a hint of honey and caramelized malts .  the mouthfeel is decently crisp while not out-of-control with carbonation .
appearance & gt ; lovely golden amber hue . lively .  the aftertaste lingers nicely , and the mouthfeel is firm . full bodied and smooth , but lacking an extra punch .

chocolate head over a pitch black pit , some sweet lacing ... some mild anise and roasted malts tingle the nose , also a hint of acetone in there .  reminds me of a lager ... mouthfeel is nice and crisp which aids drinkability . everything about this tells me this is a lager . it 's a good thirst-quencher .

bottle- color of dark orange , with a decent off white head - nose of fresh hops , pine , mint , resin , cannabis , and slight malts taste of fresh hops , slight mint , resin , cannabis , and slight malts - body is smooth , but too watery , and with low to medium carbonation aftertaste of some metallic , hops , and resin  the carbonation is considerable , quickening the mouth , and the hops are noticeable , but not significant .
poured into a fluted glass around 6c a : copper and crystal clear , with a nice 2 finger tan head that lasts a long time and laces nicely .  m : full body with mild carbonation ; slightly clinging .
s : i feel this beer smells better than the majority of pale ales . it has a very malty and hoppy smell all at once .  big body , low carbonation .
s : caramel malt with a nice sweet spiced aroma . smells like brown sugar . t : tastes like a cola at first , then the hops hit you squarely .  mouthfeel is round and full , thick and sticky .
poured from a 750ml bottle bottled on november 10 , 2011 into a tulip . a : pitch black with a 1 finger foam head . exactly how a stout should look .  m - thick , syrupy , smooth , a bit refreshing .
very double ipa , and enjoyable . taste is more subtle than i was expecting , bitter hops all the way through .  m-fairly dry . medium high carbonation .

looks picture perfect . despite my allergies , i can actually smell floral hops .  quickly hops dominate and overwhelm with a slightly unpleasant linger . smooth with a light bite . it 's not too bad until the hop bitterness overwhelms and turns this into just another hoppy ipa . all the other flavors disappear without anything to redeem it beside bitterness and a nice feel .
beautiful smell of bourbon it 's you first then caramel , vanilla , and a hint of oak .  the mouthfeel is nicely carbonated and almost creamy .
a : copper bronze , some off-white head , lots of lace .  m : good mouthfeel , its crisp , refreshing , light bodied with moderately high carbonation .

for me , the appearance of a well poured guinness is stellar . the deep rich near-black mahogany tint of it , while the flow of bubbles seems to defy physics is near magical . always great poured over a bent spoon atop bass pale ale or harp lager as well !  mouthfeel is good bordering on to thick .

s : peaty , peaty , peaty . slight hint of oak back , but peat dominates the nose , entirely . t : first taste , blast of peat overwhelms the palate , nose , pores , everything .  mouthfeel is good , slightly thick .

this is a powerfully aromatic ale it hits you the moment you open it . there is a strong candied fruit smell here . candy dates , pineapple , cherry , and a raw tobacco scent . about the most aromatic beer i have smelled in at least a year , maybe more . pliny the younger and three floyds dreadnaught are the only two on the same level of complexity . mouthfeel is good . drinkability is ok .  mouthfeel is decent medium bodied and goes down smooth .

this porter poured very dark , with about 2 fingers of just off white head . there was fantastic lacing left on the glass .  we 're okay though , as next time we get a samuel adams winter sampler pack , i 'll give her my cranberry , and i 'll have her boston lager . it 's not a bad beer , it 's just not to my liking . i ca n't even really say why . a bit sweeter than i 'd like , and just nothing that stands out and says `` i 'm great '' .

appearance & gt ; the beer poured a nice red colour , with a gorgeous haze , and a light head that lingered a spell , with not too much lacing .  the feel was light , clean and crisp . damn , and after smelling this hefe , it had so much promise .
smell is downright incredible , with lots of oily hops , citrus , and a complexity i ca n't describe .  m : thick creamy mouthfeel .
excellent lacing . great looking ipa .  it had a smooth mouthfeel with a little carbonation .

appearance : dark black color , with big chocolate brown head , medium carb smell : chocolate , with malts , and some wood taste : bitter dark chocolate , coffee , alcohol , and roasted malt mouthfeel : dry , slightly bitter , rich full body drinkability : a drinkable imperial stout , the high abv is moderately masked .  body is pleasantly creamy , almost akin to that of an esb or pub ale .

this beer pours a hazy honey golden orange with a huge fluffy white head , that leaves some seriously sticky lacing . i could only think to myself that this is an absolutely beautiful beer .  ) mouthfeel : in one word , thick .

very pleasant and layered . t - very hoppy at first , but the finish balances that out with a mild and sweet maltiness .  you do n't get much of the sweet malts you get from the aroma so it really confuses the senses and does n't make for an enjoyable experience mouthfeel is heavy and it sticks to your mouth for minutes .

a vigorous pour produced several fingers of foamy white head that eventually dissipated to about two fingers . lots of sticky lacing .  m- very smooth . medium carbonation fills the mouth a little . d- good .

sour cherries , fresh-pressed apple cider , mild marble rye , yeasty esters and a faint touch of alcohol . complex and rewarding . effervecent and envigorating without overwhelming the tongue . much lighter than the appearance would lead you to believe and it resembles many other belgian-style ales in this regard . maybe not everyone 's cup of tea but i find it to be immensely drinkable and the alcohol is hardly noticable . quite good .  first off , i can tell that this one is slightly skunked , but i ca n't really blame the brewer for this one as i am also able to pull out some nice mellow caramel malts and a touch of biscuity-bready goodness as well . nice mellow malts , not too sweet , but the hops come through for a bit too much bite from what i look for and love about english pales . the hops come on a little too strong and linger too long , not really allowing me the chance to savour the mellow malts as much as i would like . there is a slight sweetness about it that reminds me of fresh apples although not the biting green apple off taste . this is different , and nice , but not my first choice for an english pale .
looks fantastic and i am very impressed with the head retention .  the mouthfeel is good - smooth with a right amount of carbonation .

anywho , nice nose . love the nose . really nice citrusy hops with just a touch of wheaty sourness in there , but barely any . just a nice fresh smell . the beer has quite a bit of flavor for only 4.8 % abv .  m : very nicely carbonated for this type of beer .
it 's a hazy orange-red-brown with a 2 finger head of foam . a great looking brew .  '' the mouthfeel is good . its quite smooth and slightly creamy .

pours a golden orange with lots of suspended floaties . it has a huge spongy white head that retains well and laces the glass .  body and mouthfeel is more or less where it should be for the style , with a heavy weight and restrained carbonation .

smell is on the sweet side but hoppy as well , sweet bubblegum scent , weed , juicy citrus and a malt punch , great scent . taste is enjoyable , alot of different things balancing sweet and hoppy in that order with the above mentioned scents going into the taste without the weed .  m : very viscous , pretty smooth .
great retention and great lacing .  very thick and coating , with very little carbonation .
the brew pours a slightly darker golden color with a huge , creamy , rocky white head that sticks around for a while .  medium bodied with lively fine carbonation .

appearance- dark brown almost black with tan head with decent lacing .  the mouthfeel is surprisingly creamy and not too heavy . the drinkablity is pretty low , not from the booze , but extreme bitterness , which overwhelms the decent , but not exceptional malt .

however , the smell is unbelievable . this is definitely a dessert beer .  char davies , the artist in 1998 , made a fully interactive immersive visual/aural virtual artwork called ephemere , which furthers the work begun in osmose started in 1995 and displayed in the national gallery of canada in ottawa on june 26 , 1998. who cares ? this beer is almost close to a champaign ( and i would think that the yeast probably is champaign ) . also there is bitterness , which is nice to know that at least there are some hops to the so called beer . it is not advisable to use apples with fermenting , as the yeast creates funky flavors from apples , but this is much better than expected . although i would not want to drink this beer on a regular bases , thus low score on drinkability , i think it has a great taste like a grandsmith apples i use to eat as a kid .

that 's an outstanding looking brew - steady head , chunky like snowfall on fence posts from the beginning , but it melts down a bit to only ring the glass . like deep brown bricks , with hints of orange around the edges - strong looking beer .  m- medium in body and good carbonation .

a- pours about as dark as u can get without being called black . two fingers of a tan head that has pretty good retention . tons of lacing left . a very looking beer .  m- a good body to it . good weight and smooth carbonation . there is a strange foamy texture in the finish though .

aroma is a delight . clean , bright and complex , yeasty sweet spicy goodness . taste is equally complex . figs , green grapes , caramel , leather and a brief dry twang .  very tame malt , very little hops , and weak alcohol that 's more like aftershave . definitely not over-carbonated , the texture fits the style . actually the best element of this beer .

has a lovely appearance . produces about two and a have fingers thick of light tan head that has perfect retention . the body of the brew is cleanly filtered and is dark copper/ruby red in color .  the body is somewhere between medium and full , with a creamy mouthfeel .

the two versions are enough alike that any impression of 15th anniversary will translate to 16th ; therefore , my review of 15th anniversary follows : [ `` great divide 15th anniversary wood aged double ipa poured a beautiful copper with red hints when held to light . there was a massive creamy head and huge amounts of lace clung to the glass .  m : good , not too thin or thick .

black boss porter , poland the bottle is very bold and to the point , solid block cap , impressive . poured into pint glass : this beer is rich black color with a creamy brownish head , the head is small but retains well and long . the nicest red/mahogany color come thought when hit by light .  served in a pint glass mug a : pours a clear bronze color with about an inch of thick head s : a smell provides a nice rye scent with a very sweet undertone contributed by the honey addition t : very nice smooth tasting beer , has a slight hint of honey and perhaps a slight rye note but other than that there isnt much to comment on , smooth and slightly sweet but thats about it m : very smooth in the mouth with a slight bite on the tongue as it is drank d : high level of drinkability , very subdued taste that is great for a hot summer day but leaves the drinking looking for more otherwise .
served from bottle into a goblet appearance- black color , very large brown/white very frothy lasting head .  m-creamy and good mouthfeel d-did n't finish my 1/5 share of the bomber .
this really is a beautiful beer with it 's deep amber hues and dense mousey head that clings to the side of the glass .  pretty much just a tingly water . very smooth and somewhat refreshing beer .

its pale golden body is saturated with torrents of lacing , and topped off with a meringue-like head of admirable retention . o : i do n't understand how people pay an extra $ 3/6pk for this garbage over bud ; it 's essentially the same stuff .  at least its silky smooth and the alcohol is well hidden . this beer , in my opinion , is the weakest of their stout series .
the smell is outstanding - i was salivating from the roasty nutty goodness .  mouthfeel is creamy and crisp .

deep ruby color with a cream-colored creamy head that leaves a nice curtain of lacing . pretty beer , especially with a little light behind it .  aside from the taste , mouthfeel is actually pleasant on the palate . good medium body and carbonation is about right on the tongue .
the smell was fantastic ! a hop bomb . nice hop finish lingered on my tongue . i 'm anxious to try the imperial version of this brew .  medium bodied with a creamy carbonation level .

poured a beautiful mahogany with a creamy half inch of foam that never fully subsided .  the milk sugar cuts through and makes it a bit artificial and like one of those creme savers candies . creamy on the palate with sugary milkiness with some of the same strawberry flavor and other general fruitiness , a touch of tartness in the finish . weirdness in the finish ... not medicinal but has a certain harshness and fake tasting combining with the artificial fruity sweetness like many of the shorts beers , nice to try , but i did n't have any desire to finish the 12oz .

a - a mildly assertive pour yields a bubbly two-finger head with decent retention and frothy lacing down the glass . really a nice looking beer .  the best part of this one is the mouthfeel ; to my surprise , it is rather thick , at least for a beer of this style .
a perfect looking stout .  mouthfeel was good and thick , but was n't enough to save this beer from being a disappointment .
the color is a deep , very pretty dark amber . this is a beautiful beer .  m : medium bodied with moderate carbonation .

a : beautiful clear rich copper color with creamy tan head . m : smooth o : a very aesthetically pleasing beer . really beautiful to look at and smell .  mouthfeel - good feel , not too thick , kind of creamy , decent carbonation .
smell is nice ! !  firm mouthfeel , big and solid . very imperial .
poured black with a rocky mostly lasting light brown head with excellent lacing .  m : mouth feel is pretty good .
it has a great aroma . lots of sweet malt , floral notes , and honey . it 's a little too sweet , but still good . i also get a slight undertone of cloves .  medium full bodied , somewhat creamy .
a nice , interesting nose .  m : the body is medium to full with a fairly high carbonation . this is actually one of the best things about this beer .

appearance : large , crackling layer of fizz off pour , which descends to a firm , tan crown . deep brown body shines crimson in light and shows excellent clarity . nice head retention and lace .  m : good mouthfeel .

the geary 's hsa pours a beautiful dark amber , sticky-icky up the sides and a beautiful 1/4 inch head .  m/d : light and smooth feel on the mouth , drinkable but not something i will ever get again .

poured this puppy into a duvel tulip , which helped to bring about an ample 4 finger thick fluffy and off white head . the body is very murky and peach in color . head retention is great , as well as the lacing .  m- medium viscosity with a well integrated carbonation .

a= pours a beautiful dark brown almost black color with a great two finger perfectly toasty looking head on it that holds awesome retention and wonderful lacing on the glass .  mouthfeel is light and also a little creamy ; effervescence nicely balances out the mouthfeel . a little too bitter and astringent for my palate ; however , i have to confess that ipas are not my style of choice .
a : excellent dark red color . very bright and enticing .  m - very light , nicely carbonated and goes down quite smooth .

appearance : very dark , as the name would suggest ... but some brown tinge . quite a nice head , with moderate retention and nice lace .  m- the body is full . the carbonation is at a nice subdued level .

three floyds beers have a unique aroma . the hops come across , thick and flowery . ive heard they use amarillo and columbus hops for aroma . many brewers could learn from these folks . milk chocolate , coffee , a little toasted malt with just a mild flowery hop flavor on the finish . slick , smooth and rich mouth feel , very nice , very drinkable .  body is medium and carbonation is mild .
poured from a 750ml into a tulip . the look is spot on . moderate gold , huge head , great lacing , very visible carbonation .  m - medium bodied with good carbonation .
the colour is pitch-black ; the two finger head is pale beige , airy and uneven . massive amounts of lacing .  quite thick and creamy , though a little fizzy .

real dark brown . nice big dark tan head that retained throughout the beer and laced the glass nicely .  m : fizzy carbonation that smooths out a little into the sip and works well with the body of the beer .

rgc pours a deep red-cognac color with generous carbonation and a settling tan head .  syrupu sweetness , not cloying , with hop dryness in the blend . this is what imperial pilsner is supposed to be ? what happened to the pilsner part ?
still a bit of haze but not anything like a hefe . the beer looks great in this glass !  good carbonation .
pours nicely for a two finger thick tan head , and has a copper colored well filtered body .  full bodied and a bit oily in texture .

it 's a very appealing smell . taste : part belgian wit and part apple cider blended together . the smell is really good , but the taste is a bit disappointing in comparison . the good aromas in the smell do n't show up in the taste .  the mouth feel was thick and creamy ( a high gravity ) overall not a `` session beer '' but one to enjoy and move on .

a very aggressive head forms and is as thick as 3+ fingers . a deep ruby/amber color with excellent clarity and no visible carbonation . clumpy lacing everywhere .  m - light-medium body with plenty of carbonation .

appearance : crystal clear orange-brown body with randomly-placed shades of red . very nice head retention on the whole and lots of web-like lacing .  a relatively full body and a sharp effervescence up front .
it pours a dark , coppery amber with a frothy , persistent , off-white head .  mouthfeel is solid - fairly light , appropriate carbonation .

a : pours a clear copper/amber with two fingers worth of creamy off white head . it had a great cascading effect during the pour , so much that it looked like a nitro can pour .  appropriately light in body without being too thin .

pours a clear dark brown with superior side lacing and a copious tan head with very good retention . appearance is exceptional .  ) and is a deep rich molasses s : once again , may have been too cold for phenols to waft up t : slightly sweet really tasty m : nice and cold d : pour me another

a : the can exploded ( mostly into the glass ) with creamy head and produced the beautiful downward drifting bubbles that makes nitro-things look so interesting . two fingers of tight , creamy head .  the dominate taste is sort of watery . i was worried because the head but the carbonation is excellent .
beer is a slightly hazed mid-orange . very generous , sudsy white head is slow to go and leaves thick lacing .  m -- thick , slick d -- very one dimesional brew .
sm : this smells really good . nice , big , citrusy hops .  m - crisp and decent carbonation .

i love nitrous beers - they have this amazing waterfall effect as the head settles . the beer 's head was a nice creamy tan color and featured some light coffee/mocha scents . appearance - 5.0/5.0 - love the waterfall effect of the nitrous , tan creamy head - very full taste - 4.5/5.0 - silky smooth - coffee and light chocolate taste feel - 4.0/5.0 - no aftertaste , extremely smooth in mouth smell - 4.0/5.0 - very light with coffee/mocha accents drinkability - 4.5/5.0 - way better than a guiness - very tasty , smooth - i will be repeating this beer .  m : probably the best thing this beer has to offer . very smooth , with just a little bit of unwanted bitterness and carbonation .

when i poured it into a typical pint mug , this beer instantly excited my eyes . beautiful dark liquid with a thick tan head .  m/s carbonation is fine , alcohol is n't really noticeable `` thanks '' to the bitterness overall i really do n't like this beer , but i guess it has more to do with me and this style than the beert itself .
aroma is clean and bright . sassafras along with quiet vanilla sit beneath a strong phenolic note .  mouthfeel is good .

spicy and compliments the smell . m - thin and smooth , carbonation does not come in to play which may be from the age . d - this beer is very drinkable .  mouthfeel : medium bodied beer . very short aftertaste with his beer .
pretty nice looking beer .  m : dry and crisp but smooth as butter .

wow , the smell is the absolute best part of this brew - strong on the citrus . when first tasting dreadnaught , i picked up more piney hop taste than the smell indicates . the more i drank , however , the citrus hop flavor came through . i paid $ 8.99 for this bomber and it was worth it ( although pricey for an everyday beer ) .  on first sip you get hit with a strong citrus hop attack . from the aroma to the taste , there is just something that does n't sit well with me . it leaves an unpleasant bitter aftertaste . i love ipas and hops galore . my only guess is that the bitter citrus flavor is what threw this beer off for me .
pours a beautiful dark brown with a slight ruby hue on the outer edges , nice thick microfoam head that leaves nice lacing .  m - a fairly heavy mouthfeel with all the sweetness .
this beer smells amazing but its taste is over the top .  it had a medium bodied with good carbonation .

s : holy hops , batman ! intense , complex , and amazing . t : starts off with citrus and herbal hops , then transitions to a bit of caramel malt before finishing with a wave of piney bitterness . delicious . m : medium bodied with a good dose of initially spiky , finally smooth carbonation .  ) mouthfeel is just nicely carbonated and light and the only reason the drinkability is n't higher on my ratings is because after a few 40 's your out of the game for a while .

a - golden and slightly hazed with coppery highlights and a foamy , cushiony head that jets to the surface and clings to the glass like glue as it subsides . head retention is fantastic , and would be even without the aid of the etching at the bottom of the glass . fantastic .  the mouthfeel is it 's only saving grace . it 's a light bodied beer and is very drinkable , although i know this will be my last one .

nose : a nice profile of strong citrus notes , not overly complex , but nice . tongue : what strikes my first is just how malty this is .  most everything else about this beer was great , looked good , good mouthfeel , but the taste .
aroma : very complex . banana , clove , butter , bubblegum , and hints of alcohol .  m : dark beers always feel good in the mouth . this one isnt super smooth , but the feel is good .

it smells great . t : the taste didnt exactly match the smell but the taste was good too .  ) the body is a hefty medium , bordering on the truly heavy , with a light moderate carbonation and a fairly chewy feel . harsh .

a : pours a one finger head of amazing cream , brilliant thickness , and incredible retention ( over six minutes before i could n't wait any longer ) for the style . incredibly appealing .  the feel is between medium and full for the style and enjoyably so . moderate carbonation nails the feel .
aroma is absolutely perfect . sweet maple and brown sugar mouth-watering goodness with fresh cannabanoid hop perfume .  m - nice average mouthfeel .

i absolutely loved the smell of this , chocolatey , with some sweet fruits from the yeast and subtle hop profile .  starts off clean and finishes with metallic hops m : silky smooth , good carbonation d : why ?

the hazelnut scent was so strong and so nice , it easily could have been mistaken for frangelico .  i believe the bottle i got was 8.75 percent.. looked pretty good for a esl , smell and taste reminded me very much of great western extra gold.. very malty with a nice solventy sweet-like alcohol burn ... carbonated perfectly , making it halfway drinkable , still hangover juice as far as imports go.. cheers !
pours with a beautiful amber body topped by a thick lasting head with a good amount of lace left on the glass .  adequate carbonation .

pours with a vast amount of co2 . produces a beautiful light tan head that sticks around forever . the body is dark amner in color .  the body of this beer suits the style with the usual level of north coast drinkability and feel to it . definitely the best feature .

this brew poured a medium head of fine bubbles and left behind a nice lacing as it receded . it has a dark cloudy red brown body and a malty aroma .  mouthfeel -pretty good . foamy , not spritzy . nice and full , for a lager .

s : smell is awesome . so complex for a stout which are normally one dimensional . coffee and dark unsweetened cocoa powder , whiskey/bourbon and even some woody notes that are muted .  m - i find with sub-par beers such as this one , the mouthfeel usually gives them their only good qualities . good amount of carbonation and goes down smooth .

the aroma was very fresh , like a breeze on a river , ( stunning ! ) floral hops and hints of citrus along with caramel malt ; a sweet and inviting blend . muted orange rind , grapefruit notes and a doughy malt/yeast blend were present but the bitterness that sat atop them i found unpleasant .  m : medium bodied , good amount of carbonation .

appearance : orange/amber body with a nice two finger head .  glass : new belgium globe aging notes : one year at ~60f in the dark bang for the buck ( oz* % / $ ) : 22*6.2/10 = 13.64 a : orange , white lacey head , slightly cloudy from yeast s : horse-y farmhouse brett with hints of orange t : brett dominates ( horse-stable hay , a little dung almost ) , notes of orange m : silky , coating , lingering , pleasant o : worth drinking , a little one-dimensional with the brett .

12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass a : pours a clear light golden amber with a fingers width of sea foam white head . the head dissipates to a solid thick film and leaves a surprising amount of lacing .  the mouthfeel is good , but obviously does not improve the flavor !
great streaks of lacing that never disappear .  very nice feel .
a : this beer pours a beautiful hazy red color with a fluffy off white head . the color of this beer is amazing .  m - light to medium carbonation with medium carbonation .

caged and corked 75cl bottle ; poured with an immense head of tight foam and a beautiful tornadic swirl of yeast-inspired carbonation .  flavor is malty and sweet , and on the finish , bubble gum ! mouthfeel is firm , and drinkability is high .

this amber ale pours with a clear amber body topped by a thick head with lots of lacing left on the glass .  let me first say that the brugse tripel used to be one of my favorite beers . nowdays its called brugge tripel and the taste changed slowly ... but a lot of small steps make a big one and today this beer is nothing what it used to be . smell of spices and a little hops , not fresh at all and a dull taste make it just a drinkable beer but nothing great like it had in the past .
( bottle into pint glass - sampled 4/5/10 ) picture perfect pour with a dark brown color and creamy off white head .  m - crisp and refreshing o - overall pretty meh .
tremendous head and a deep , dark brown body . the lowly brown ale usually isnt going to win beauty contests , but this is about as good as one will look .  m : light body with good carbonation .
pours deep burgundy/ with 3 fingers+ of sand/tan colored head . superior lacing & head retention s : chocolate & coffee ( ?  it is very finely carbonated , giving a tickle on the tongue .

pours a murky , dark dark brown colour , only a sliver of colour really visible . head is stunning : beige , dense , small bubbles that wobbles on top but retains , with a beautiful , vibrant cascade when poured . lace is clingy and thick , like coffee foam . that 's a stunning beer .  carbonation is right on par .

vanilla , oak , maple leaf , faint rum aroma , and most of all ooey gooey caramel - sort of like a caramello bar . t : bittersweet chocolate layered with oaky and vanilla flavors , a caramel filling , and a coffee finish . i would even go as far to say this was luxurious or elegant .  feels right in body , but the taste is just off .

fantastic lacing & head retention is als really good , a peresitent film hugs the orval goblet all the way down s : slight hints of choclate , cherry & oak barrels t : choclate & oakyness up front .  m : light-bodied on the palate , with a slightly creamy texture and average-to-lively carbonation . d : i just do n't think it tastes like a real lambic .

glorious aroma of silky dark chocolate and dark-roast coffee beans . very pleasant . the dry , slightly acidic roasty finish leads well into another sip .  - 3.0/5.0 feel - coats the mouth well , with a bit of pepperly aftertaste .

s : smells really good . lots of bourbon , vanilla , oak right away , giving a huge barrel presence . the barleywine aromas of caramel , toffee , brown sugar , and dark fruits are evident and impressive as well . o : a really nice nose but the flavor was disappointing .  mouthfeel : nicely carbonated and good level of thickness - probably the best part of this beer .
this beer is beautiful . red/amber color with a thick rocky head that clings to the side of the glass . head disappears fast though .  m : felt good going down had a nice thick feel to it .
looks like a good representation of the style .  good mouthfeel , crisp , medium body , good carbonation which is refreshing for a warm weather beer .
but wow , this one looks amazing ! a gorgeous burgundy with beautiful creamy froth on top .  it had a really good mouthfeel .

big piney and resiny hops fill the aroma , backed by a pretty sizeable maltiness . tobacco and bread come to mind . the malts may dominate the hops in this aipa , which almost always results in an iffy beer , that has you questioning the style .  mouthfeel is light to medium and has a soft feel .

the nose on the beer is very good with a nice orange burst type hop presence . i just wish the taste followed suit . the beer is overly bitter , with a very pungent tangy hop bite , and not enough of the enjoyable orangey citrus hop and estery juices that i was expecting from the aroma .  the body is on the full side , though not quite as much as most stouts ( i suppose increased attenuation should have been expected with the switch in yeast strain ) , and has a solidly low key carbonation .

the aroma is very fruity and hoppy : orange and maybe a hint of apple mixed together . ester 's given off from the yeast is quite detectable too . this is a very fragrant beer . helios tripplebock is crazy for being a german brew , as it is a total hop bomb .  m : well carbonated and thick , fairly heavy . fits the style .

amazing lacing & head retention , really pretty to look at s : hints of choclate & some roasted malt as it warms t : rich choclate up front , then a little grainyness & some bitter choclate .  m - medium bodied with some soft carbonation .

poured a hazy gold-orange with a 1.5 inch frothy white head and cascades of tiny effervescing bubbles that traveled from the base of the glass to the bottom of the cap . sticky rings of lacing were revealed as the head slowly receded .  this one is crisp and carbonation is at a good level . body is n't as light as i had expected ; this one 's medium-bodied .

the beer poured beautifully into the glass : a bronze-brownish coloured pint with a thick off white head . the main thing i noticed throughout the duration of the pint was the excellent retention and lacing that the head left .  m- medium bodied with a decent carbonation level .

it smells delicious , but it needs more sweetness and less bitterness to balance the tartness of the brett , no fusels , less carbonation and more body .  mouthfeel is nice and full and slippery without any carbonation .

makes a great presentation with three fingers of light tan head that sticks around for a good bit .  the mouthfeel at the start was mildly crisp and finished dry and smooth . the unbalanced flavors knock down the drinkability for me .

intense hop nose , complex , very piney , leafy with a strong minty/evergreen aromas with a sight sweet malt note . the hops were overpowering hard to smell anything else . would have expected more maltiness with the dark color , really got fooled there .  no complaints as the the mouthfeel , medium bodied with a pretty sharp carbonation .

the 2005 is a brighter copper , with the most beautiful , nearly unbroken sheet of off-white lacing on the other side of the glass . gorgeous . on the 2010 , no lacing , bigger bubbles , thinner cap .  medium mouthfeel .
pours a hazy light auburn in color . plenty of head and very nice lacing .  the mouthfeel was decent , medium with adequate carbonation .

aroma is way way hoppy . pretty good , almost a back sweetness to it . pretty piny in the aroma .  i like the feel with some prickly carbonation and moderately light feel and some creaminess from the head .
body was cloudy and amber aroma was outstanding . moderate hoppiness and perfume .  the mouthfeel is crisp overall .
a - a lovely copper with startling clarity , it truly poured beautifully .  mouthfeel is thick and smooth , no watery sensation at all .

big , bold aromatic amarillo hops billowing out . pour is gold , with no head , as it seems to have lost carbonation in transit , unfortunately . very drinkable and i can see this being fantastic properly carbonated . great ipa .  m : medium-bodied and creamy ; high carbonation ; mouthfeel is this beer 's strongest attribute , in my opinion .
as pretty as beer poured out of a can into a glass can be .  mouthfeel : smooth and medium thick , low carbonation .
it has a very deep black color and tan head that make it beautiful to pour .  nice creamy mouthfeel .
pours a copper color with some haze . it has the consistency of whipped cream and has some of the best retention ive ever seen .  medium carbonation .
this smells real delicious . t - balanced malt hop mix up front with a hint of the fruity taste the smell indicated .  light to medium bodied , with a very smooth mouthfeel .
pours a clear amber color with a creamy off white tannacios head that leaves great lacing .  m : creamy and spot-on carbonation .

a- black beer into ayinger glass , huge head with infinite retention , probably 4 fingers on average . nice light mocha color and a ton of lace everywhere .  m - good mouthfeel , coats a bit like oil but smooth .

the nose begins to drift toward me as i pour ... a nice roasted barley , chocolate and espresso with a hint of cinnamon . this smells more like a stout . the nose is deceiving .  mouthfeel : medium body , medium carbonation overall : this beer has almost no taste , pity

smells fantastic . spicy , fruity and different . really intriguing . tastes similar to the aroma -- some malty , almost candy-like , sweetness underneath , but with a strong bitterness taking centre stage .  but , also an odd smell kind of like salami . this must be some nasty phenol created by the yeast . a bad yeast flavor here and a lot of it . i usually love unibroue brews for that complex yeasty quality but for some reason this one tastes a little off . that lunchmeat aroma and now this bad oily yeasty taste make this beer almost undrinkable . i doubt it considering it 's called edition 2004 , we 're in 2005 , and it 's 10.5 abv .
a - black brew with two fingers of frothy light brown head . lacing is pretty thick in decent rings .  mouthfeel is fine for the style .

a : pours a light golden with a couple fingers of dense white head that reduced very slowly into a thick frothy head . beautiful rings/sheets of lacing left with every sip .  the mouthfeel was quite good , though . well carbonated and it felt good going down .

appearance : this `` holy brew of antioch '' poured quite well leaving a thick head that sustained quite well . lacing is generous and adheres to both the glass and spiderwebs on the surface . excellent so far ... smell : there is a sweet spiciness , maybe like green apples , that provides a good portion of the aromatic body .  this beer feels almost delicate .

i fricking love the way this beer looks . huge foamy white head , brilliant dark golden color with a cascade of carbonation bubbling up the side .  the mouthfeel is smooth and oily and the carbonation is alright .

pours dark brown nearly black with thick fluffy , chunky milk chocolate head that leaves hefty amounts of 3-d lacing as it slowly falls , damn this looks good !  it is medium bodied and smooth in the mouth .
s- some nice fresh fruit hits the nose immediately in the way of some fresh apple and the caramel moves in next .  pretty refreshing , not overwhelmed with carbonation .

very attractive beer . massive sticky foamy eggshell colored head rises to 2 fingers and holds there forever .  the palates leads with a thick , malty mouthfeel up front and a sticky , resiny bitterness in the back .
the smell is very pleasant , a combination of biscuit , pear , and pepper .  m : mouthfeel is crisp , light-medium bodied and pretty dry .

pours a clear amber color , a few bubbles rising to the top . creamy ivory head fills the pint glass , leaves a bunch of stick and keeps a very nice lace .  still for such a big beer it had a great body , just not sure if i would want more , until it got about 5 years on it .
appearance is great . a very nice looking stout .  mouthfeel : soft creaminess , light to medium carbonation , with a medium to full body .

bomber into a shaker glass , the boont esb is hazy burnt orange with a tall , rocky light khaki head , that took a while to subside to a thick skim leaving decent lace . very nice !  pours a cloudy , almost 'chunky ' looking way -- looks a bit similar to an apple cider ( non alcoholic kind ) . caramelly sweet too . vanilla . taste is what kind of throws me - again , both the oak ( taste of whisky barrel ) and smokiness are there . i like both of those favors in my beers , but combined , my jury is still out : like they are competing for my affection . alcohol is quite present too , which seems to go well with the aforementioned whisky oak . a lot going on in this brew .
a big , thick , creamy , dark-tan head forms on top of an opaque black body .  mouthfeel is good and thick , finish is dry with a moderate dose of alcohol present .

aroma is fabulous , even at this temperature . delicious . well worth the $ 6 canadian that i paid for it .  aroma : hops . the crystal hops dominate the aroma . the malt is there , but overpowered by hops . but i do n't taste the balance that an esb should have . the hops weigh far more than the malt in this beer . notes : this tasted like a very good ipa , but did not have the balance i was expecting , for an esb . a great beer , but did n't fit the style as well as i would have liked .

called the skellig irish red on the chalkboard , but confirmed with watch city that it is their shillelagh irish red . magnificent , bulbous cream of head that frankly amazes with its ocean of white and a knifes edge cut ; huge stick and lace . dark red hue with a dead quiet calm and plenty of crystal clarity .  oily mouthfeel with next to no carbonation . quite thick and heavy , coating every area of the mouth .

blood red color with a thick pink foamy head the color of blush wine .  everything about this beer was pretty light - light , crisp malt scent ; light fruity taste ; light body . feel - 4.0/5.0 - refreshing , which was really nice .

appearance - nice dark brown with a thick tan head that hugged the glass .  smells sour , big nodes of orange and very tart lemon juice . there 's a bit of a funky hop in there , as well . no real spice of which to speak , nor any hint of wheat . very sour , almost cidery . starts more tart , like lemon juice , moves into a dryer , white wine middle , and ending on a more of a light , semi-sweet orange sour . a unique beer , to say the least . could benefit from a bit of something at the end , but is drinkable enough as it is .
smell : smells nice and tasty , with chocolate and molasses notes . very little hop aroma , but still strong enough to balance the brew .  mouthfeel is nice & creamy .

the smell is enticing , pumpkin , cinnamon , and clove . tastes like a belgian brown , but the spice is overdone .  m : fuller side of medium-bodied with moderate carbonation that tickles the tongue and throat . this aspect of the beer is really nice .

wonderfully hoppy scent with a citric , floral edge . notes of toffee and orange in the aroma . taste does n't quite live up to the aroma , but overall a nice , easy-drinking harvest ale .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied , with a soft prickly creaminess , along with some easy slickness in the body that helps that raw feeling finish go down . just a smidge of alcohol is felt but it is n't overly noticeable .
almost one-finger of fluffy dark brown head over an almost perfectly clear orange-brown liquid .  m - nice and creamy in the mouth , goes down smooth .
the smell is nice and wheaty . definitely smell the 12 percent .  the mouthfeel of this beer ( outside of taste ) was great . great carbonation , bitter hop aftertaste , medium bodied .

served at a few degrees below fridge tempeature in a tulip glass . the color is a gleaming orange , and the lacing is setting up with unbelievable sticky cling . superb ! smell- a bold metallic smell booms out from the glass , incredibly phenolic and overpowering the malts and hops .  mouthfeel - good smoothness , a medium body on par with the style , crisply carbonated .
full concentric rings of lace and very good retention are a highlight .  mouthfeel is quite nice and full .
a one finger , mocha colored head has supreme retention and some amazing lacing to go along with it . very nice looking .  m- felt just about right on not too thick .
incredible retention and ok lacing s- sweet and hoppy .  m - good carbonation and it finishes clean . good light to medium mouthfeel .

hazy and dark copper-amber in color with a thick cream colored head of super tightly laced foam that left great lacing at it receded at a slow but steady rate ; the head reminds me of an improperly baked cake very slowly losing its leavening .  m : easy drinking with medium-body and low-moderate carbonation .

it looks like a very refreshing and tasty beer . crystal clear straw colored beer , again looks very refreshing .  as i drink more my palate adjusts but it does n't ever really get over the off flavors m - pretty thick , not too carbonated , nice mouth coating qualities d - burnt coffee does not go down very well , plust the thickness of the beer limits my ability to quaff this completely i like coffee , i like stouts , and i like a lot of coffee stouts ( new glarus and founders breakfast stout for instance ) .

lovely sugary sweetness , rich chocolate , and coffee nose & # 8230 ; the bouquet shows excellent depth , very inviting . the palate is less enthusiastic . fairly complex & # 8230 ; excellent hops influences at the finish , it builds on the coffee flavors nicely .  m : moderate carbonation with a decently viscous mouthfeel .
poured a 2 finger fluffy light tan head with excellent retention to 1 finger cap .  finish is very grainy and `` off '' lol mouthfeel : full-medium , creamy body with moderate carbonation .

enjoyed from snifters and beer a gift from the brewer himself ... ap : deep dark body , roasted brown head , awesome retention .  mouth feel is more medium bodied than the wheats i 'm used to , a nice change and the full blast carbonation leaves one a happy advocate overall it is lacking smell , good in flavor , great in feel .

smell is very sugary with a fruit and spice scent of apple butter . apple , cinnamon , clove , raisin , grape , figs , black pepper and sweet prunes are all in here . taste is drier than expected sweet but not very . good spice flavor that builds as you sip . the flavor just is n't anywhere as complex as the smell . mouthfeel is good nice drinkable belgian here that is worth a try , only problem is that there are lots better around .  m : lots of carbonation , but a pretty smooth medium body nonetheless .

a-black , a lot of tan head s-dark roasted malts and a lot of sweet creamy chocolate , there 's hint of caramel as well t-hits with a very light hint of roasted malts and chocolate but they come in quite strong within the after-taste .  mouthfeel : medium body with smooth carbonation and a dry finish .
pours an almost transparent golden/light copper with an amazingly fluffy 3 finger head from an extremely gentle pour .  m : creamy to a crisp finish with a good carbonation throughout .

looks very lively . this looks amazing and out of control .  i did n't want to buy this because i do n't trust twisted pine to sell me a good beer . since i am a sucker and i love hoppy beers i bought it anyway . the smell was very hoppy citrus , pine and something off i could n't place until i tasted it , butter . this beer was quite disappointing and i poured out the remaining 13 or so ounces after i finished my first glass .
s - the aroma initially reminded me of kentucky monk ( a very fine compliment ) . nice stuff .  fine mouthfeel , nothing objectionable , but it 's not a stand-out lager either .

a : orangey amber cloudy beer with a huge 3 finger cappucino head that settles to peaks and valleys veery slowly , great lace throughout .  mouthfeel -- nice , an initial carbonate bite followed by a foamy smoothness . , molasses , pepper/spice .

the second surly can i got from my man joe aka ineedabeerhere . the aroma is quite hoppy , even with all this time in the can . pineapple , grape , carrots ? you can also smell a bit of alcohol in the furious , but only after sniffing the juice . the taste continues with the depth of the aroma , and i 'm loving it . it could use a bit more sweetness to accentuate the fruity hops .  mouthfeel - some creamy smoothnes , well-carbonated .
best by june 28 2010 poured into a rave vos tumbler . half a glass of milky , fluffy , off-white head that is slow to settle .  lighter body and a nice lively carbonation .

s : a really interesting mix , i get a strong strawberry aroma mixed with a heavy caramel smell . there is also a nice hop/citrus aroma in the middle , some tangerine maybe . overall a really nice beer , very drinkable .  mouthfeel is nice and light , with adequate carbonation for the style .
two fingers of frothy light yellow head with great retention and lacing . truly exceptional .  m : smooth and round .

cloudy pale copper color and of hazy reddish tone nearer to the top which is adorned by a rich creamy head of froth about an inch high and colored of dark ivory . head retains its thick body to settle a bit with a lumpy top and lots of lace in big blotches , looks scrumptious !  creamy mouthfeel with the addition of oatmeal in the mix .

the appearance is amazing . it pours really really dark brown , safe to say black . it leaves a thick lacing around the glass that is very very intimidating .  mouthfeel is medium bodied and crisp . good carbonation , but the overall trainwreck of flavor in the brew makes this one hard to take down .

750ml a : really looks great with red notes . the amber color really makes this look appetizing .  mouthfeel is medium , well carbed , nice on all fronts but where it needs to be . big failure , in my opinion .

also , a wonderful , frothy , mocha head retains throughout .  the body is nice and thick , with a flavorful malt profile : sweet medium caramel malts with a bit of roast character . hops , by the way , are almost nonexistent , which would n't be bad if not for the oxidation , which makes the faint floral flavor seem dull . overall not bad , but has the same type of oxidized or maybe just oversparged flavor common to other corporate breweries like gordon-biersch .

perfectly balanced , wonderful , and refreshingly innovative . i 'm starting to think rogue bombers might be worth their exhorbitant price out here .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied and watery with almost no carbonation .

great aroma , hope there is more of this in the palate . pretty decent .  medium body , almost non existent carbonation , sweet sticky syrupy mouthfeel . i think the lack of carbonation ruins the mouthfeel and makes this taste and smell overly sweet .
poured into a tulip . this beer is a beautiful gold . stunning and fragrant .  overall , feels unbalanced , too much carbonation and a little too dull .

nice . d - i 'm coming to the conclusion that i 'm not a huge fan of hoppy beers . but this is nice . while i ca n't say i 'd like this all the time , i 'd definitely like to revisit it .  flavor is rather plain , roasty , sweet , a bit of coffee and coco , the hops seem to be hiding somewhere , i detect little to none , little carbonation , short finish , with a bit of dark bread , and rasins , very thin body.drinkable but not very memoriable .

damm , skippy , now thats what a stout should look like ! deep , cream black pour . an absolutely beautiful , thick and fluffy brown head , clings to the side of the glass endlessly .  m : this was the most dissapointing . aside from the lingering dry finish this was a very thin porter .
huge pepper aroma and a very pronounced and balanced flavor . thanks to the lovely folks at elysian fields today , very gracious hosts .  mouthfeel was poor .

a - pours an opaque golden hue with limited head and noticeable lacing s - apples , bleu-cheese , cherry pie dominate the aroma , surprisingly . citrus and grapefruit as it warms . t - very sweet , especially for an ipa .  body is depressingly light . very nonexistent in the finish . taking bigger an bigger sips just to capture some flavor . smooth , but light . bitterness in the aftertaste follows a big gulp .

aroma of spruce and tiger lillies . supremely floral . this is not the aroma of your average triple . this beer could be marketed as liquid potpourri , and i 'd be proud to buy a lame plug-in air freshener that smelled like this . certainly , all the qualities are there .  the mouthfeel is disappointing with absolutely no carbonation and mild flavors lingering around . overall , i could have possibly gotten a flat beer but this beer had potential ( when carbonated ) but it didnt come through in my bottle .
smell is of fresh hop , so fresh.just layers of vegetal , cirtusy hops with a slight hint of pine and pale malt .  mouth is thin and watery . too simple and too one dimensional and thin .

grapefruit ! my favorite aroma in beer and life for some strange reason , but enough about me ... .once i break from my grapefruit coma , i do notice pine and a little lemon rind in the background t - there is that damn grapefruit again , i just ca n't get away from it . immense hop flavor with a surprising amount of malt that finds its way through the hops .  mouthfeel is thin for the style .

as the beer warms , these scents blend beautifully . t : opens tart with assertive notes of grapefruit , lemon , bitter orange , kumquat , grass , salty brine , and oaky , lactic yeast .  2.5 m very light , i am not impressed . it is very close to water in feel .
smells delicious . ( t ) bold combination of mild coffee and chocolate , with a sweet , smoky flavor .  the mouthfeel is syrupy and shows none of the carbonation that the pour hinted at .

quite delicious , but not quite as good as the nose led me to believe . m. thin with a good level of carbonation d. i was a bit disappointed with the taste after the incredible smell , but the mouthfeel is really what let me down here .  aside from that , the taste , like the smell , is unremarkable mouthfeel is borderline watery .
the appearance is the best attribute of this beer for it is a nice amber-brown and has a steady head that leaves rings of lace .  the mouhfeel is weak , watery , thin .

nose is `` oh my fucking god '' chocolate . this smells like a combination of the greatest cup of pure milk chocolate , chocolate milk or hot chocolate with touches of espresso , coffee , dark burnt coffee beans and pure vanilla beans .  taste is weak , almost watery , has to be drank ice cold or has a taste like vomit . bottom line is compared to other cheap beers pbr excels in taste , quality , and conveniently the price , 7 bucks a 12 pack .

smell : the smell is a wonderful mix of rich malts and strong , powerfully complex hops that are almost perfectly balanced . perhaps this flying dog may stand the test ... taste and mouthfeel : the taste is not as good as expected , but still not bad . drinkability and overall : this beer is just a tiny bit above the average ipa , but definitly nothing too seek out .  smells basically like apple juice . watery . also , the carbonation that was so present during the pour now seems dulled . for all its faults , in the end rogue makes a malt liquor that achieves what you usually want out of the style .

s : nice big belgian yeast nose . one of the best smelling beers i have ever encountered . t : starts off sweet with some raisins . the worst part of this beer and it was still way above average . d : very drinkable .  m - thin , watery , overly carbonated .

mmmmm , a smell like none other . besides aroma , this is a mighty tasty beer ; absolutely my newest favorite ipa . i could drink a couple of these at once , but like many highly flavorful beers , not my kind of session brew .  mf : it 's medium-bodied at best despite the label 's claims of `` full bodied . '' speaking of which , it has a soda watery type carbonation , not at all the `` luxuriously smooth '' of the label . i have to say that they could get the mouthfeel under control ( i 'd imagine this is less of an issue on tap ) , it would be hands-down my favorite irish stout .
man this was incredible . citrusy herbal if i had to put some words on it .  mouthfeel is equally watery .
roasty , some coffee and chocolate . decadent .  very thin , and barely any head .
the smell is exceptional . tons of different scents .  it 's highly carbonated , and extremely astringent .

very strong baking chocolate smell - the kind that smells delicious but is really dry and ends up too bitter when you taste it . what a deceptive beer - first you notice it because it is a ris in a can , then it looks and smells great , and then it just lets down big time in the taste .  mouthfeel : terrible . after drinking half of this bomber , my mouth is completely numb and i am starting to feel comatose .

nose has a surprising sweetness with tropical fruit esters of subtle pineapple and mango : both were of the dried and sweetened kind of fruit rather than fresh . citrus , earthy , grassy hops balanced with biscuit sweet and bitter malts .  mouthfeel is thin and weak .
overall : a solid fresh hop pale ale with a really good aroma .  mouthfeel : absolutely no carbonation .
s : earthy tart wheat , lots of honey , sweet toffee , and a nice floral hop/heat combination . bit-o-honey candy comes to mind .  the mouthfeel was thin and not terribly hoppy on the palate .

pours very dark brown with a large very foamy light brown head that leaves tons of drippy lacing and holds a nice rocky island and cap .  mouthfeel : the carbonation is very high , way too high , for a milk stout . the body is thin . drinkability : just an ok beer , the mouthfeel also hurts the drinkability .
beautiful color , deep dark amber with beautiful smelling hops and some nice plumy undertones .  m - thin , a little harsh and a bit drying .
smells like sour cherries and sour grapes with a white wine smell .  mouthfeel is excedingly thin and watery .
