i was afraid since this beer emphasized bacon , that it would be like an overly smoked beer that gave a nitrate like amora , but this one is balanced nicely . road tar , malted barley , honey ham , rubber , and charred hickory . absolutely awesome . t- the taste is light and pleasant .  hard to slam the beer that got my through college but ... . the twelfth tasted like the first . not really whatt i consider beer anymore but my in-law says it is more of a beer than budweiser ? could there be a reason you can by `` cooler-packs '' in multiples of 6 !

this one turns from a flurry of cascading cream colored bubbles into a light coppery hue and makes a really thick and fluffy , dense , cream colored head .  the mouthfeel is medium-light bodied with a watery texture , and a little too much carbonation .

a very intriguing nose , wow , minty , citrusy , lemon-grass , soft licorice notes , very pleasant even with its slight funk of oxidation . this is actually quite nice even with its funk , i could deal with a little less carbonation .  taste is malty to start , but very thin . the body leaves one wanting more . dry finish with an almost soda-like feel . despite the lack of body , this beer is rather drinkable .
lots of aromas , raisins , plums , maple sugar candy .  m. thin with no carbonation at all . d. i thought the flavors were interesting , but this beer was much too thin and flat for my taste .

a - no pop when i pull the cork , pours a lifeless , soul sucking , pitch black , with a big oily slick on top , no head s - big nose of chocolate , coffee , vanilla , carmel sweetness , booze , smells pretty damn good t - taste is nowhere near as robust as the aroma , huge coffee flavour , basic sweetness , booze , gigantic roasted coffee finish m - no carbonation , heavy mouthfeel , dry finish , big boozy warmth d - another half assed effort from mikkeller no carbonation , ridiculous , over the top coffee flavour , and massive booziness ( even after cellaring for close to 2 years , best before is aug 2011 ) .  m : light carbonation with a very light watery body .

very nice . nose is absolutely beautiful with belgian chocolate , rich cocoa , caramel , toffee . smells like this one is going to be a whopper ... ... and sadly it 's not . finish is very clean and crisp . the nose , however , is truly wonderful so one should at least experience that .  m : this feels fairly thin ; the flavors fall quickly off the tongue , resulting in a watery finish .

before i can even look more i smell fresh roasted coffee . incredibly nose on this beer .  the taste is cloyingly sweet , viscous , the aromas transfer , and turn very bready on the finish , the middle has cherries candies , almost medicinal the mouth feel is vaguely reminiscent of cough syrup , but watered down . there is no bitterness and even less carbonation .

another malt bomb for me . lots of rich malts with dark fruity characteristics . plumbs come to mind with a cranberry aroma layered with cinnamon and a maple kind of sweetness . the taste is not quite as rich as the aroma . slight hints of pine and not quite as much fruit presence as i 'd expected . decent , but the aroma certainly outshines the actual flavors .  m - one of the first things that i noticed was how thin this beer was . unfortunately , this definitely felt watered down .

this is a seriously complex nose , just tons going on ... fruits , mainly peach , some pineapple ? certainly lemon , white grape , sure , some white pepper , dry lemon rind , citrus , gosh ... it goes on and on and on ... certainly some funk and wildness , dry white wine ... yeah , this is hard to pin down and extremely academic , enjoyable , and all around good . t. follows , lots of dry white wine , peachy , semi-sweet , spicy , earthy , some tire , champagne , peach again , no real hop , dry , wild , funky , lemon-citric , seriously interesting , challenging , to be sure , but i am digging it . fun to try and get your palate around . d. not really , this is something to share and comment on , and take your time with .  almost no body present .
smells amazing ! t - not too much smoke , bet definitely present .  mouthfeel was quite thin and highly over carbonated .

`` hello , my name is coriander and pepper '' says the aroma in a pleasing fashion . a bit heavier and sweeter than i would like hurts its drinkability , but the great aroma and pleasant flavor make this a very nice beer .  the mouthfeel is light to medium bodied and just way too thin and watery for an oatmeal stout .
smell : smells like a nice rich coffee from sbux with tons of caramel added .  watery and flat in my mouth .

the aroma of this beer is really something -- it 's powerfully strawberry , like sticking your nose into a jar of jam . very appealing , assuming you 're really into the idea of strawberry beer . but i was disappointed with the taste -- it 's less strawberry lambic than just strawberry juice , a powerfully sweet , syrupy brew with no real malt or hop presence .  the beer was entirely too light bodied for a stout , this really was one of the most disappointing elements of the beer .
this beer smells so good ! sweet with almost a balsamic vinegar quality . great . tart , sour gets me in the back of the mouth .  mouthfeel is thin and watery .

taste is very boring after the wonderful aroma . this almost has no taste whatsoever .  beer is black in color , with very little light showing through when held up to the ceiling s- after some swirls , gives off a boozy sweet aroma with notes of wood t- well , it has a very good flavor starting out malty sweet with dark fruits , then gets an added booziness a with notes of wood m- has a full body but there 's pretty much no carbonation d- its a shame , if this had at least a hint more carbonation , it would have been a pretty stellar beer because the flavor is there .

exquisite nose has brandy , oak , vanilla , dark pitted fruits , candy malts , port wine and whiskey . taste does not hold the same complexity . some tart cherries , plums , caramel , toffee , wood , vanilla , wine grapes and cognac . past prime for sure , but still an interesting beer .  not thick at all , but lacking carbonation .

s : wonderful nose . toasted notes with some malt character hiding behind it .  but it seemed way too flat and thin . the favor is there , but the body is not . unless you have a pathological obsession with oatmeal stouts , look elsewhere for your beer drinking needs
great nose of banana , passionfruit , cloves and green apples .  taste is very light and mouthfeel is weak .

it 's quite clear and straw/amber colored . it has a very strong smell of fresh hops . pine , citrus , and maybe a bit of tropical fruit , but quite spicy . the smell is the only part of this beer to reflect it 's ipa label .  mouthfeel - watery .

plenty of other fruit aromas to go around . t : like all hop bombs for me , a great aroma but as i take a sip a mouth puckering bitterness takes over . though this is still a very bitter beer . slick and oily . it looks amazing with a great nose . just to bitter for me .  m - watery . too thin , especially for a beer so strong , and meant to be malt-forward .
aroma is big citrus , sweet fruit , tropical and juicy .  unfortunately it takes on flat , syrupy , and warm qualities from the cask . it needs more carbonation to lift it .
smelled great , very witbier like , coriander , fermented yeast , spices and citrus .  mouthfeel is very flat .

look : it poured a transparent orange-brown colour with a thin tannish head that did not disappear smell : exceptional . it smells delicious . a little sour with some sweetness in there .  m - maybe i 've had too many rises recently , but this is thin , very very thin .

smell only needs one word : raspberries . lots of raspberries . also smells a bit tart and kind of like juice . very sweet and tart at the same time .  a - medium to dark amber ; almost no head , but what little bubbling there was at the edge of the glass managed to leave a slight bit of lacing s - there was nearly no aroma , and what was there was nothing distinctive t - good malt/hop balance with pleasantly surprising bitter finish m - far too thin and too little carbonation in this sample ; a bit of a sticky finish d - though it will not be mistaken for a world-class brew , this one is easy to suck down since it is thin and flavorful ; without the sticky finish , it would score a half-tick higher

s- large amount of aromatics here ! strongly grapefruit in character , citrus of oranges and lemons behind that , notebook paper , and minute hops profile . t- the grapefruit is a tease . i prefer to smell it to be honest , but that wo n't last forever . the hops become distracting towards the middle , but it is no where near the annoyance of a hop bomb .  mouthfeel is flat but this is the only disappointment .

the aroma is pretty complex like any respectable barleywine , but definitely more on the malt side . brown sugar is obvious and is of pleasant company to figs , peaches , alcohol and an all-around complex fruitiness .  smells and tastes bland and grain like . almost stale . it is a good beer to party with if all your doin is playin beer pong or circle .

a truly wonderful bouquet . taste accents of hops and light fruits , again pineapple , with a delayed afterthought of hops bitterness at the back of the throat . a tasty and sexy organic brew .  mouthfeel is somwhat thin for a baltic porter , with more carbonation then i 'd like .

smell is incredible . only the most dazzling gets a 5,0 , but if there were a 4,75 , i 'd definitely give it to 'smell ' on this one . to my regret , while still very good , this smells quite a bit better than it tastes . definitely good , but not even close to the depth and complexity in the smell .  m - very thin and watery with flat carbonation .

good retention and lacing ... the aroma is pretty nice , sweet candy wheat , honey , floral finish ... the taste really is disappointing , borderline bad . pretty disappointing for me after such a great aroma . i ca n't recommend this .  m - syrupy , mouth coating body with an obnoxious amount of carbonation . carbonation is prickly and really too much as i feel like i ca n't taste everything because of it . it does get better the more you let it warm and let the carbonation die down .

huge fruity aroma , kind of a grapefruit/lemon hybrid . extremely bitter , even for a west coast ipa . this makes for a tasty , although not particularly well balanced , ipa .  the mouthfeel is very thin and highly carbonated , very reminiscent of your typical macro lager .

smell : complex nose boasts belgian yeast with a sweet apricot note and some underlying white pepper spice . complexities abound . taste : a well balanced tripel with a nice peppery spice and undistinguishable fruit presence . overall : solid , solid tripel . very fine beer .  mouthfeel : medium-bodied . it took much diligence to see my way to the end of this beer , and , were it not for the runaway carbonation , it could 've been far better . one to revisit , provided they clear up the carbonation issue .

definite lactose on the nose although emphasis is placed much more firmly upon the strong roasted and baker 's chocolate qualities of the beer . once again , lactose shows itself with a vaguely milky start and a kiss of sugar at the finish ( along with bitter chocolate ) .  almost watery .

you can smell the fresh raspberry puree aroma from almost 2 feet away ! the first sip hits you with an insane burst , it tastes like you just bit into a big overly ripe juicy berry . i really enjoyed this but personally could not do more than say 2 or so glasses at a sitting , since there is so much flavor , so it would not be a good session beer , but it really is very great tasting !  the flavor was both too light and 'way too bitter for a pils . it was watery and lacking in aroma . not much foam - what there was disappeared quickly . the word i 'd use to describe this beer is `` insubstantial . ''

aromas begin with dark dark fruits , leather , oak and light light bourbon . as it warms more you get apple skin and vinous grape notes . really complex to say the least . overall i am really pleased with this beer .  m - light and fizzy , thin bodied .

terrific chocolate and coffee notes with some fruity hints as well .  mouthfeel : this beer is almost watery yet with a hint to tannins that leave my mouth dry and scratchy . the beer had a watery texture in my mouth and the flavors were not in balance with the nose . while it did have a light mouthfeel and i am used to drinking hoppy dry beers , this beer would have had an easy drinkabilty yet with its unbalanced flavors i had very little desire to do so .

this beer was very jeckyll and hyde for me . the smell is also terrific : citrusy , apricot , peach ( as others have noted ) .  it lacks a big full mouthfeel , and is actually very watery and disappointing .

the aroma is very roasty and has plenty of chocolate notes . smells very nice .  mouth : enters the mouth with very light carbonation that flattens as it goes back . overall , it 's not a bad brew , it 's got a great hop flavor but not enough depth or balance , and the weak mouthfeel ruins the experience .
the smell of this beer is lovely ; nothing but cherries .  mouthfeel is weak and watery .
nose is heaven , sweet green apples , almost like a sour cider .  mouthfeel - very light and dry .
) , puckered 10/06 slow pour in a tulip glass poured murky pale orange with a huge rocky fully lasting white head with good lacing .  body is way too thick , sweet , and syrupy .

s- strong aroma of banana , clove , yeast , pear , bubblegum , wheat , nuttiness , and spice . complex and aromatic . t- banana , clove , pear , lots of spice , and the alcohol was surprisingly prominent , some warming . m- pretty high carbonation , crisp , finishes dry , drinks smooth o- first weizenbock i have ever had .  but i felt i owed it to myself to see if smaller carbonation meant bigger taste .

aroma is predominately belgian funk and gambrinus honey malt . flavor is pilsen , honey , and belgian aromatic malt with just enough hop to balance . yeast flavor is a very nice blend of straight belgian and brett .  carbonation is way too strong .

a trace of lacing & head retention s : dates , raisins , steel & port soaked raisins t : rich dark fruits , herbal & leafy hop bitterness up front . started strong , but the dryness & oakyness detracted as this warmed mf : slightlty overgassed , medium bodied & with fair balance drinks easy , but this one could use at least 12-18 more months of aging , not a bad take on the style  mouthfeel is thin for a ris , almost watery .

aroma is complex , vinous , hay-ish with hints of scotch or cognac , appealing old cereals past their prime complements sweet caramelic malt . it smells old malt basically . taste is on the sweet side , lots of toffee/maple flavours with honest hints at wood and resin . very vinous , but certainly less intense than the beautiful aroma . once the yeast comes into play , it becomes drier , earthy with a dirty waters feel .  taste : largely dry ; bland notes of roast upfront and throughout ; slightly sour with a mildly bitter finish ; hints of chocolate ; somewhat light bodied ; thin mouthfeel .

great smell . on the buds , the mint is first and foremost .  i 'm going to have to go against the gimmick and with the style here , the mouthfeel just is n't there . i 'm not impressed at all , it 's like a half flat beer that you 've left on your desk whilst reviewing a beer and forgotten about it only to come back to it 30 mins later . the shining point of this beer is it 's drinkability .

aroma is smack you in the face hop blast appropriate for a pnw ipa . taking dry-hopping to its logical extreme with several whole hop cones in each bottle .  mouthfeel/ drinkability : the carbonation isnt stinging and seems appropriate . the body of the beer seems far too thin .

smells great though . tart aromas and there is some great fruity and malty notes there too .  a nice chocolatey finish that lingers for a while on the palate is the best part about this beer . m : poor .

smells very delightful , just like fresh lemonade .  nose : it 's aroma is a little bit malty , a little bit citrusy flavor : the taste has some lemon/citrus notes w/ some hints of maltiness , but the big thing that you notice is how fizzy this beer is . it 's far too fizzy for me .

s - the nose on this one is as good as it gets . t - just wonderful - almost as perfect as the nose . this outstanding beer 's only downfall . d - great . tons of booze and heat on this one , but the outstanding vanilla and coconut flavors allow me to drink as much of this as is available !  mouthfeel is kind of thin and not very pleasant as the carbonation dies down and leaves a sort of flat cola sensation , without the stickiness .

smell : wow , mazing ! roasty , dark chocolate , very coffee forward , sweetness . taste : very good , nice and roasty . overall : very good beer , i would certainly want to have this again .  d-a little rough on the palate with the huge carbonation and extremely grainy feel .
has a nice aroma of sweet carmely malt and spicey hops .  mouthfeel is boring and watery .

very poor and lazy design with 3ded fonts . extraordinary head towering above the glass , great retention , surface memory , and frothy lacing .  on first taste the mouthfeel seems a little thin . all in all tasty , but quite thin and seriously lacking in body .
very very nice . very complex .  watery mouthfeel in terms of a stout .
very nice aroma ! very nice beer .  medium body . nearly flat .

i 'm intrigued by the label that tells me this beer is a mix of young and old ipas aged in french oak ; intrigued because i like hops and like the effect that age can have on hops . i liked the earthy , woody aroma of this ale . i liked how the earthiness and vanilla-oakiness emerged among the caremelly malt and herbal hop flavors .  m - the body is vanishingly thin and i feel the carbonation is too high for an english porter .

the aroma is great , extreamly fresh .  mouthfeel is overly fizzy , making an already light beer even fluffier . overall , this is an interesting beer that could be very refreshing if less carbonated .

aromas are just awesome ... deep rich fruits , candy sugar , plenty of oak barrel , dark bread-like yeast character , and some orange peel in the back . maple and molasses in the sweetness , with just a touch of citrus rhind hops in the finish . not overly chewy , which was nice for this strength of beer .  neither was the taste - a bit bitter , no real aftertaste , with a weak , watery mouth feel .

what an aroma ! ! ! funky , fruity , sweetyeast , vinegar , spicemagic marker , sugar , oak , vanilla , cherries , sour-candies.you cant count all the smells . the taste is equally thrilling.sour and mouth puckering one minute , sweet and succulent the next . this brew is a little sweeter than expected , and very earthy . at times it seems to have a musty , woods-like quality about it . lingering , funky finish .  not the worst tasting beer ever , but very thin and watery .

the aroma of berry funk with a hint of crust that smells delicious . the appearance is rich pinot wine color with a white head and tons of berry sediment floating on top .  mouthfeel was thin like water , very little body .

the smell is quite good : belgian yeast funk , candi sugar , orange peel and coriander . it has more of the belgian yeast aroma than most wit brews . not as heavy on the orange peel and coriander as most wits ; which i find to be a good thing .  m- spritzy , carbonation fills your mouth swelling your cheeks slightly . rough , bubbly and thin .

very vibrant fruity/floral aroma with a hint of peat , grain and sweet caramel malt . all these blend perfectly together to make a fantastic aroma . certainly the best aspect of this beer . it tastes very much like the aroma - fruity berry , white grape flavors with a little herbal spiciness . the flavors are n't as rich as the aroma would suggest . a really nice beer overall . i genuinely enjoyed it , but i only with the flavors were richer .  2/5 m : thin and watery with medium carbonation .

boozy for sure . notes : the nose is pretty friggin ' great . the palate feels thin for the style and the flavors that it 's supporting .  good for a lager , but way too much carbonation really throwing this beer off .
nice warm smells , clear and well-executed .  thin body looked nice in the glass , but was over carbonated . kind of a watery finish .

aroma : heavenly . roasted malt , chocolate , a hint of coffee , and i detected a hint of whiskey aroma that was very pleasant . taste and mouthfeel : slightly chewy but not quite creamy .  was excited to see this one.. but again newcastle has let me down again ... on the bottle it says `` blood red ale '' .. it pours a reddish-brown color.. smells a little funky ... way too carbonated for my liking .

has a solid malt flavor with a huge hop aroma . i could use a tad more bitterness but that is just a personal preference .  really fizzy ( like coca-cola fizzy ) on the tongue , with a metallic finish , not really what i was hoping for , dissapointing .
